title: Penn State wrestling stays on road, wrestles Northwestern
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Penn State will stay on the road and travel nearly four hours east of Iowa City to Evanston, Illinois to take on Northwestern in the second dual of the weekend.

The Nittany Lions will take on the Wildcats at 3 p.m. Sunday, with the matchup being streamed on Big Ten Plus.

No. 1 Penn State is coming off a 32-3 victory against No. 4 Iowa in front of a raucous Carver-Hawkeye Arena. On the other side, Northwestern fell to No. 18 Wisconsin, 28-12, in Madison, Wisconsin. Now, the Nittany Lions will head to Evanston in an attempt to keep their historic win streak alive.

Here’s how each weight class matches up ahead of the Sunday matinee dual.

125: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 26 Dedrick Navarro (NU)

Dedrick Navarro’s ranking understates his ability after a victory over No. 11 Nicolar Rivera. However, Rivera isn’t in the same tier as Luke Lilledahl, who just defeated No. 6 Dean Peterson.

Lilledahl brings a style that isn’t normal, a quick, slippery approach that catches most opponents off guard. Coming off a convincing victory, the Nittany Lion could get back to his bonus-point scoring.

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 24 Sean Spidle (NU)

Continuing with what are the best matches on paper, Marcus Blaze and Sean Spidle will face off in a young vs. old match. Blaze is a true freshman, who’s still undefeated, while Spidle holds an 11-5 record as a redshirt senior.

Blaze is coming off a victory over 2025 national finalist, Drake Ayala, and could continue his dominant start against a wrestler with less caliber than that of Ayala.

141: No. 7 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 32 Billy Dekraker (NU)

Braeden Davis was the only wrestler to lose in the Nittany Lions’ dual against Iowa. However, he’ll take on a significantly lower-ranked opponent in Billy Dekraker. The Wildcat came out victorious against an unranked Wisconsin wrestler, but will take on a top-10 wrestler in Davis.

Davis is still acclimating himself to full-time wrestling after getting his redshirt pulled. He was noticeably gassed in his match against No. 11 Nasir Bailey of Iowa, but could put that behind him to get his first ranked victory of the season.

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. Sam Cartella (NU)

Shayne Van Ness proved he’s a force to be reckoned with after defeating No. 17 Ryder Block of Iowa. Against Northwestern, Van Ness could face an unranked Sam Cartella.

Van Ness will put his 12-0 record on the line against Cartella or August Hibler, who wrestled against Wisconsin. Hibler fell 11-6 to No. 16 Joseph Zargo and would face an even tougher opponent on Sunday if he wrestles both matches on the weekend.

With the Wildcats’ 149-pound starter still unknown, it could allow Van Ness to showcase his strength and earn bonus points.

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. Gunnar Myers (NU)

Starting at 149 pounds with Van Ness, and continuing at 157 pounds, the Nittany Lions could really catapult the dual score. PJ Duke won a tight battle against No. 12 Jordan Williams of Iowa, but gets a lighter opponent in Gunnar Myers, who’s unranked on the season.

Myers lost by a major decision to No. 26 Luke Mechler, a 23-rank difference from Duke who’s undefeated and a national title contender. Duke could add yet another bonus-point victory to his resumé, while remaining undefeated in his inaugural season.

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. Jacob Bostelman (NU)

Mitchell Mesenbrink proved yet again he’s on a tier of his own against Iowa. He took down No. 3 Michael Caliendo for the seventh time in his career, extending the gap between him and the Hawkeye after Caliendo closed it at the Big Ten Championships and the NCAA Championships.

Mesenbrink will face a significantly worse opponent on paper. Jacob Bostelman lost by tech fall to No. 26 Cody Goebel. Mesenbrink’s gas tank has been unmatched ever since his championship match against Iowa State’s David Carr in 2024.

With a significantly stronger emphasis on back points and falls, Mesenbrink could add to his pinfall total.

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. No. 32 Eddie Enright (NU)

Levi Haines will take on Northwestern’s final ranked wrestler in chronological order from lightest to heaviest weight classes.

Haines wrestled a close match against Gabe Arnold, who has bounced around multiple weight classes during his career. However, Haines will take on a wrestler who’s 18-5 heading into Sunday. The Nittany Lion has also had more of a focus on back points, especially after fully filling into the 174-pound weight class.

Enright will have his hands full with Haines, who provides a mix of speed and power, and is currently in a tier of his own at 174.

184: No. 4 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. J.D. Perez (NU)

Rocco Welsh had arguably the biggest win of the entire season, earning a defensively focused victory over No. 1 Angelo Ferrari. Welsh showed poise and patience, defeating Ferrari in tiebreakers, keeping Ferrari down for 27 seconds.

Now, Welsh can show more of his aggressive side against J.D. Perez. The Wildcat took down Caleb Dennee, 7-6, but will have his hands full with potentially the next No. 1-wrestler at 184 when the updated InterMat poll is released.

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. Alex Smith (NU)

Josh Barr is fully back from his injury, and didn’t have to face one of his initial big tests in Massoma Endene, who’s no longer on Iowa’s roster.

Barr will take on another unranked opponent in Alex Smith, who’s struggled against ranked wrestlers. Smith lost by fall to No. 28 Wyatt Ingham of Wisconsin, and Barr appears to be a different kind of beast as the leading candidate for the national title with his No. 1 ranking.

The final weight classes could prove to be the dagger in a blowout victory for the Nittany Lions.

285: No. 13 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. Gabe Christenson (NU)

Another wrestler who’s coming off the biggest win of his season is Cole Mirasola, who is riding high heading into his unranked matchup. Mirasola took down No. 5 Ben Kueter of Iowa, solidifying his spot as an All-American threat.

Gabe Christenson hasn’t had success against ranked wrestlers, and Mirasola provides a different kind of heavyweight for him. The Nittany Lion is one of the more undersized heavyweights, something that’ll allow the Wildcat to match up better, as he’s listed on the roster at 197 pounds.

Mirasola will be the heavier wrestler for likely one of the only times in his career against a wrestler who typically wrestles at 197.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Flo Rida performs for SPA Day 2026
author: Rebecca Fein | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State’s Student Programming Association (SPA) hosted its annual SPA Day on Friday in the HUB-Robeson Center and featured a performance by Flo Rida with special guest DJ Temi in Alumni Hall.

The day’s events included virtual reality racing, slime-making, sand kit art and an at-home rage room before culminating in the evening concert.

Flo Rida, also known as Tamer Dillard, is a Grammy-nominated artist who rose to fame in 2008 with the release of his debut single “Low” featuring T-Pain. He is best known for hits such as “Club Can’t Handle Me” featuring David Guetta, “Good Feeling” and “My House.”

DJ Temi opened the show, and is a graduate student who serves as the official game day DJ for Penn State Football and the women’s basketball team.

Hana Mohd Yusrizal attended the concert to hear some of her favorite songs and enjoy the spring semester.

“I love Flo Rida and I’m a huge fan, so it’s such a fun way to spend my time, especially since I’m graduating in the spring,” Yusrizal, a fourth-year studying mechanical engineering said. “My favorite Flo Rida song is definitely ‘Whistle’ because I love the Josh Hutcherson meme.”

Angelica Laughner said she came to dance to all of Flo Rida’s songs.

“My friend is in SPA and I wanted to come support her, but I also love music — specifically rock and emo — but 100% Flo Rida,” Laughner, a first-year studying nutritional sciences, said.

Tanvi Joshi, the concert chair for SPA, said she was excited to bring a throwback vibe to Penn State.

“As concert chair for SPA, I’m in charge of making three to four concerts for the student body,” Joshi, a third-year studying Economics and Telecommunications and Media Industries, said. ”I work with all of SPA to brainstorm, rank and select who we want to bring in.”

Joshi took inspiration from the recent online trend centered around bringing back 2010s culture.

“I have been a big fan of Flo Rida’s music for a long time and the theme of this event is very 2016 because in 2026 we wanted to bring that vibe back,” Joshi said. “SPA wanted to get someone who has those old generation bangers because that time was so fun and we wanted to be a part of bringing it back.”

MORE LIFESTYLE CONTENT

title: Special teams propel No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey to conference win over Notre Dame
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Heading into No. 8 Penn State and Notre Dame’s first meeting of the season, they were two of the three most penalized teams in the country, meaning a special teams battle was likely ahead. After a combined 14 penalties and 41 penalty minutes, those proved to be the difference maker Friday night.

The Nittany Lions’ special teams propelled them to a 4-1 conference victory over the Fighting Irish.

The blue and white took to the ice in front of a lively Roar Zone — the first time the home team had played in front of the packed student section in over two months.

Both teams were dealing with holes in the lineups after Penn State was hit with the injury bug, forcing it to skate with only 11 forwards, and Notre Dame’s leading scorer, defenseman Paul Fischer, was suspended for the two-game series.

The opening minutes were largely a back-and-forth battle, with both teams trying to find their offensive momentum.

The game saw its first penalty a little over halfway through the first period, after Notre Dame’s Jayden Davis was called for interference, sending the Nittany Lions to the power play.

About 40 seconds in, forward Matt DiMarsico broke the ice for the blue and white, set up by a tic-tac-toe passing sequence with Gavin McKenna and Luke Misa.

The Fighting Irish — and their No. 7 nationally ranked power play — got their own opportunity a few minutes later, after senior defenseman Jarod Crespo was called for holding.

Penn State’s penalty kill unit, along with a very solid performance from goaltender Josh Fleming, kept Notre Dame off the board on the man-advantage.

“I was really happy with the penalty kill,” Guy Gadowsky said. “(Notre Dame’s) an excellent power play team…but all in all, I thought all game the penalty kill was really good.”

With just over a minute to go in the first frame, Davis headed back to the box, this time for high-sticking, but Penn State couldn’t capitalize on its second attempt.

The physicality, while always present, ramped up in the middle frame.

Notre Dame’s Cole Brown laid a high hit on captain Dane Dowiak, and the freshman was awarded a five-minute major and a game misconduct, while the blue and white headed to an extended man-advantage.

DiMarsico once again took advantage of the extra attacker and fired a shot on net that was redirected out in front of goaltender Nicholas Kempf and found the back of the net.

Notre Dame answered with a power play goal of its own shortly after, after Crespo made his second trip to the penalty box.

The blue and white regained its two-goal lead and tallied its third power play score of the night with about two minutes to go in the middle frame, after Sutter Muzzatti’s roughing penalty led to Misa tallying his third point of the night off a one-timer that rocketed past Kempf.

“We were moving pucks really well, I mean, we were playing with speed, we’re winning faceoffs too,” Misa said. “(the power play) was just clicking today.”

The theme of penalties continued on into the final period, first with the Nittany Lions’ Carter Schade being sent to the box for hooking. The home team’s penalty kill once again held strong and maintained its lead.

The intensity boiled over late in the third period, starting with defenseman Jackson Smith laying out a Notre Dame skater to the roar of the crowd. Muzzatti retaliated and went after freshman McKenna along the boards, and was quickly surrounded by Nittany Lions.

Both Muzzatti and Smith walked away with penalties, but the 4-on-4 quickly turned to a 4-on-3 after Reese Laubach was given a slashing penalty 30 seconds later.

After pulling the goaltender, Notre Dame had a two-skater advantage for its last push in an attempt to close its gap, but the blue and white’s strong defensive efforts continued through the final minutes.

DiMarsico sealed the game and a dominant performance, with an empty net goal to tally his third hat trick of the season, and 13th total goal.

“It’s hard to talk about him because I don’t understand. I don’t know how he does what he does,” Gadowsky said. “His mind is elite. His stick is better than elite.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Dowiak, Misa propel undermanned No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey past Notre Dame
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 8 Penn State swept Minnesota last weekend, but it came at a cost.

Star forward Charlie Cerrato exited Friday’s 3-0 win with an injury that caused him to miss Saturday’s 5-2 victory. The next night, forward Braeden Ford was helped off the ice with a lower-body injury that head coach Guy Gadowsky said will sideline him for a “significant amount of time.”

With forward Keaton Peters out for the season and forward Shea Van Olm sidelined with an injury, the Nittany Lions were thin offensively as they welcomed Notre Dame on Friday at Pegula Ice Arena.

Down to just 11 forwards, Penn State defeated Notre Dame 4-1. The win propelled the Nittany Lions to 15-6 and marked their fourth straight Big Ten victory.

Following a goaltender interference penalty against Notre Dame’s Jayden Davis, Penn State earned the game’s first power play. And on the man advantage, two of its stars connected with a new power-play linemate to break through.

As he typically does when given time and space, a calm Gavin McKenna scanned the ice before lasering a pass to Luka Misa. The freshman forward, who filled in for Cerrato on Penn State’s top power-play line, one-timed a pass to Matt DiMarsico, who ripped a slap shot into the top right corner to give the Nittany Lions a 1-0 lead.

But Misa wasn’t done there.

After DiMarsico and Notre Dame’s Evan Werner traded goals, the Nittany Lions were back on the power play. And off a slot feed from Ben Schoen, Misa rifled one beyond Nicholas Kempf’s outstretched glove to give Penn State a 3-1 advantage.

A MISA MISSILE!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/7gPZijln2t— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 17, 2026

It was his seventh point in his last five games — a turning point for a forward whose lack of production had undermined a terrific start to his freshman campaign.

“Things have just started going my way,” Misa said. “I feel like I had a lot of chances in the (first) half, but things just weren't going in. So it's nice to see things go down.”

To provide context to the extent of Penn State’s injury bug, it forced Gadowsky to play three defensemen on the same line several times, with extra skater and natural defenseman Nick Fascia serving as a de facto forward. The team even left the fourth-line right winger spot blank on the pregame lineup sheet because there was no healthy forward to fill it with.

While some played different roles, forward Dane Dowiak showed up as his typical gritty self, and Penn State’s captain drew two penalties, each leading to a power-play goal.

Early in the second period, Dowiak outraced Notre Dame’s Cole Brown for a loose puck along the boards of Penn State’s defensive zone. A frustrated Brown leveled Dowiak with a booming hit to the head, drawing the ire of the Pegula fans.

“Dane is a tough kid. When you talk about a guy stepping up in a leadership role, that's what you had from him tonight,” Gadowsky said. “He played tough. He won faceoffs. He stuck up for his team. He did everything that a leader should do.”

The officials handed Brown a five-minute major and a game misconduct, which led to Penn State’s first tally. Later in the period, Dowiak caught another high hit while scrapping for a loose puck among three Fighting Irish skaters.

The defense cleared the puck, and Dowiak drew another penalty, this one a roughing call on Sutter Muzzatti. Misa scored shortly after to give the Nittany Lions some cushion in a tight contest — a testament to his captain’s resolute play.

“(Dane) is our captain. He's our leader,” DiMarsico said. “To see a guy take a couple of hits like that and not retaliate at all sends a message to the power play that you gotta have that same work ethic. If someone's going to take a hit like that and not respond, you better make it worth it.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State built on opening weekend score, defeats Illinois away from Rec Hall
author: Caroline Riley | The Daily Collegian
description:
After securing its highest-ever home opening score against Yale last weekend, Penn State women’s gymnastics traveled to Illinois to try to better last weekend’s historic effort.

Penn State started a winning streak with a victory over Illinois, 196.075-194.100, short of last week’s massive Week One score.

Rotation One

The first away meet of the year brought new challenges for Penn State, like opening on bars.

Ellie Monahan opened the rotation in a big way for head coach Sarah Brown. She was a bit short on her first handstand and pirouette on the low bar, but just a small hop on her dismount opened the meet with a strong 9.775.

Jessica Johanson followed it up with an ever cleaner routine. Similar to Monahan, she had to take a hop on her dismount, also scoring a 9.775. Elizabeth Leary put up a massive routine in the middle of the lineup, nailing her straddled jaeger to overshoot connection, followed by a perfectly stuck dismount. She improved from last week’s routine with a 9.850.

Ava Piedrahita, coming off her ACL injury last season, was back in the bars lineup. She showcased textbook form throughout, taking just a small shuffle on her dismount, putting a huge exclamation mark on her bars debut with a massive 9.925.

Ava Cash was aggressive on her opening handstand, but with her shoulders and hips too far over the bar, she came off. Starting her whole routine over after the fall, the freshman scored a low 8.900.

Looking to drop Cash’s score, Dani Lartronica did not hold back. She hit her handstands right on top of the bar, nailed her piked jaeger, and stuck her toe-shoot piked half for a 9.875 to end the rotation.

Meanwhile, on the vault, Illinois showed off a few strong Yurchenko fulls with some key missteps in the lineup for a 48.625 trailing Penn State’s 49.200 total. The highlight was Chloe Cho’s 9.800.

Rotation Two

Leary opened up with a powerful Yurchenko full, resulting in a large hop back after a strong block, scoring a 9.700. Cash followed it up with a massive Yurchenko full. She had some leg separation on the table and a hop back for a 9.700.

Bringing back her Yurchenko one and a half this season, Kaempfer slightly underrotated her vault, needing to take a step back. Starting out of a 10.0, the sophomore managed a 9.775. Johanson had one of the strongest Yurchenko fulls with just a small hop for a rotation-high 9.825.

Latronica had another small hop on her Yurchenko full for a 9.775. Piedhraita took just a small hop on her half on, pike off for another 9.775 to anchor the rotation.

On the bars, Illinois picked up the momentum. Cho continued her incredible night with a massive 9.950 to pass Piedrahita to win the event. Lyden Saltness ended the rotation with a 9.900 as well, but it wasn’t enough as Penn State led after two rotations, 98.050-97.550.

Rotation Three

Not Penn State’s strongest event, the Nittany Lions needed to keep up the momentum. Johanson, not in the floor lineup last weekend, led off and did just that. She opened with a strong double pike. One and a half into a front half with another strong landing to get the rotation off to the right start with a 9.800.

Monhanan, a front tumbler built off Johanson’s performance. She opened with a front double full and finished with a front lay front full, all with solid landings for another 9.800.

Ashley Maul opened her routine with a massive stuck double tuck, not needing to lunge back. On her second, she was short on her layout after underrotating her one and a half for a low 9.625.

Bella Misiura opened with an E pass, a front double full. She finished with a front full but was unable to continue her front layout, needing to tuck her legs, bringing her start value down, scoring a low 9.475.

Alyssa Kramer tried to get the Nittany Lions back on track. Another strong front tumbler, she opened with a big front double full and finished with a Rudi to layout stepout to score a 9.825.

Kalea McElligott anchored the rotation with a gorgeous double tuck and a one-and-a-half to front layout for a 9.825 to help Penn State hold the lead.

On the beam, Illinois faced a lot of struggles, including a fall. However, Cho continued her strong night with a big 9.675. Despite their struggles on the floor, the Nittany Lions still led Illinois 146.925 or 146.575-145.850 going into the final rotation.

Rotation Four

Closing out on beam, the blue and white bounced back from a low 48.875 on the floor. Monahan led off with a front toss to swing down acro series, taking a small hop on her dismount for a 9.800.

Kramer bailed her backhandspring-layout stepout to keep the momentum going for a 9.775. Maul crushed her triple series and stuck her landing cold for a huge 9.850. McElligott followed up Maul with another massive triple series and stuck a dismount for a matching 9.850.

Leary followed with another triple series and stuck dismount, copying and pasting three straight routines for a 9.775. Latronica nailed her series as well, showcasing her flexibility and clean lines for a rotation-high 9.875 in the anchor position.

Despite a strong floor rotation, including Cho’s event-winning tying 9.825, it wasn’t enough for Illinois to overtake Penn State’s strong beam finish.

Up Next

Penn State welcomes Big Ten foe Maryland at 2 p.m. on Sunday, Jan. 25, in Rec Hall.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Report: Former Penn State LB DaKaari Nelson transfers to NC State
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
On the final day for players to enter the transfer portal, a former Nittany Lion has found a new home.

Ex-Penn State linebacker DaKaari Nelson has transferred to NC State, according to Chris Hummer of CBS Sports.

In three seasons in State College, he appeared in 29 games mainly on special teams, tallying 10 total tackles. His lone start came against Illinois in the 2024 season.

Nelson was a 4-star recruit coming out of Selma High School in Alabama arriving at Happy Valley in 2023 as a member of the safety room. That would be the solo season for him in the secondary, transitioning to linebacker ahead of the 2024 campaign.

He'll join safety King Mack as the second Nittany Lion to depart to play for the Wolfpack this offseason.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s gymnastics tops first night of West Point Open
author: Jimmy Blair | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coming off a win to kick off the year, the Penn State men’s gymnastics team competed in the opening day of the West Point Open on Friday night.

The Nittany Lions combined for a total of 313.500 points at the West Point Open, putting them in first

Bars

The blue and white covered the top three spots on the Parallel Bars with strong performances. Eliran Ioscovich topped the table in the Parallel Bars with a score of 13.800, while Landon Simpson wasn’t far behind in second place with a score of 13.500. Akseli Karsikas tied for third with a 13.200.

The blue and white dominated in the High Bar, with Karsikas and Michael Artlip rounding off the top two with 13.600 and 13.100, respectively. Simpson and Kacper Garnczarek placed sixth and eighth as well. With these performances, the blue and white found themselves in four of the top eight spots in the category.

Floor

On the Floor, Artlip topped the table with a 13.750, and Matthew Underhill slotted behind him into second with a 13.650. Kellen Ryan’s 13.400 got him into fourth, with Shaun Smith and Simpson both scoring 13.300, tying them in the sixth spot.

Pommel horse

The Pommel Horse was commanded by Landon Simpson for the blue and white, placing third with a 13.700. Garnczarek was the second highest for the blue and white in the category, with a 13.050 slotting him into ninth

Rings

The Nittany Lions dominated the Still Rings. Underhill placed first with a 13.600, Luke Esparo claimed second with a 13.450, and Karsikas rounded out the top three as all blue and white with a 12.950.

Vault

The Vault stood as the only flaw on the outing for the Nittany Lions, as none of its gymnasts cracked the top five. Shaun Smith scored a 14.100, which was the highest for Penn State. The Lexington, Kentucky, native stood as the only blue and white gymnast to score above a 14, as his five accompanying teammates in the event all scored in the 13s.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions continue in the West Point Open on Saturday

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey dominates Notre Dame, extends win streak to four games
author: Chase Fisher | The Daily Collegian
description:
It wasn’t long ago Penn State was winless in Big Ten play, scratching and clawing for its first conference win in South Bend to begin the second half of the 2024-25 campaign. In that instance, the Nittany Lions persevered and defeated Notre Dame to spark a historic 23-game run for the program.

Friday, a mere calendar year later, the roles reversed, as the Fighting Irish were a bleak 0-10 in Big Ten play. This time, it was Penn State defending home ice.

The Nittany Lions did what Notre Dame couldn’t a year ago, winning in their home arena by a final score of 4-1, and extending their win streak to four games.

First period

Penn State came out of the gates firing on all cylinders. The Nittany Lions earned 10 shots on goal through the midway point of the first period, controlling play and dominating offensive-zone time, in large part due to winger Gavin McKenna.

That consistent offensive effort reaped its rewards with just under eight minutes remaining in the frame after Notre Dame center Jayden Davis was pinned with an interference penalty, putting Penn State on the man-advantage.

The Nittany Lions’ power-play unit took the ice and looked the sharpest it has all season. Just 40 seconds into the man-advantage, McKenna engaged in a tic-tac-toe action with wingers Luke Misa and Matt DiMarsico, where he found Misa across ice, who one-tapped the puck to DiMarsico in the bumper.

The junior sniped a relatively wide-open net, breaking the ice and giving the Nittany Lions a 1-0 advantage, which was the only scoring for either team all period.

Second period

Penn State entered the second frame on a short man-advantage, and while it didn’t last long, the Nittany Lions quickly returned to the power play after Notre Dame winger Cole Brown laid a massive hit on center Dane Dowiak along the boards, which the referees determined as a major penalty and game misconduct after a short review.

Unlike the first period, however, Penn State was lifeless in the man-advantage. Over four minutes of game action went by with minimal offensive zone time for the Nittany Lions. But in the final minute of the major penalty, Penn State took a 2-0 lead with a little bit of luck.

DiMarsico leisurely controlled the puck by the right dot before firing a low shot into several bodies in front of Kempf. His shot ricocheted off a skate and into the back of the net to extend the Nittany Lions’ advantage.

The story of the second frame continued to be defined by penalties, as the fourth one of the period, given to defenseman Jarod Crespo, put the Fighting Irish on a 4-on-3. Winger Evan Werner scored on a wrist shot just 37 seconds into Notre Dame’s power play, cutting Penn State’s lead to 2-1.

Over the final 10 minutes of the frame, there were three more penalties, bringing the period total up to seven. The Nittany Lions were the only team to capitalize on one of them, as Misa scored a one-timer off an assist from winger Ben Schoen, with just under three minutes remaining, extending Penn State’s lead to 3-1.

Third period

The third period showcased more back-and-forth action, but nothing added to the scoreboard. Center Reese Laubach owned the best chance, as he had nearly a wide-open net from a rebound off the boards, but Kempf made a sprawling save to keep Notre Dame’s deficit at two.

Three penalties, from both teams combined, in the span of 36 seconds, played into a hectic final five minutes of regulation. The Fighting Irish owned the 4-on-3 due to the penalties. Not much came of it, though, as Notre Dame went scoreless despite Werner ringing a post.

Penn State netminder Josh Fleming was a big proponent of the Nittany Lions killing off their penalties. He stood tall to maintain the Nittany Lions’ lead, finishing the night saving 39-of-40 shots, good for a .975 save percentage.

DiMarsico hit the dagger on Friday, scoring the empty-net goal for his third hat trick of the season.

Injury Report

Center Charlie Cerrato was inactive for a second consecutive game with a day-to-day injury, while winger Braedon Ford remained out with a lower-body injury coach Guy Gadowsky disclosed as “long-term,” on Monday.

Additionally, winger Shea Van Olm was inactive with a day-to-day injury.

Up Next

The Penn State-Notre Dame series will conclude at 8 p.m. Saturday at Pegula Ice Arena.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling downs Iowa in highly anticipated road battle
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 1 Penn State wrestling renewed its greatest rivalry against the No. 4 Iowa Hawkeyes on Friday, traveling to Carver-Hawkeye Arena for its biggest test of the season thus far.

Though the Iowa program is mired in controversy in the past week, they feature a lineup with members who could’ve tested the Nittany Lions.

Penn State defeated the Hawkeyes by a score of 32-3.

125: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs No. 6 Dean Peterson (IOWA)

These two started off with a blaze, with both aiming for an attempt leading to each other flipping out of the circle. Dean Peterson needed a second to recover following the scrum, and when he returned to the circle, Luke Lilledahl took him down.

Peterson shocked Lilledahl by reversing the control for two points and the pair continued a scrappy battle without further scoring for the rest of the first round.

Peterson brought the bout within one point with an escape to start the second frame. He wrapped his arms around Lilledahl and nearly brought him down before Lilledahl countered with a left-handed high crotch to make Peterson lose balance, followed by a double-leg takedown. The second round ended with blood time for Lilledahl.

After Peterson let Lilledahl up to start the third, he secured another takedown to extend his lead to 11-4. Peterson stood up before riding time reached a minute, and Lilledahl was unable to secure a takedown despite holding Peterson’s leg for the final 30 seconds.

Lilledahl defeated Peterson 11-5 in a gritty revenge match after losing to him a year ago.

Penn State 3, Iowa 0

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs No. 8 Drake Ayala (IOWA)

Marcus Blaze and Drake Ayala had a longer feeling out process than the previous match, but neither gained control as they stalemated the entire first round, trying to secure a collar-tie up against each other.

Ayala opened the second round on top and kept Lilledahl locked up for 40 seconds, picking his leg every time Lilledahl reached his feet. Ayala received a stall warning after running out of bounds when Blaze launched an attack. After Ayala received a stall penalty, Blaze completed the takedown before Ayala could reach the edge.

Ayala started the third with a quick escape and began putting pressure on Blaze, pushing him and launching the attacks, looking to come back from a 4-2 deficit. Blaze stalled as Ayala tried to pull him down, receiving a warning but securing the decision, earning a chorus of boos from the Iowa crowd.

Penn State 6, Iowa 0

141: No. 7 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs No. 11 Nasir Bailey (IOWA)

Nasir Bailey has had a relatively down year, but showed his talent in this match, securing Iowa’s first victory. Bailey took down Braeden Davis in the first period and stumped his offense for the final two frames.

After escaping in the second, Davis went on the offensive but Bailey continually avoided him, winning 3-2.

Penn State 6, Iowa 3

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs No. 17 Ryder Block (IOWA)

Ryder Block opened aggressively, and after keeping himself low to the mat, picked Shayne Van Ness’ leg to secure the first takedown. Van Ness quickly responded with a takedown of his own thirty seconds later.

Van Ness opened the second frame on top and rode out the entire period to hold the tie at 4-4, while accumulating over two minutes of riding time. Van Ness escaped in the third to secure the lead, but Block immediately picked his leg.

Van Ness picked his leg to counter and locked Block in a bow-and-arrow leading to a takedown and a four-point near-fall securing the 13-4 major decision.

Penn State 10, Iowa 3

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs No. 12 Jordan Williams (IOWA)

PJ Duke opened the match with vengeance, backing up Jordan Williams and nearly securing the takedown before his hold on Williams was deemed potentially dangerous. He continued shooting for the ankle after resetting, but couldn’t get Williams off his feet.

After Williams escaped five seconds into the second period, Duke again went on the offensive and had Williams on the verge of neutral danger. As the clock expired, no points were awarded but assistant coach Cody Sanderson threw the challenge brick on Duke’s behalf. The review upheld the call, and Duke entered the third trailing 1-0.

Duke stood up even faster than Williams did to go back to neutral, tied 1-1 in the third. After catching a shot from Williams, Duke circled around and landed the first takedown of the bout. Williams couldn’t break the collar-and-elbow tie up for the rest of the bout, giving Duke the 4-1 decision.

Penn State 13, Iowa 3

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs. No. 3 Michael Caliendo (IOWA)

Mitchell Mesenbrink and Michael Caliendo renewed their lopsided rivalry for the first time this season, and the seventh time in college. Mesenbrink has won all six prior matches.

Mesenbrink notched the first takedown, but only kept Caliendo down for fifteen seconds. Caliendo got a hold of Mesenbrink’s leg, but Mesenbrink escaped unscathed. Caliendo received a stall call but remained on his feet using a defensive posture for the remainder of the first period.

Caliendo started visibly frustrating Mesenbrink in Round 2, not giving up a takedown until there were nine seconds left on the clock. Mesenbrink quickly escaped to start the third. A tired Caliendo looked resigned as his offensive attacks slowed in the final minute.

After Mesenbrink started attacking again, Caliendo got a stall call and Mesenbrink went on a mad scramble to land one last takedown in the final seconds to extend the lead to 11-2 and earn a major decision.

Penn State 17, Iowa 3

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs. Gabe Arnold (IOWA)

Gabe Arnold filled in for All-American Patrick Kennedy, who has never beaten Levi Haines. It was Arnold’s first NCAA match against a Nittany Lion after he had words for the program last season, but didn’t end up wrestling in the dual at the Bryce Jordan Center.

Haines held control immediately in the match, securing a takedown two minutes in and keeping his hands locked around Arnold as he scrambled out of the circle. Arnold escaped after a clock malfunction delayed the whistle, catching Haines off guard with a quick jump. The rest of the first two periods were an uneventful stalemate.

Arnold stood up and brought the score to 4-2 with slightly over a minute remaining. The two were head-to-head for most of the last minute as Arnold searched for an opening. Three attacks by Arnold didn’t reach past Haines’ defensive stand and he secured another decision for the Nittany Lions.

Penn State 20, Iowa 3

184: No. 4 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs. No. 1 Angelo Ferrari (IOWA)

The most anticipated slate of the dual was the top-five matchup at 184 pounds. Redshirt freshman Angelo Ferrari hadn’t given up a takedown since becoming Iowa’s starter. His defensive stance of staying on a knee forced Welsh to be patient throughout the first period. Neither man launched a real attack in the first three minutes.

After Ferrari escaped after 25 seconds in Round 2, the match returned to a chronic stalemate. The wrestlers finally spent a prolonged amount of time locked up in the third round after Welsh drew the score even with an escape.

With 30 seconds remaining in round 3, Ferrari drew a stall warning and renegaded with Welsh, but the bout advanced to sudden victory, tied 1-1.

In the extra frame, Ferrari secured an under-hook and got a grip around Welsh for the closest attack of the match to that point. Welsh returned the favor, powering Ferrari down but was out of bounds as the clock passed one minute. The draw continued and sent the contest to tiebreakers.

Welsh deferred on the coin flip and rode Ferrari for 15 seconds before a stall call reset the mat, much to the dismay of the crowd in Carver-Hawkeye Arena. Welsh secured two more mat returns en route to a full 30 seconds of riding time.

Welsh debated his options for a minute before electing to take the bottom, just needing an escape to win. Welsh successfully broke Ferrari’s grip, leaving the top-ranked wrestler 17 seconds to take him down. Welsh backed off multiple Ferrari attempts and secured the upset to a chorus of boos.

Penn State 23, Iowa 3

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. Brody Sampson (IOWA)

Brody Sampson had his first match as Iowa’s permanent 197 starter against the top-ranked wrestler in the class Josh Barr. Sampson took the spot after No. 4 Massoma Endene was removed from Iowa’s roster earlier this week.

Barr welcomed Sampson with a takedown in the second minute. He led 6-1 following another takedown, and secured one more in the second period before locking Sampson in an assassin pin and securing the fall.

Penn State 29, Iowa 3

285: No. 13 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs. No. 5 Ben Kueter (Iowa)

The dual ended with the heavyweight bout between Cole Mirasola and Ben Kueter. Mirasola opened the rush against the larger Kueter, moving him backwards throughout the first minute.

Mirasola hooked Kueter’s leg with a minute left in the first, but Kueter wrapped his arms around Mirasola to eventually break the danger with a stalemate call.

Kueter escaped 21 seconds into Round 2 and received a stall call while Mirasola tired him out in a heavy tie up. Kueter picked the ankle but couldn’t control Mirasola, allowing him to unjam his foot and roll to his back for the takedown. Kueter escaped with three seconds on the clock and the bout entered the final frame, 3-2.

Mirasola escaped to extend the lead to 4-2, leaving Kueter about 90 seconds to attempt a takedown. Mirasola wouldn’t let Kueter get close, drawing a stall call, but retained the lead and secured the 4-3 decision.

Penn State 32, Iowa 3

Up Next

Penn State will hit the road to Evanston, Illinois, to face Northwestern at 3 p.m. Sunday.

title: No. 4 Penn State back into win column with victory over Syracuse
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
An upset loss in overtime to Mercyhurst lingered in the mind of No. 4 Penn State as it traveled north to New York for a series against Syracuse.

With focus shifted to the task at hand, the Nittany Lions looked to get back on a winning streak as the back half of the season quickly approached. In a tightly contested game, Penn State used its high-powered offense to beat the Orange 4-1.

It was Maddy Campbell who got the nod against a surging Orange offense, which is fresh off a five-goal weekend. The freshman made her fourth-straight start in the absence of Katie DeSa.

The Orange looked as though it tightened things up defensively through the first 10 minutes. With the last matchup between both teams ending in an 11–2 victory for Penn State, Syracuse made obvious adjustments to slow down the Nittany Lions' forecheck.

The adjusted defense couldn’t hold Penn State’s offense for the entire duration of the opening period as Grace Outwater forced a turnover on the boards in the offensive zone. The Picton, Ontario, native snapped a quick shot from the faceoff circle that beat Ava Drabyk’s glove.

With this goal, Outwater leads the AHA in goals with 14 on the season.

A full first 20 minutes seemingly controlled by Penn State came to a close as the Nittany Lions held the puck on the boards in the offensive zone.

It only took Mya Vaslet 20 seconds into the second period to open the scoring as she ripped a slapshot in close on Drabyk. With a look of shock on her face as she skated to the bench, this was the Stittsville, Ontario, native’s third goal on the season, after scoring only once last season.

Pressure continued to develop from the Nittany Lions as Tessa Janecke found herself alone with Drabyk as she skated in close, ultimately missing the net on the backhand.

Momentum from both teams quickly picked up in the first five minutes as the fast play led to a Nicole Hall cross-checking penalty as she crashed into the boards. However, the Penn State penalty kill unit stood tall.

After an unsuccessful power play, a quick two-on-one opportunity developed behind the Penn State defense as Rylee McLeod fed Heidi Knoll a smooth pass under the defenseman's stick that found the back of the net.

The opening first 10 minutes of the middle frame consisted of scoring chances seen on both sides of the ice, which seemed to slow down as time bled off the clock. Outwater nearly scored her second of the game as she was in close on Drabyk, ultimately having her wrist shot attempt shut down.

A much different second period concluded with Penn State having possession as time ran out, leaving the score at 2-1.

Syracuse had the first quality chance in the third period as Jordan Blouin had a chance backdoor to put one behind Campbell, ultimately denied by the left pad.

The freshman made 13 saves in her sixth career start.

The insurance goal for Penn State came off the stick of Kendall Butze as she sent a wrist shot from the top of the faceoff circle that found the back of the net.

A late power play paired with an empty net posed a challenge for Penn State as the game reached its three-minute mark.

Janecke didn’t take long to step up to the challenge as she sent the puck down from center ice, slowly reaching the vacant net.

Campbell spent the remaining two minutes of the game fending off any chance the Orange could generate, continuing to show promise in place of DeSa.

Penn State found itself back on track with a 4-1 score as the horn sounded.

Up Next

Both teams return to Tennity Ice Pavilion for Game 2 of the final series between the two sides with puck drop at 3 p.m.

Injury Report

Katie DeSa was not listed on the lineup for the fourth-straight game with an undisclosed injury. Matilde Fantin also wasn’t in the lineup as she is practicing with the Italian national team ahead of the upcoming Olympic Games.

title: Former Penn State basketball forward Puff Johnson to play for Ohio State this season
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A Big Ten foe has made a mid-season addition involving a former Penn State player.

Forward Puff Johnson, who has already played five years of collegiate basketball, has officially joined Ohio State and will play this season, the team announced Friday.

Buckeye Nation, welcome Puff Johnson to the program‼️Read more » https://t.co/4jKARKQngD pic.twitter.com/P4NW6FqC4b— Ohio State Hoops (@OhioStateHoops) January 16, 2026

Johnson, who's been enrolled at Ohio State since the fall, had his eligibility injunction motion denied in November. However, he was granted a temporary restraining order, which makes him eligible to play immediately.

The 2025-26 campaign will be Johnson's sixth collegiate season. He started his career at UNC from 2020 to 2023 before transferring to Penn State. He spent the 2023-24 and 2024-25 seasons with the Nittany Lions, averaging 8.4 points and 3.6 rebounds per game across both years.

Johnson appeared in 111 games total throughout his collegiate career. Playing for Ohio State this season will give him the opportunity to play in 15 more regular-season games, including matchups against Penn State on Jan. 26 and March 4.

title: Penn State signs Iowa State transfer LB John Klosterman
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State made another addition to the linebacker room.

The Nittany Lions have signed Iowa State transfer John Klosterman, the team announced Friday.

Klosterman appeared in 24 games throughout his Iowa State career that began in 2022. He was a reserve player, logging 18 tackles, a sack and a fumble recovery during his time as a Cyclone.

SIGNED: LB John KlostermanIowa City, IA → Happy Valley#WeAre | @Klosty22 pic.twitter.com/RYplsscGMA— Penn State Football (@PennStateFball) January 16, 2026

The Iowa City, Iowa, native first joined the Cyclones as a walk-on, and he redshirted during the 2022 season. He missed all but four games in 2024 due to injury and played in seven contests this past season, so he has one more year of eligibility.

Klosterman joins Caleb Bacon, Cael Brezina and Kooper Ebel as former Iowa State linebackers to follow Matt Campbell to Happy Valley.

title: Who is on Matt Campbell’s initial Penn State staff?
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
There’s been a lot of turnover for Penn State upon the transition of making Matt Campbell head coach.

Part of that turnover is building out his first coaching staff, as he’s brought in many new faces while retaining a handful of those from the Nittany Lions’ previous group.

Here’s who is currently on the Penn State staff.

Coordinators and position coaches

Associate head coach/cornerbacks coach: Coming off of his stint as interim head coach, Terry Smith will resume his previous positions of associate head coach and cornerbacks coach.

Offensive coordinator/tight ends coach: Taylor Mouser continues to follow Campbell, having been with him since 2015 at Toledo. His roles with the Rockets and Iowa State have ranged from graduate assistant, assistant director of scouting, senior quality control for offense, tight ends coach and offensive coordinator.

Defensive coordinator: D’Anton Lynn is the new defensive coordinator. The former Penn State cornerback joins the staff after two seasons in the same role at USC.

Special teams coordinator: Justin Lustig stays on staff for his third season as the special teams coordinator, coming off of a 2025 campaign where the unit made major strides. He also will be the nickelbacks and outside linebackers coach.

Quarterbacks coach: Jake Waters spent the last six seasons on the Iowa State staff, including the last two coaching quarterbacks.

Running backs coach: Savon Huggins heads to Happy Valley after four years of coaching tailbacks at Boston College.

Wide receivers coach: Noah Pauley joins the staff after three campaigns with the Cyclones in the same role.

Offensive line coach: Ryan Clanton comes to State College after three seasons as the head man in the trenches with the Cyclones.

Safeties coach/pass game coordinator: After five years coaching safeties in Ames, Iowa, Deon Broomfield joins the Penn State staff.

Linebackers coach: Tyson Veidt will coach the linebackers after two years as the defensive coordinator for Cincinnati. He was the linebackers coach under Campbell from 2014-23 at Iowa State and Toledo.

Defensive line coach/run game coordinator: Ikaika Malloe joins Penn State after two seasons as the UCLA defensive coordinator.

EDGE coach: Christian Smith will coach edge rushers after three years coaching the Northwestern defensive line. He played under Campbell at Toledo, and also spent a season as a graduate assistant there and another at Iowa State.

Analysts

Assistant special teams coordinator: Matthew Colangelo is back after joining the staff in 2025 as an analyst. He briefly departed for Virginia Tech.

Assistant quarterbacks coach: Former Penn State quarterback Trace McSorley is back for his second year in the role.

Assistant running backs coach: Sheldon Croney Jr. heads to Happy Valley following a year as the lead position coach at Central Michigan. He played and was a graduate assistant under Campbell at Iowa State.

Assistant offensive line coach: Jackson Scott-Brown will follow Campbell after working as a graduate assistant the last two seasons.

Assistant tight ends coach: Former Cyclone Sam Seonbuchner will follow Campbell in a different role, as he spent 2025 as quality control and run game coordinator.

Assistant linebackers coach: Dan Connor will return to an analyst role like he did in 2024, coming off of a season where the letterman was the lead position coach.

Assistant cornerbacks coach: Jordan Lucas returns to this role after stepping up to lead cornerbacks coach in light of Smith taking over as interim head coach.

Assistant defensive line coach: DeOn’Tae Pannell will be an assistant after being the lead defensive line coach at Austin Peay. He is a Penn State letterman.

Quality control for defense: Beau Fryler and Shawn Collins head to Penn State with ties to Campbell. Fryer was a former Cyclone, while Collins had the same role at Iowa State the last three years.

Quality control for offense: Ryan Gent is a former Cyclone, who held the same role in 2025.

Offensive analyst: Jake Landry follows Campbell after spending 2025 as an offensive analyst for the Cyclones. He also played for Iowa State.

Strength and conditioning

Director of football strength and conditioning: Reid Kagy will be the lead voice in the weight room. He spent six years at Iowa State, doing so in two different stints of three years, with his most recent being the past three seasons in the same role for the Cyclones.

Director of sports medicine: Jose Resendez holds the same role he did at Iowa State a year ago.

Director of speed and performance science: Ben Moortgat will have a new role under Campbell after spending 2025 at Iowa State as an assistant strength and conditioning coach.

Associate director of football strength and conditioning: Brandon Pietrzyk joins the staff after three seasons at Iowa State as an assistant strength and conditioning coach.

Director of sports performance: Aaron Hillmann heads to Penn State after nine seasons at Iowa State, with the last four being as the director of football performance operations.

Assistant strength and conditioning coach: Lucas White and Jalyn Baker head to Penn State after both spending three seasons in Ames.

Recruiting

General manager: Derek Hoodjer has been with Iowa State since 2011, having roles such as operations student assistant, graduate assistant, assistant director of recruiting and high school relations and director of player personnel. He spent the last three seasons as the associate athletic director for football personnel, the de-facto general manager.

Director of player personnel: Trent Slattenow was with the Cyclones the last four years, serving in the same role in 2025.

Director of college scouting: Xavier Quigley worked in Ames the last six years with the last two as assistant director of player personnel.

Director of football operations: Kelli Fogt has been with Iowa State for the last four seasons, serving most recently as the director of recruiting.

Recruiting coordinator for personnel: Alan Zemaitis stays in the recruiting department, as the letterman joined the staff in 2021.

Recruiting NIL operations: Justin Cummings-Morrow comes to Penn State after three years at Uconn, with the last two as executive director of football and recruiting.

Recruiting assistant: Jack Griffith joins the staff after three years at Cincinnati as the director of player personnel. Jace Heacock, the son of recently retired Iowa State defensive coordinator John Heacock, has been with Iowa State for seven total years in two different stints, with one being six years from 201622 and then he returned in 2025.

Recruiting coordinator: Naz Oliver and Gabby Mazzie both return for their second season at Penn State.

Administrative and support staff

Chief of staff: Skip Brabenec has been with Campbell the past 10 seasons at Iowa State.

Director of football player relations: Jayrone Elliot played under Campbell at Toledo and was on staff at Iowa State in 2025 as the program’s director of student-athlete development.

Director of player development: Letterman Jordan Hill returns for his second year in the role.

Administrative assistant to head coach: Brooke Anderson spent the last 10 years at Iowa State in the same role.

Assistant athletic director for football player development: Angie Hummel has been an administrative assistant for Penn State since 2014.

Video director: Jevin Stone has been on staff since 2009, where he started as a video assistant.

Assistant video director: Blake Yunker will return for his second year with the program.

title: Mark Wadsley named Penn State field hockey associate head coach
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State field hockey has found a new associate head coach in Mark Wadsley. Wadsley is the first addition to Hannah Prince’s staff in Happy Valley.

𝐒𝐞𝐜𝐨𝐧𝐝 𝐢𝐧 𝐂𝐨𝐦𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐝 🫡 pic.twitter.com/ISCgaNLcYB— Penn State Field Hockey (@PennStateFH) January 16, 2026

Wadsley held the same role at Saint Joseph’s the last three years under Prince. Prior to joining the college soccer ranks, Wadsley was head coach of Repton Hockey Club’s indoor and outdoor women’s soccer team.

Wadsley also has experience in college recruiting and international soccer training prior to becoming a coach.
