title: Abby O’Shea leads Lionettes to UDA Nationals despite funding cuts, leaves lasting legacy
author: Emma Lessick | The Daily Collegian
description:
Beyond kick splits, makeup and dance lies dedication, discipline and the true heart of a Penn State Lionette.

Abby O’Shea spent her senior year as a teammate, friend and captain of the 2025 Penn State Lionettes dance team.

For O’Shea, a fourth-year studying finance, her dream of dancing in Beaver Stadium began early.

“I started dancing when I was 3 years old,” she said. “Like every other girl, I took ballet classes.”

As a child, O’Shea also played soccer, but it wasn’t long before she swapped her cleats for ballet slippers. By the time she reached high school, her heart was set on becoming a Nittany Lion.

But her journey hasn’t been without sacrifice.

“Any sport or commitment you pour so much into can get really tiring,” O’Shea said. “It’s a lot of hours, and they definitely pay off, but especially during nationals season, it can be tough.”

Beyond their regular football season commitments, the Lionettes prepare for their biggest annual challenge, the Universal Dance Association National Championships (UDA Nationals). In 2024, the Lionettes placed third in the Division 1A pom category.

Each January, the team travels to Florida to compete against the nation’s top collegiate dance teams — a feat made more difficult this year after Penn State cut the Lionettes’ funding, leaving the team to raise tens of thousands of dollars themselves to fund their trip to UDA Nationals, which will kick off on Friday.

“My teammates and I were deeply disappointed and also a little frustrated by the situation," O’Shea said. "We don’t ask for much, so it was tough to learn that our dance ‘Super Bowl’ would have to be financed entirely through our own fundraising efforts."

After the Lionettes spoke out about the challenge they were facing, the team received more support than they anticipated.

“The Penn State community’s response has been overwhelming. I never expected to receive such an outpouring of love and support from students, community members, alumni and donors,” she said. “We had no idea how many silent supporters were cheering us on.”

As college dancers, the Lionettes team has only one major competition each year and two minutes on stage for each style of dance.

“That makes every moment, every sacrifice and every dollar matter,” O’Shea said.

For as long as O’Shea can remember, she’s dreamed of performing on the national stage. With the financial challenges the team has faced, she said this year’s competition has become even more special.

“We dedicate hundreds of hours of practice to our season so that we can step onto that stage with confidence and represent Penn State with heart and pride,” O’Shea said. “Being able to bring that passion to life on the UDA stage and share it with the world is our ultimate goal.”

O’Shea's teammates and coach see her not only as a dancer but as a leader. Nikki Romano, co-captain of the Lionettes, describes the team as “dedicated, passionate and hardworking,” and said O’Shea embodies those qualities.

Lionettes head coach Jackie Hovis also spoke highly of her leadership.

“Underclassmen look up to her when she teaches something, and she’s a great example. She really shines when it comes to details. I will turn to her and she always knows.” Hovis said, “All of these kids on the team right now will never forget her leadership.”

O’Shea's presence has left a mark; a Lionette legacy.

As O’Shea enters her last UDA Nationals competition, she recognizes just how incredibly fortunate and grateful she is to dance on the UDA Nationals stage one last time.

“We bring unmatched passion, work ethic and selflessness to representing this university, often without the recognition or resources that other athletic teams receive,” O’Shea said. “Witnessing the community come together in this way has been incredible, and I hope everyone knows just how grateful my teammates and I truly are.”

Her Lionette journey has been defined by resilience and community, leaving a blueprint for those who follow in her footsteps.

“‘Lionette will always be my favorite title, and one I am incredibly proud to hold,” O’Shea said.

MORE SPORTS COVERAGE

title: Penn State baseball sets opening week game times, broadcasts
author: Sam Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
The baseball season is almost here.

The Nittany Lions will be making a trip to Arizona to play in the Desert Invitational.

Opening 2026 in the Desert! Just four weeks away!🎟️ https://t.co/6Uq5zzs2gp#WeAre pic.twitter.com/hqe8nv286x— Penn State Baseball (@PennStateBASE) January 16, 2026

The team announced its game times and broadcast feeds. The invitational will begin at 8 p.m. on Friday, Feb. 13, when Penn State faces Air Force. That game will be featured on MLB.com.

At 3 p.m. on Saturday, Feb. 14, Penn State will play Grand Canyon on MLB Network. The blue and white will close the stint at 2 p.m. on Sunday, Feb. 15, on MLB.com.

The Nittany Lions went 29-24 last season and kicked off their season in Puerto Rico, where they went 2-1.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball hosts Rutgers as both seek their first Big Ten win, McMiller faces former team
author: Gianna Dowling | The Daily Collegian
description:
Following a 24-point loss to No.14 Ohio State on Wednesday night, Penn State women’s basketball has now lost its last seven games and is still in search of a Big Ten win. It’s been a tough stretch for the Lady Lions as they’ve faced four ranked opponents, along with one receiving votes, during this skid.

However, the blue and white’s next competitor looks a little different. Penn State welcomes Rutgers, which is also winless in conference play, to Rec Hall at 1 p.m. on Sunday.

Aside from the fact that someone will get their first Big Ten win of the season, there’s another story to look out for in Sunday's matinee. It’ll be Penn State’s star guard Kiyomi McMiller’s first game against her former team.

The Lady Lions allow more points per game than any other team in the Big Ten, at 82.4. Having said that, the Scarlet Knights have the conference’s lowest points per game average at 58.6. Penn State averages 75.9 points, about 13 more than Rutgers typically allows.

The blue and white’s leading scorer is 6-foot-6 center Gracie Merkle, who’s coming off back-to-back 20-plus point games. The Mount Washington, Kentucky native averages 19.2 points per game and owns a nation leading 75.5% field-goal percentage.

The Scarlet Knights’ go-to also comes from the front court through 6-foot-1 forward Nene Ndiaye. The junior Boston College transfer averages 14.7 points per game, but does a little bit of everything for Rutgers. Ndiaye also leads the team in steals, is second in three-point shooting and rebounding, and third in assists.

Given Ndiaye’s versatility, rather than Merkle, a better comparison to her on Penn State’s squad is the former Scarlet Knight McMiller.

The 5-foot-8 sophomore is the Lady Lions’ second leading scorer at 18.9 points per game. In the blue and white’s last outing against Ohio State, McMiller scored 20 points, while also tallying seven assists and four rebounds.

McMiller leads Penn State in assists and is second on the team in steals and rebounds, but the Silver Spring, Maryland, native also turned the ball over 82 times, which is the most in the Big Ten.

McMiller has to match veteran guards Faith Blackstone and Kaylah Ivey, who weren’t there for McMiller’s lone year at Rutgers.

Blackstone averages 10 points per game, but has only made 11 appearances for the Scarlet Knights this season. Ivey averages eight points per game, but has a much bigger presence on the floor.

Ivey transferred from Boston College with Ndiaye and has been Rutgers’ number one passer. The 5-foot-8 graduate student leads the Scarlet Knights with 61 assists and averages 8 points per game. Ivey also got things done on the defensive end with 23 steals on the season.

The Lady Lions’ scoring trio rounds out with 5-foot-8 guard Moriah Murray, who averages 10.6 points per game. The junior was Penn State’s leading scorer on Wednesday night with 25 points, and she shot 8-for-17 from three-point range.

In Sunday's matchup, the blue and white will have an opportunity to snap its seven-game skid, defend its home floor and finally break through in conference play. The Lady Lions have a chance to regain momentum and reset the trajectory of their season, but it won’t be easy because Rutgers has the same goal.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling’s Luke Lilledahl, Cole Mirasola discuss matchup against Iowa
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has its most anticipated matchup of the season on Friday, as the Nittany Lions will hit the road to face Iowa at Carver-Hawkeye Arena. This was the location that the squad last lost at back in 2020.

Penn State is trying to continue its historic win streak, but will have a few matches that are looked at as an uphill battle.

A pair of wrestlers met with the media on Wednesday and offered insight ahead of the dual.

Luke Lilledahl

At 125 pounds, Luke Lilledahl will face Dean Peterson. Last season, Lilledahl lost to Peterson, 4-1, when Peterson was at Rutgers before transferring to Iowa.

“I would say there’s definitely a couple things that I learned just feeling guys out and wrestling, but most of the time it's a clean slate every match,” Lilledahl said. “Every match starts 0-0, so just another opportunity.”

Lilledahl has the opportunity to defeat an opponent that he’s never had his arm raised against. The sophomore discussed his new mindset going into the match.

“I feel like last season was kind of more about showing people my potential just because people had a lot of high expectations for me,” Lilledahl said. “This year I feel like it’s more like just going out there and dominating these days and kind of putting myself at the top of the weight class.”

Lilledahl has a solid start with a record of 9-0 so far this season.

Cole Mirasola

Another match to watch for Penn State is at heavyweight. Cole Mirasola will take on Ben Kueter, who like Mirasola, is also considered a smaller heavyweight. Going into this match Mirasola is on a win streak and will try to upset a top-five wrestler.

“I’m just trying to get better every match and get ready for Big Tens and nationals,” Mirasola said.

Mirasola went 1-2 in Big Ten duals last season with losses coming to Nick Feldman of Ohio State and Luke Luffman of Illinois. The redshirt freshman is another wrestler that seems to have a different mindset than last season.

“I feel like in the past I haven’t really been like super mean when I wrestle, just kind of tactical and slick, but just talking to coach Cael (Sanderson) you always have to be clean,” Mirasola said. “You can win dirty, like not being dirty, like winning off a go behind or pulling guys down and stuff, focusing on being neat.”

Being a smaller heavyweight, Mirasola has to use other skills to take advantage of his opponent. This includes quickness and being technical about when they’re going for the takedown.

“I don’t think anyone can really wrestle me for the whole seven minutes. So, if I use my conditioning as a factor, I think that’ll help for sure,” Mirasola said.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: ‘A great message for a great time’ | FOBA holds 51st annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Memorial Banquet
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
The Bryce Jordan Center (BJC) was awash with purple light on Thursday evening as members of the Penn State and State College communities came together to attend the 51st annual Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. memorial banquet.

The banquet, which was hosted by the Forum On Black Affairs (FOBA), is one of several January events meant to commemorate Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and his legacy.

Stephanie Preston, MLK banquet chair and former FOBA president, said she has had a long history of both attending, and later organizing, the banquet.

She said the event’s theme of “undaunted hope” was chosen by the MLK Commemoration Student Committee, which FOBA then adopted.

Preston said the biggest challenge the banquet faced has been finding a large enough space to hold the event. Previously, former FOBA President Carlos Wiley moved the banquet from the Penn Stater to the BJC.

The banquet began at 6:10 p.m. with a call to order from Preston followed by speeches from Executive Vice President and Provost Fotis Sotiropoulos, Paul Robeson Cultural Center Director Evan Williams and Dean of J. Jeffrey and Ann Marie Fox Graduate School and Vice Provost for Graduate Education Levon Esters.

A blessing was given by Gary Abdullah, the assistant dean for diversity and inclusion for the Donald P. Bellisario College of Communications, followed by performances from the Essence of Joy choral ensemble and spoken word artivist Sir Dominique Jordan.

Williams, a member of FOBA, said he was pleased to see the banquet occur once again. He said he hoped attendees of the banquet left with a sense of need to come together to settle differences amongst themselves.

“Sometimes we have to crawl before we can walk and we're going to have our differences but oftentimes we have to understand the similarities and allow that to be at the forefront,” Williams said. “We may not agree on certain things, but we can agree to disagree respectfully and I think, in this current climate that we are in, this program and the messages that will be spoken tonight will be able to have a billowing effect of positivity and help make a paradigm shift in the right path that we need to go as a community.”

Kenyatta Shelton-Burleigh, the assistant director for the admissions strategic partnerships office in undergraduate admissions, said the banquet has been a staple of her time at Penn State and she always makes an effort to attend.

“We still, as Americans, have a job to do to keep the fight going for equality, and being here at Penn State, what I love is that in the light of everything that's going on in today's world, Penn State is still standing strong on being equitable,” Shelton-Burleigh said.

Preston and Williams announced Jamie Campbell as the recipient of the Humanitarian Service Award and Gyasi Franklin, a second-year studying film production, and Deja Workman, a PhD student studying informatics, the recipients of Fannie Lou Hamer – W.E.B. DuBois Service Scholarships.

The banquet concluded at 8:15 p.m. following a final performance by the United Christian Campus Ministry Choir and closing remarks from Preston.

Gopal Balachandran, a member of the State College Borough Council, said it was “fantastic” that the speakers and performers selected for the banquet were able to contribute to the event’s theme.

“The fact of the matter is that all of the speakers and all of the stories building around this theme, particularly in a part where many of the speakers acknowledge how hard it's been in the past year,” Balachandran said. “To be able to give a message that is consistent with Dr. Martin Luther King but is both uplifting and full of hope, but doesn't lose sight of the fact of how much work and how much fighting still needs to be done, so I thought it was a great message for a great time.”

He said he hoped the banquet would leave attendees hopeful for solutions to overcome current issues in American society and around the world.

“We're living in a difficult time,” Balachandran said. “There are a great deal of challenges and stresses all around and what is really hopeful to me is that these are struggles that have occurred many times in our shared history and that there's still a way and a path forward and that we can still do that with our heads raised high and open our hearts.”

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: Small resets that don’t require a new routine or personality
author: Lexi Cannan | The Daily Collegian
description:
There’s something about the new year that makes it feel like everyone suddenly needs to get their life together.

All at once, it’s new routines, new goals and trying to become the “best version” of yourself — even though most people are still just getting back into the semester and double-checking where their classes are.

A glow-up doesn’t have to be extreme. You don’t need a crazy early alarm or some perfect system to change your life. Usually, it’s just small things that make everyday college life feel easier.

Start small with your routine

One of the easiest places to start is your routine. You don’t have to overhaul your entire schedule — just start small. Trying to change everything at once usually doesn’t stick, especially once classes get busy.

Going to bed earlier, eating something before your first class or finally using an alarm you won’t snooze ten times can make your day feel way less chaotic. Even one of those changes helps you feel a little more on top of things.

Clean up your space (even a little)

When your room is a mess, everything feels harder — papers on your desk, cups you forgot about, clothes on the floor that have been there way too long — it adds up fast.

You don’t need to clean your whole room. Clean off your desk, your backpack or even your phone if you’re feeling productive. It doesn’t fix everything, but it helps your space feel less chaotic.

Movement that actually feels doable

Being active doesn’t have to be a big thing. You don’t need hard workouts or gym motivation. Some days it’s just walking to class, stretching a little or pacing around your room.

Going with a friend helps too. Trying classes together or just meeting up makes it feel more like hanging out than working out.

You can complain the whole time, laugh about not knowing what you’re doing and leave early if you want. It just feels like a break from sitting around all day, which is kind of the point.

Rethink the way you choose your daily outfits

Let’s be honest — most of us wear the same few outfits every week. A glow-up doesn’t mean changing that, it just means liking those outfits.

A good hoodie, jeans that don’t feel awful and sneakers that go with everything can make even low-effort days feel better.

When you actually feel comfortable in what you’re wearing, you’re not constantly thinking about it throughout the day. You can actually focus on class, run errands or just get through a long day on campus.

It’s not about looking dressed up — it’s about feeling like yourself, even on days when you’re putting in the bare minimum.

Take your mental health seriously

The beginning of second semester is rough. It gets dark early, everyone’s tired and it feels like there’s always something you should be doing.

Taking care of your mental health sometimes just means stopping for a second. Skipping plans, logging off or even sitting in your room doing nothing without turning it into a whole guilt spiral. You don’t have to push through everything.

It’s okay to slow down when things feel overwhelming. A glow-up isn’t just about looks — it’s taking care of yourself when you need to. Instead of big goals, think about how you want to feel this year. Less stressed, more balanced or just better overall.

Focus on how you want to feel

Instead of putting pressure on yourself with big resolutions, it helps to think about how you want to feel this year. Maybe that’s more balanced, less stressed or more confident.

Let whatever habits you pick support that instead of making your life harder. You don’t need to do everything “right” or have it all figured out — just do what actually works for you and your schedule.

MORE BLOGS

title: Satire | Penn State students ‘Betrayal List’
author: Amelia Houck | The Daily Collegian
description:
As Penn State students, we’ve experienced our fair share of cultural, social and campus phenomena.

The idea of individuals creating their own ‘Betrayal List,’ — inspired from a viral tweet by Kanye West in 2025 — is now used as a way to describe people, situations or events that have scorned you in a way or you view as disloyalty.

With Penn Staters experiencing their own trials and tribulations, here is our ‘Betrayal List.’

James Franklin

Enough said.

Cancelled classes until 9 a.m or 10 a.m.

Is this a joke?

There’s absolutely nothing worse than waking up on a bitterly cold winter morning to an alert on your phone which says all classes and activities are cancelled up until 9 a.m. or 10 a.m due to snowfall, just in time for your 9:05 a.m. or 10:10 a.m. class.

Good luck on that walk to campus, because the downtown paths definitely aren’t salted.

Penn State Football

Were you a victim of believing the AP Top 25 College Football Poll last summer? Me too.

I really thought last season would’ have been the one where we secured a BIG 10 Championship. (But hey, at least Ohio State lost).

Sitting in class during a beautiful day

I am sure we’re all aware of just how little sunshine State College gets this time of year.

There is absolutely nothing comparable to seeing the first sunny day in the spring after a long, cold, brutal winter and having mandatory classes to attend — keeping you inside all day.

Getting Pollock freshman year

Name a worse experience than finding out you’ve been placed in Pollock for the year — you can’t. While the year there can turn into a great time, going into the space with little information other than the horror stories is certainly a fright.

Yes, the location is better than East Halls, but there’s no other positives to be found amongst the bats and cockroaches.

Having class the Monday after THON weekend

If only professors could express some sympathy for the fact that the majority of students have not slept for hours, whilst supporting an incredible cause of fundraising, and standing for 46 hours consecutively.

The Monday after THON Weekend should be an official Penn State holiday.

Running out of meal plan freshman year

With no kitchen, no way of getting to the grocery store, low funds and places to get food — except downtown Target, which is always practically ransacked — you essentially have no other option but to try and tough it out or to reload money into your meal plan account.

The Philadelphia Eagles

Growing up, we endured the Eagles at their worst; however, now a loss hurts so much more when your team is objectively considered “good.”

There was a time fans would have been excited if we won any game period.

The reigning Super Bowl champions losing in the wild-card round this season is a major letdown to say the least.

Unfortunately, the defense can only do so much with a lack of effective offensive plays and playcalling.

“The Freshman 15”

Before even beginning college, I am sure everyone was warned about the dreaded 15-pound weight gain following the start of a collegiate lifestyle.

With an increase in academic stressors raising your cortisol levels, unhealthy dining hall foods instead of healthier home-cooked meals, binge drinking and the lack of a consistent sleep and exercise schedule are huge contributors to this cultural phenomenon.

Adjusting to a completely new place you are now calling home and feeling uncomfortable in your own skin are not pleasant experiences, but unfortunately they tend to go hand in hand.

Graduation looming

The real world sucks. Actually, I wouldn’t know I’m still in college.

Basically, a dark cloud looms over your head the second you become an upperclassman. Once senior year begins, everything once fun and carefree starts to become bittersweet.

MORE BLOGS

title: Penn State men’s basketball looks to  snap four-game losing streak in road test against Maryland
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
Now in the midst of a four-game losing streak, Penn State fell to 9-8 on the year and 0-6 in the Big Ten.

The Nittany Lions are one game ahead of Northwestern and two games ahead of Maryland, both of which are also winless in conference play. All three sit tied for last in the conference.

Oregon’s 1-5 Big Ten record is the only thing keeping it above the blue and white in the standings, as the Ducks sit at 8-9 overall.

Penn State heads about 200 miles south on Sunday to take on the Terrapins at the XFINITY Center. Tipoff is scheduled for noon.

Something’s gotta give come Sunday as Maryland’s also dropped its last four-in-a-row. The Terrapins suffered quality losses against Virginia, Michigan, Alabama and Gonzaga. Three of four of those losses were blowouts, however.

Maryland’s leading scorer, Pharrel Payne, hasn’t played since the Terrapins’ Dec. 13 game against Michigan. He enters as questionable with a leg injury. Payne averaged 17.5 points and 7.2 rebounds per game when available.

The injury bug is going around, though, as Penn State also arrives in College Park without some of its key players.

Nittany Lion standout freshman Kayden Mingo sustained a broken nose in practice and will “be out for a while,” and Tibor Mirtič also enters questionable, with a knee injury that he’s “just rehabbing,” as both described by Mike Rhoades.

In Penn State’s most recent loss to UCLA, Freddie Dilione V sustained an ankle injury and is questionable against Maryland, though he’ll most likely be sidelined, as Rhoades detailed it was a sprain.

With Payne’s injury, Maryland’s points leader is David “Diggy” Coit, who averages 13.8 points per game. The 5-foot-11 guard enters fresh off a 30 point performance in the Terrapins’ recent loss to USC.

That was his third 30-plus point performance of the season. He dropped 41 against Mount St. Mary back in November.

Despite Mingo’s injury sidelining him for the last three games, he still leads Penn State in scoring, behind his 14.9 points per game average as a freshman. With Dilione V likely being out against Maryland, the blue and white’s leading scorer against the Terrapins will be Melih Tunca.

Tunca averages 10.1 points per game and only recorded five points in the loss to UCLA.

Dominick Stewart led the way against the Bruins, dropping 16 points – the most of any Nittany Lion. He likely sees a tremendous amount of playing time against Maryland as one of just three healthy guards.

Penn State averages 78.1 points per game as a team, while the Terrapins average 73.2, though the Nittany Lions' defense surrenders 75.4 points per game.

The blue and white is 4-8 in games when it allows opponents to score 70-plus points. Maryland has been stopped short of 70-plus points in just six games this season.

Prior to the 2025-26 season, the Big Ten announced that all 18 teams would make the conference tournament after the regular season, up from 15. Despite that, this still feels like a must-win game for both teams, as each is desperate for its first conference win.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Column | Welcome to the final show
author: Julia Frederick | The Daily Collegian
description:
To my fellow spring 2026 graduates, welcome to your last semester of undergrad.

If you’re anything like me, the thought of graduation has always seemed like this far-off, almost make-believe thing. It’ll happen eventually, but not for a while.

Well, a few years have sprinted by and now you’re getting emails from your academic advisor to apply for graduation on LionPATH, pressure from your mom to order your cap and gown and crossing your fingers that your family found a place to stay come May.

Additionally, Spring 2026 holds a lot of lasts. Last first day of class. Last night out at the bar with your friends. Last moment before you enter the big, scary “real world.”

The finish line is approaching rapidly. Are you ready?

If you aren’t, you’re certainly not alone. Big transitions like this carry a lot of emotion. You might feel excited, scared, uncertain or all of the above.

However you’re feeling, allow me to share some advice that I’ve found to be helpful.

Tip 1: This is not the first big change you’ve faced

“Anticipatory anxiety” is something that can surface as graduation approaches, according to the American Psychological Association (APA).

It’s exactly what it sounds like. It’s “worry about the future” and “the fear that bad things might happen or that you might become unable to successfully accomplish what you set out to do,” as the Anxiety and Depression Association of America defines it.

The APA points to looking at one’s history to alleviate these feelings.

Thus, I encourage you to think back to graduating high school all those years ago. Remember the feeling of being freshly 18 with the world at your fingertips and the uncertainty of what was in store for you.

Remember the drive to University Park and the teary family goodbyes. Remember your first-year dorm, roommate and classes. Remember your first lecture hall in the Forum or Thomas, thinking to yourself, “How can there be so many people here?”

It all felt so overwhelming at the time, didn’t it?

Look at you now. You came out the other side. You not only did the hard thing, but you thrived while doing so.

It all worked out then; there’s no reason to doubt that it will now, too.

Tip 2: You’re not the first and you won’t be the last

Penn State has over 800,000 alumni. That means that over 800,000 people have gone through the exact same thing. All of this goes to say that you aren’t alone.

While of course, graduation may be bittersweet, you’ll join something bigger than yourself and the current campus population. Penn State has one of the largest alumni networks in the U.S.; you’re in good company.

While your time as a student at Penn State may be over, that doesn’t mean you’ll never come back. Happy Valley has a way of welcoming past-students back home.

You took great care of Penn State while you were here, it’s time to pass it on to the next incoming class.

Tip 3: Make the most of it

To bring in one of my 2026 New Year’s resolutions, say yes to as much as you can (within reason, of course).

Do that bar crawl, see that movie, stay out late. Do everything you wanted to do when you came here, plus a few extra things.

Graduate with no regrets … OK, maybe a few (WITHIN REASON).

Leave with college years well-lived, whatever that means to you. Be proud of where you came from, but keep moving forward. Penn State will always cheer you on.

You’re off to your next big adventure. Congratulations on what you’ve accomplished.

MORE COLUMNS

title: Penn State men's volleyball sweeps St. Thomas Aquinas, remains undefeated on season
author: Keira Albert | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State kept its winning streak alive with its third straight win of the 2026 season on Thursday. It swept St. Thomas Aquinas 3-0, taking home another victory from Rec Hall.

The first set started with back-and-forth scoring from both sides. For every point scored by the Nittany Lions, the Spartans responded immediately, keeping the first few points close.

After keeping the set neck-and-neck, the blue and white finally pulled away with a block from Sean Harvey, making the score 11-8.

But St. Thomas Aquinas was able to get it close again after a few blocks and quick points, diminishing the blue and white’s lead to 11-10.

After a big kill from Penn State’s Gaige Gabriel, the blue and white started to pull ahead, making its lead 13-10. The 6-foot-8 sophomore then went on to deliver an ace, increasing the blue and white’s lead to 14-10.

A kill from Penn State’s Owen Rose tallied its third point in a row, forcing the Spartans to take their first timeout of the match. Following the break, the Spartans were able to score three quick points and tighten the game back up.

After a play being challenged by the blue and white, however, it continued to pull away, setting the score at 18-13.

After some brief back-and-forth, a service error from the Spartans made the score 25-19, giving Penn State a win in the first set.

Going into the second set, the pattern seemed to continue, with the first few points being back-and-forth on both sides of the court.

However, after two big kills, one from Gabriel and another from Matthew Luoma, the blue and white pulled ahead, making the score 8-5.

However, after a few errors on the Penn State side, the Spartans were able to close the lead to 11-10. And just like that, it was back-and-forth scoring, with the score staying within two points for the next few points.

After a kill from Harvey, the Nittany Lions took the lead by three points, making the score 19-16. But the Spartans were quick to respond and close that gap. But it was Harvey again who got another big kill and put the blue and white back up.

Rose’s sixth kill of the game put the Nittany Lions up 22-18. From there, the rest was history. A kill from Luoma got Penn State the win in the second set, 25-20.

The third set started with two quick points from St. Thomas Aquinas.

Penn State was quick to respond, however, and went on a five-point streak. After a kill from Gabriel, back-to-back aces from Harvey, a Spartans’ block error and a kill from Harvey, it took the lead 5-2.

After some back-and-forth, redshirt freshman Jaidyn Bethel logged his second kill of the match to make the score 10-6. From there, the blue and white seemed to run away with it a bit, as Gabriel logged his ninth kill, making the score 13-7.

After another Harvey kill, his ninth of the night, Penn State increased its lead to 16-7, leading by more than double.

Penn State took the remainder of the set with ease. Freshman Tristan Hassell logged his first kill of the match to make the score 22-12.

While they managed to score a few more points in the set, the lead was too great for the Spartans to close. The blue and white won its third straight set after a service error from the opposite side of the court.

Up Next

The Nittany Lions will continue their homestand as they face Lewis at 7 p.m. Saturday in Rec Hall.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Former Penn State women's soccer goalkeeper earns pro invite
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Another Penn State women’s soccer player has earned a camp invite from the National Women’s Soccer League. This time, its goalkeeper Amanda Poorbaugh gaining the chance to make Racing Louisville FC during their preseason camp.

Nothing’s getting past AP🧤Shoutout to the AMAZING Amanda Poorbaugh on earning a preseason camp invite with Racing Louisville FC⚜️#WeAre | #PSWS pic.twitter.com/cE7Bd8uUQq— Penn State Women’s Soccer (@PennStateWSOC) January 15, 2026

The Westerville, Ohio, native is coming off of her redshirt senior year after playing for Penn State since 2021.

Poorbaugh saved all six shots she faced in 64 games of action this season. Her most substantial season came in 2024-25, when she went 8-3-1 with six shutouts, posting a 0.639 goals-against average while saving 36 of 44 shots faced.

MORE SOCCER COVERAGE

title: Former Penn State WR Tyseer Denmark transfers to Virginia Tech
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A young wide receiver is following James Franklin.

Tyseer Denmark is transferring to Virginia Tech, he announced on his X on Thursday night.

Lets do it @HokiesFB pic.twitter.com/ZndPPxr0M2— tyseer5denmark (@tyseer5denmark) January 15, 2026

Denmark entered the transfer portal shortly after initially announcing he would stay at Penn State. Ultimately, he lands with his former coach, who flipped him from Oregon to the Nittany Lions.

The redshirt freshman finishes his time in State College with four career catches for 45 yards and a touchdown.

Denmark had a substantial amount of praise throughout his two seasons with Penn State, but ultimately never carved out a role on offense.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State lands commitment from Henry Lustig as a preferred walk-on
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Penn State has added another to its 2026 class, this time one with ties to the staff.

The Nittany Lions landed a commitment from wide receiver/cornerback Henry Lustig as a preferred walk-on, he announced on Thursday evening via X.

COMMITTED🦁!#WeAre pic.twitter.com/iI4jjCnTyY— Hank Lustig (@henry_lustig) January 15, 2026

Lustig is the son of special teams coordinator Justin Lustig and plays for State College Area High School. He recently landed an offer from the new staff.

He’s coming off of a senior season where he tallied 41 receptions for 642 yards and 10 touchdowns on the offensive side of the ball. Defensively, he recorded 39 total tackles, eight pass break ups and a pair of interceptions.

He is 5-foot-9,155 pounds, and was first-team 6A-All-State as a kick returner and was a second-team selection as a slot receiver.

Lustig caught passes at the Elite 11 camp in State College this summer, where early enrollee quarterback Peyton Falzone was participating. He was also a team captain for Little Lions.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 8 Penn State men’s hockey hosts Notre Dame to round out homestand
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Last January, Penn State put an end to its nine-game conference winless streak after a 3-0 shutout over Notre Dame. The win acted as a catalyst for the Nittany Lions’ red-hot second-half, going 13-3 to round out the regular season.

This January, the Fighting Irish are back for their first series of the season with the blue and white, set for a 7 p.m. puck drop on Friday and 8 p.m. puck drop on Saturday, both at Pegula Ice Arena.

Notre Dame’s struggles

Notre Dame has had a tough year and is currently in the midst of a seven-game losing streak. With an overall record of 4-15-1, the Fighting Irish are winless in conference play and sit at the bottom of the Big Ten standings.

Notre Dame’s averages of 2.55 goals per game and 4.25 goals allowed both rank last in the Big Ten; however, its special teams have performed well, with a conference-third-best power-play percentage and a second-best penalty kill percentage.

The Fighting Irish are led by defenseman Paul Fischer, who has five goals and 11 assists on the season, but the junior will miss out on this weekend’s action after being assessed a suspension for a checking penalty in last weekend’s contest.

Both Penn State and Notre Dame sit at No. 2 and No. 3, respectively, in the NCAA in penalty minutes per game, setting up a likely physical series.

In net for the Fighting Irish is sophomore Nicholas Kempf, who recently wrapped up a World Junior Championship campaign with Team USA. The Washington Capitals prospect has an .887 save percentage on the season, while allowing 65 goals.

Penn State injuries loom

While the addition of both Aiden Fink and Cade Christenson back into the Penn State lineup after the holiday break has been an added boost, the home team sustained multiple injuries after last weekend’s sweep of Minnesota, which could impact the upcoming series.

Shortly after recording his first goal of the season in the Nittany Lions’ 5-2 win over Minnesota on Saturday, sophomore Braedon Ford collided awkwardly with the boards and left the ice in visible pain.

Coach Guy Gadowsky announced the forward would be “out for a significant amount of time with a lower-body injury.”

A big question mark for this weekend is the status of the blue and white’s point leader, Charlie Cerrato, after he exited Friday’s contest early and was scratched the following night.

Gadowsky announced Cerrato, along with Casey Aman and Shea Van Olm, are all “day-to-day,” leaving open the possibility of the three returning to the lineup, although the likelihood is unclear.

Goaltending tandem

The blue and white have stuck with its rotational strategy of alternating goaltenders Josh Fleming and Kevin Reidler. The strategy has largely worked out, with both having solid seasons, keeping the option open for either of them to compete on a given night.

Fleming holds the slight edge over Reidler, although with two fewer appearances, tallying a 93.8 save percentage to Reidler’s 91.1.

Fleming is impressing in the midst of his freshman season, recently being named to the Mike Richter Award watch list, an award given annually to the top goaltender in NCAA men’s Division I hockey. His save percentage is tied for first nationally, and his 1.91 goals against average is tied for seventh.

Reidler is also in his first season with the Nittany Lions, transferring in after spending his first season with Nebraska Omaha, and has helped the team to 11 wins so far through the season.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State baseball’s Michael Anderson named to Perfect Game’s Top 100 Seniors
author: Samuel Simonic | The Daily Collegian
description:
The baseball season hasn’t begun, but it’s off to a good start.

On Thursday afternoon, Perfect Game announced that infielder Matt Anderson ranked No. 12 among the Top 100 collegiate seniors.

Coming in at No. 1️⃣2️⃣ on @PerfectGameUSA’s Top 100 college seniors rankings!@Michael_A110 #WeAre pic.twitter.com/fyKspjHJBM— Penn State Baseball (@PennStateBASE) January 15, 2026

Anderson, a native of Haverford, Pennsylvania, made numerous stops before settling in Happy Valley. Out of Monsignor Bonner High School in Philadelphia, Anderson committed to Rhode Island before transferring to Arkansas.

The 6-foot-3 first baseman played a total of 103 games, making 99 starts across that timeline. Last season, he led Arkansas to a College World Series appearance.

Throughout his collegiate career, Anderson has batted .282, with a .551 slugging percentage and a .397 on-base percentage.

MORE BASEBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women's lacrosse announces 2 televised matchups
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Coach Kayla Treanor's first season with Penn State is going live.

The Nittany Lions announced two of their matchups would air on Big Ten Network this season.

The first televised matchup for Penn State is its home game against Oregon at 8 p.m. on April 9.

The second matchup is a week later, when the Nittany Lions host Johns Hopkins at 6 p.m. on April 16.

Treanor will enter her first year leading Penn State after leading Syracuse to four straight NCAA tournament appearances.

MORE LACROSSE COVERAGE

title: Savory and sweet | A review of Honeygrow
author: Veronica Figg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A new spot for stir-frys, salads and honey-based desserts recently opened it’s doors in State College. The Philadelphia-based restaurant chain Honeygrow is now located at 160 E Beaver Ave from 10:30 a.m. to 10:00 p.m.

This week, I decided to go and try some of the new spot’s options, and to find a dish that might “wok” your world.

Stir-Fry

I chose to order Honeygrow’s seasonal Miso Garlic stir-fry noodles. The dish includes egg white noodles, roasted chicken, miso corn, caramelized onions, shaved parmesan, chives and Umami miso sauce. I chose to remove the shaved parmesan.

The dish was very good and had a great Umami profile. The noodles were cooked perfectly — not too soft or soggy from the sauce.

The chicken was juicy and was not dry at all. The Umami profile came into play when the sauce mixed with the individual flavors of the chicken, corn and onions, making them a powerful combination.

The caramelized onions were tangy and crunchy, giving a needed sharpness to the sweet corn. The noodles, corn and onions together created a rich, tangy and sweet balance that — when mixed with the chicken — created the Umami flavor the dish strives for, tasting savory and comforting.

The chives were sprinkled on top and I mixed them in to add to the flavor profile. Unfortunately, the taste of the chives was overpowered by the garlic in the sauce.

I would have liked to have tasted the chives more clearly so they could have added some more tang to the dish.

Rating: 8/10

Dessert

I ordered a create-your-own Honeybar for dessert, and chose clover honey, apples, grapes, blueberries, strawberries and granola as my toppings.

This dessert was delicious. I ate the whole thing and would really recommend it.

Clover honey is sweet and was the highlight of the dessert. It made the multiple flavors of the fruits really pop.

The granola was crunchy and a great juxtaposition for the sweetness of the strawberries and tanginess of the blueberries, making for a great flavor combination.

The grapes were a great addition to the dessert that added a unique flavor which complimented the other fruits.

The apples were crunchy and sweet, and — when paired with the grapes — went great with the honey. All of the fruits tasted fresh and no part of the dessert was dry.

Rating: 10/10

Veronica’s Food Sensitivity Corner

As a student who was recently diagnosed with a dairy sensitivity, I am always on the lookout for foods that fit my new dietary needs and am aware there are other students who may have similar needs as well.

Honeygrow does offer vegan dishes like the Red Coconut Curry Stir-Fry, or Gluten-free items on their menu including the Loaded Greek Salad and OG Cobb Salad.

At Honeygrow, all dishes on the menu can be modified to remove ingredients, and you can also create your own stir-fry, salad or honeybar and customize it.

As with any food establishment, please inform a service worker if you have any food allergies.

Overall, I would recommend Honeygrow to anyone who misses a home-cooked meal of the noodle variety, and for any student that needs a sweet treat after a long day of classes.

MORE LIFESTYLE COVERAGE

title: 5 Songs to Get You Through the Winter Blues
author: Brennan Kramp I The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s a random Wednesday during the frigid January winter in Happy Valley. You step out of your class building and get hit with a gust of wind to the face followed by a trek through the flurry of snow to the library under an endlessly grey sky.

The sun becomes a celebrity — making rare and treasured appearances. In times like these, it’s best to put on some headphones, crank up some music and escape the seasonal depression for a few brief minutes.

Here are some tunes to play to get you through the day and put a little more pep in your step as you hunker through the winter.

“Like A Rolling Stone” by Bob Dylan

Arguably Dylan’s biggest hit of his career, “Like A Rolling Stone” is a bitter sweet story about a once-rich woman who loses everything and finds herself — as Dylan would put it — rolling through life like a stone.

Sure, a bummer topic for a song, but the production, ensemble and groovy tempo of it make you want to shake into a dance no matter where you’re walking. A fitting song for a gloomy mood as the juxtaposition of the lyrics and the production of the track make for a comedically ironic vibe that is sure to boost your spirits.

“Drive” by Incubus

Incubus’ “Drive” is a much slower tune, but the true uplifting power comes from the lyrics. A fabulous song about regaining control of your life and finding the empowerment behind that act.

Lead singer Brandon Boyd lays a blanket of warmth over your soul as he belts out the lyrics to the chorus, “whatever tomorrow brings, I’ll be there, with open arms and open eyes.” Best played on the bus or car ride home after a long day, “Drive” will give you a comforting sense of security in yourself to keep pushing through the dreary days of winter.

“Let’s Go Crazy” by Prince

Switching tracks and putting you in a free and easy mood is the iconic opener to Prince’s “Purple Rain” album, “Let’s Go Crazy.” This killer track opens with a monologue from the eccentric lead singer, talking about “the afterworld, a world of never-ending happiness.” In this world, “you can always see the sun, day or night.”

The true message of this song is simply, if the world is bringing you down, just let loose and find a way to have a good time — ignore everything else and just be alive. The snow and the wind won’t stand a chance to bring you down with this tune bumping between your ears.

“Sweater Weather” by The Neighbourhood

An early 2010’s hit where the music alone immediately throws you back to the wonderful winter days of elementary school, while keeping you in the present to take a moment to appreciate how many winters have passed and how you’ve survived all of them.

A truly creative and embracing song on all levels that carries the vibe of a gloomy winter night to help you embrace — yes — the sweater weather. Layered on top of that is a lyrical composition that will also take your mind away from whatever it is that has you down that day, as you hear a tale of two lovers cherishing each other during a similarly rough patch.

“I Gotta Feeling” by The Black Eyed Peas

Rounding out this list is a pure nostalgia hit for anyone working through their years at State College. “I Gotta Feeling” is sure to remind you of the upcoming good vibes of spring and summer that lay ahead.

This 2000’s radio banger exudes positivity, enthusiasm and eager excitment, with the trio preaching, “tonight’s gonna be a good night,” and just like with Incubus’ “Drive,” you truly feel that sense of confidence in the thought tonight will in fact be a good night, no matter the blizzards of assignments you have to go through.

Lyrics aside, the production on this track just puts you in a party mood — wanting to bust out dancing and grooving along to the fun and energetic tune. A choice pick for the mid-day grind that will hit you like a double shot of espresso between the ears.

MORE BLOGS

title: Penn State women’s gymnastics heads to Champaign to take on Illinois
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hits the road this Friday for an away meet, kicking off its Big Ten schedule, taking on Illinois. The Nittany Lions were in Rec Hall this past Sunday and tested the waters by testing various rotation lineups against Yale, which proved successful and resulted in a win.

The Nittany Lions rank well entering week 2, obtaining the No. 17 spot, while the Fighting Illini hold the No. 35 spot. Illinois finished second in the Border Battle Quad Meet, coming in close to first-place, Iowa.

Penn State looks confident in its ability to secure some big points right off the bat, with a slew of well-rounded talent to play around with. Penn State brought in an arsenal of new talent this season, and it can begin to move around.

Fresh faces like Kayla Bender, who excels on the balance beam, round out some of the struggles that the blue and white saw on the event last season. Freshman Lizzy Ryan could be a great addition as an all-around competitor, adding to the capabilities of Kalea McElligot and Elizabeth Leary, who were strong all-around athletes in the 2025 season.

The floor is looking like the event that will define this Fighting Illini and Nittany Lion meet, with 2025 season scores on the floor being high on both sides. Illinois enters the Big Ten season with high 9.800 scores for multiple athletes, with some reaching that 9.900 mark. Penn State is right up there with the Fighting Illini, with most of its roster scoring a high 9.800.

Vault appears to be a weak spot for Illinois, struggling to put up 2025 season high scores above 9.7500, and the rotation wasn't as successful as it had hoped during the Border Battle Quad Meet. The Nittany Lions put a heavy focus on vault, and they managed to get a good set of numbers after their rotation on Sunday.

Penn State’s meet with Yale showed Dani Latronica as a possibility for multiple events, starting off strong across vault, bar and beam. Ellie Monahan and Allison Kaempfer are both great options for the Nittany Lions to cover all their bases on Friday, with Monahan scoring well on beam and floor and Kaempfer holding it down on vault and bars.

As for the Fighting Illini, Chloe Cho showed out in their quad meet, scoring over 9.800 across the board. Bars also seem to be a focus for Illinois, with multiple 9.800 and higher scores after week one.

Mareli Muller is also a strong all-around athlete for the Fighting Illini, but she was missing from competition last week. If she joins the team again on Friday, she could be a really powerful aspect of the lineup. Being a great all-around gymnast, she can really excel and be a reason for the Nittany Lions to worry.

Illinois, similar to Penn State, has great depth and new talent entering the 2026 season, especially Callie Kauffman, a freshman who was a four-time level 10 regional qualifier and proved her abilities during week one.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Ways to celebrate Dr. Martin Luther King’s legacy in State College
author: Rubi Orellana | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is celebrating Martin Luther King Jr. with a series of events honoring his legacy of service, social justice and community.

From service projects to panels, students and community members are invited to celebrate King’s legacy and take meaningful action together.

Monday, January 19

MLK Day of Service

Students are invited to join the MLK Jr. Day of Service from 10 a.m. until 2 p.m. in the HUB-Robeson Center. The event honors King’s legacy by bringing students together for a day of community service and impact.

Volunteers will take part in indoor service projects with local organizations where free food, T-shirts and giveaways will be provided.

All students and student organizations are welcome to attend.

Tuesday, January 20

Dr. King Memorial March

Students are invited to gather at 3:30 p.m. at the MLK Jr. Plaza in downtown State College.

The march will begin at 3:45 p.m. following brief, inspirational remarks from State College Mayor Ezra Nanes and a Penn State student.

Participants will walk to the HUB, where the event will continue with a panel discussion at 4:45 p.m. in Freeman Auditorium. Students and community members are all encouraged to attend.

Register at this link if you plan to attend.

MLK Jr. Panel Discussion

After the march and a short break, students and community members are invited to stay for a panel discussion at 4:45 p.m. in Freeman Auditorium in the HUB.

Moderated by Penn State students Deja Workman and Noa Diggs, the panel will feature Randall Maurice Jelks, Wade Fulton Dean and Tracey Mariner who will explore how King’s legacy connects to today’s social and political challenges.

The evening will wrap up with a social reception at the Paul Robeson Cultural Center.

Wednesday, January 21

Poetry and Performance: A Tribute to Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

From 6-8 p.m, the Lion’s Lair Lounge will have music and readings with students, community and staff members. There will also be featured performances.

Make sure to RSVP before this event.

Friday, January 23

A Musical Tribute to MLK

Students can enjoy a special musical performance from 7:30- 9 p.m in Freeman Auditorium as part of Penn State’s week-long celebration of Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy.

The event will feature Noire, Spelman College’s contemporary popular music ensemble, known for reimagining popular music and highlighting historically underrepresented voices.

Additional performances by the United Christian Campus Ministry Choir and Penn State’s Essence of Joy will round out the evening, creating a powerful and uplifting musical tribute to King.

Saturday, January 31

A Movie Screening of the “ King in the Wilderness”

Join fellow community members in State College for a special screening of “King in the Wilderness” in Freeman Auditorium at the HUB-Robeson Center.

The film explores King’s final years, his struggles and the lasting influence of his leadership.

The screening provides new insights into King’s philosophy, courage and legacy, giving viewers a deeper understanding of the man behind the movement.

MORE CAMPUS COVERAGE

title: No. 4 Penn State hits the road, visits Syracuse
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
The collegiate women’s hockey world was stunned on Saturday afternoon, when No. 4 Penn State allowed a late tally followed by an overtime goal against Mercyhurst in its first conference loss of the season.

Continuing on their seven-game road trip, the Nittany Lions embark to Tennity Ice Pavilion in Syracuse, New York, to take on the Orange at 6 p.m Friday, and 3 p.m Saturday. The blue and white enter against Syracuse with a 19-4 overall record and 13-1 in the AHA. Meanwhile, the Orange are 12-11-3 overall and 8-6-2 in the conference.

Head-to-Head

The last time these two teams squared off, the puck was nearly always on a Nittany Lions’ stick.

The blue and white rode the offensive wave en route to an authoritative series sweep over the Orange, kicking off with a 7-0 victory in Game 1 before its history-making 11-2 punchline in Game 2. Penn State’s 11 goals tied the program record for most goals in a single game.

Syracuse currently rides a four-game winning streak after stringing together consecutive sweeps over Delaware and Robert Morris. Meanwhile, the Nittany Lions endured an upset in their previous outing against Mercyhurst.

Scouting the Orange

Syracuse is a difficult team to read. While they’ve faced defeat to ranked and unranked teams alike, the Orange responded with close games and even found success in the shootout against a top-5 opponent.

On Nov. 25, Syracuse went the distance with then-No. 5 Cornell. The game was deadlocked at 2-2 and ended up decided in a shootout. Heidi Knoll and Nea Tervonen converted on their attempts, while goaltender Ava Drabyk was solid in net for a 2-0 shootout victory, despite the game officially registering as a draw nationally.

This contest wasn’t the first time the Orange pulled off an extended-time victory, however. Four days before beating Cornell, Knoll dealt the same blow to Mercyhurst in a shootout, as well.

Outside of the shootout, Emma Gnade paces Syracuse’s offense with eight goals and seven assists. Peyton Armstrong follows closely, with 13 points this season and Jackson Kinsler rounds out the top three with 12 points.

Senior Sami Gendron leads the defensive effort with 51 blocked shots, as well as contributing a goal and five assists while maintaining a zero plus-minus rating. Sophomore Jessica Cheung ranks second with 42 blocked shots, adding seven assists.

Drabyk’s set to make her 24th start of the season between the pipes. The freshman netminder shows a 10-10-3 personal record, while boasting a .931 save percentage and 2.07 goals-against average.

Potential roster changes

Currently, Penn State has two players listed as members of their respective Olympic teams for the 2026 Milano-Cortina Winter Olympic Games: Tessa Janecke for the United States and Nicole Hall for Sweden.

With the Games approaching, Janecke and Hall, two of Penn State’s top performers, could be missing out on the Nittany Lions’ closing act with the Orange this season.

Starting goaltender Katie DeSa didn’t appear in either game against the Lakers last weekend, possibly due to an undisclosed injury, with no clear timeline on return. Freshman Maddy Campbell stepped into the starting role and has posted a .932 save percentage coupled with a 1.40 goals-against average so far through eight games.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 2 Penn State travels to West Point open for first tournament of the season
author: Annie Gleba | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 2 Penn State travels to West Point, New York, to compete in the 2026 West Point Open. The two-day event begins this Friday. The Nittany Lions opened this season with a win over Army, 311.300-297.600, at Rec Hall.

This event features competitors from levels 3 to 10 events and includes athletes from Penn State, Simpson, Navy, Springfield College, Army and William & Mary. The first day consists of NCAA-level team competition, while the second day will host individual event finals for the top qualifiers from Friday’s competition.

Last season at the West Point Open, Penn State finished second behind Ohio State, which will not return to the competition this year, with a team score of 237.800.

Simpson College

Simpson College is a Division III program that competes in the Eastern College Athletic Conference (ECAC). Simpson established its program and began to compete in the 2022-23 season. This means the Storm has never attended the West Point Open competition. They are the only NCAA school in Iowa to sponsor men’s gymnastics and one of the few DIII programs nationwide.

Last season, they placed 6th in the ECAC Championship with a score of 299.600, and their all-around season average being 292.100.

Navy

Navy won its conference championship frequently in the last decade. The Midshipmen are a powerhouse within their conference and defeated Springfield College this season. Last year in the West Point Open, they placed third with a score of 309.500.

Despite losing the conference last year, Navy posted a 5-0 record. The name to watch from the Navy is Danilo Viciana. He was elected team captain this season and participated in the NCAA Championship Event Final.

Springfield College

Springfield College finished last place during last year's competition, just narrowly behind William & Mary with 300.050 points. During the first meet of this season, the Pride placed about 1.5 points under Navy, 307.650-306.100. The Pride’s roster contains gymnasts who previously qualified for individual finals in recent seasons, aiming to improve on their previous standing scores.

They will lean on players like Owen Carney, who qualified for individual finals in three different events in last year’s West Point Open. The senior won the high bar event and placed second on the floor.

Army

Last year, Army won its conference, dethroning Navy's previous six-year streak and its first ECAC championship since 2015. Last season, Army placed 4th in the West Point Open, just slightly behind Navy with a score of 308.300.

After their conference win, the Black Knights went on to the NCAA Championships Qualifier, where they placed 10th.

William & Mary

The Griffins placed 5th in the West Point Open last year with a score of 300.450. They had four individuals advance to event finals, with all competitors placing inside the top eight. One of William & Mary’s top competitors is Evan Wilkins.

His floor score against Springfield ranks as the nation's 10th-best mark in 2025, as well as earning all-ECAC on the floor after tying for third.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: No. 1 Penn State wrestling hits the road to face No. 4 Iowa
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
This Friday, Penn State faces their marquee opponent of the season so far, traveling to Carver Hawkeye Arena to face off against the Iowa Hawkeyes.

The venue is the last place the Nittany Lions lost a dual, nearly six years ago. Iowa will look to shock the world by handing the Nittany Lions another loss. However, recent controversies and some underperforming upperclassmen leave Penn State as a heavy favorite in this top-five matchup.

125: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl (PSU) vs. No. 6 Dean Peterson (UI)

This serves as a revenge match for Luke Lilledahl after Dean Peterson upset him, 4-1, at Rutgers last season.

Peterson is 7-1 in his senior year, but has no marquee victories under his belt to this point. This will be Lilledahl’s highest-ranked matchup of the season so far.

133: No. 4 Marcus Blaze (PSU) vs. No. 8 Drake Ayala (UI)

Drake Ayala is a two-time NCAA runner-up, but has taken a step back early this season with his record floating around the .500 line heading into a match with Blaze. For Blaze, this marks an opportunity to claim a victory over one of the most prestigious names in college wrestling, even during his down year.

Despite the record, Ayala is no cake walk. In the past two years, Ayala didn’t drop more than five matches in a season. Blaze will have to use pure skill to outmatch the experience of Ayala.

141: No. 7 Braeden Davis (PSU) vs. No. 11 Nasir Bailey (UI)

Braeden Davis faces another big name talent having a relatively down year for the Hawkeyes, wrestling against former All-American and Pac-12 champion Nasir Bailey. Bailey’s 9-3 record isn’t bad, but he is nearing his loss total for previous years earlier in the season than usual.

For Davis, this is his biggest match since moving up to 141. Davis jumped into the top 10 immediately after returning to the lineup and will try to earn that ranking on Friday.

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness (PSU) vs. No. 17 Ryder Block (UI)

Ryder Block is in the midst of a breakout year after going 2-4 last season. Block is 6-2 in the early goings of his sophomore season but is 1-2 in ranked matches.

Shayne Van Ness has been running through competition this season, and Block doesn’t show the makings of an opponent that could upset the No. 1 at the weight class.

157: No. 3 PJ Duke (PSU) vs. No. 12 Jordan Williams (UI)

Jordan Williams is another highly touted transfer on Iowa’s roster after coming in from Little Rock. He’s 7-2 on the season for his new team, but is 0-2 against ranked opponents. This is the biggest matchup of the season so far for PJ Duke, going against the defending PAC-12 champion. Duke has been outscoring Williams on the year and is the favorite in this matchup.

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink (PSU) vs No. 3 Micheal Caliendo (UI)

This is a familiar matchup for both sides, as Michael Caliendo has faced Mitchell Mesenbrink six times over the last few years, with Mesenbrink winning each matchup. Each matchup has gotten closer, but it’s clear Mesenbrink has Caliendo’s number. This is expected to be a low-scoring affair as both wrestlers are patient and familiar with each other’s styles.

174: No. 1 Levi Haines (PSU) vs No. 3 Patrick Kennedy (UI)

Patrick Kennedy is in the midst of his most successful season in his senior year, starting out 9-1 and jumping into the top three. He is 3-1 against top-15 opponents, but Levi Haines is on a different level.

Haines is 3-0 against Kennedy in his career, with each win being decisive. Nothing has shifted to suggest this match will end much differently than those ones.

184: No. 4 Rocco Welsh (PSU) vs No. 1 Angelo Ferrari (UI)

Angelo Ferrari was a highly touted prospect during his redshirt season last year. During one of his matches in the Bryce Jordan Center, Ferrari held former Nittany Lion Carter Starocci to one point. This season, his defense has defined his success, as he hasn’t been taken down in a match this season. This is one of two matches where the Nittany Lion won’t be the favorite.

Rocco Welsh has been consistent since joining the Nittany Lions, but hasn’t been showing off the way Ferrari has this season. This will be a low-scoring match that may be decided by a single takedown or escape points.

197: No. 1 Josh Barr (PSU) vs. Gabe Arnold/ Harvey Ludington (UI)

With the dismissal of No. 4 Massoma Endene, there is uncertainty around who Josh Barr will face on Friday night. Gabe Arnold is a familiar name to Penn State fans and he has wrestled up to the weight class multiple times.

Harvey Ludington is on the verge of burning his redshirt, so the decision must be made to start him for the season, or yield to Arnold.

Barr has been dominant since returning to action in December, either wrestler will be challenged to compete with No. 1.

285: No. 13 Cole Mirasola (PSU) vs No. 5 Ben Kueter (UI)

This is the second matchup in which the Hawkeye is favored. Kueter, a former Iowa football player, has continued to grow as Hawkeye heavyweight. He is 3-1 in limited action and viewed as a tier above Mirasola in terms of national championship contention.

This means Mirasola has an opportunity to move up a lot in the rankings with a victory over Kueter. However, Kueter has a clear size advantage over Mirasola, a consistent struggle for the undersized Nittany Lion.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Off the Record | Ins and outs of 2026
author: The Daily Collegian
description:
Editor’s Note: Off the record is a weekly column written by a third-year Collegian staffer writing under an alias. It aims to promote a space for honest conversations about love, sex and relationships. Those interested in sharing their experiences or submitting a topic are invited to do so through our anonymous form.

Dearest reader,

Welcome back to another semester in Happy Valley — where the drama is high, the standards are low and somehow everyone’s still trying to “just see where things go.”

Allow me to introduce myself. I am Miss Behave and this semester I have the pleasure of exploring everything and anything about love, relationships and sex with you. And the best part? You get to send in your own stories and advice, anonymously, of course.

Think of me as your campus Cupid, if Cupid had a sharper tongue and better Wi‑Fi. So grab your beverage of choice and settle in, because it’s time to talk about what’s in and what’s out as we enter our 2026 era. The popular “ins” and “outs” trend is the new way to set intentions, and naturally I have thoughts.

I know we’re all busy bees this first week back, so let’s skip the foreplay and jump right into it.

INS

Self-Respect (Membership Mandatory)

Self-respect is mandatory. Desperation is the emotional equivalent of wearing socks with sandals, stop it. Also, if someone can’t meet you at your level, don’t lower standards and don't you dare settle for less than you deserve. Respect yourself and know your worth.

Emotional IQ

Ladies, if you can order a Starbucks with multiple modifications, you can say what’s actually going on in your head. Gentlemen, if you can rant about your favorite sports team for half an hour, you can spend a few minutes admitting you have feelings. Speak up and be honest.

Dating with Intention

We’re dating like adults … calendars, expectations and actual standards included. If you want something casual, say it. If you want something real, act like it. Show up, text back like a functioning human and stop acting like effort is optional.

Modern dating isn’t always cute; it can be exhausting. So stop with the games, stop with the mixed signals and for the love of all that is holy, stop chasing people who won’t even meet you halfway.

A Review Board

Your friends are the jury. If your friends aren’t hyping up your standards, they’re enabling your delusions. We should be able to lean on our close friends for advice and some guidance. Navigating a love life isn’t an easy task, and without a friendly jury, it’s basically a trial by fire.

When it comes to crushes, dating and relationships, none of us have it all figured out. It’s easy to get lost in your own feelings. Take a breath. Sometimes your friends can see the red flags or the hidden gems that you can’t.

OUTS

Chasing the unavailable

Newsflash. If they’re unavailable, they’re unavailable. Stop wasting your emotional energy on a figment of your imagination. Chasing someone who isn’t showing up for you isn’t romantic. It’s pathetic.

Your time, attention and feelings are worth more than being a background character in someone else’s story. Walk away, save your energy and invest it where it’s actually wanted.

Mixed signals

Mixed signals are manipulative. One minute, they’re all warmth and charm, the next, they vanish like Houdini. If someone can’t communicate, they’re not complicated, they’re careless.

Stop twisting yourself into knots trying to interpret vibes, texts or emojis like a cryptic code. Give your attention and effort to people who actually show up consistently, not ones who leave you guessing.

Ghosting

It’s not Halloween. Grow up.

Red flags

Listen, we will not be colorblind in 2026. If it’s giving toxic energy, leave. Ignoring warning signs isn’t brave; it's dumb. Likewise, red flags aren’t suggestions; they’re stop signs. Respect them and trust your gut.

I apologize if I sound a little harsh. Scratch that, I’m not sorry. I’m here to be real with you. If anything I said makes you flinch, chances are it’s about you. And if it is, maybe it’s time for a little self-reflection as we enter the new year.

I truly hope everyone had a great first week back. Take some of these thoughts to heart. Let them inspire you, or simply remind you that you matter. Your time, effort and heart deserve to be treated with care.

I hope your first week back is as exciting as the stories waiting to be written.

Yours truly,

Miss Behave

MORE COLUMNS

title: Film review | Ohio State transfer James Peoples brings athleticism to Penn State RB room
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Ohio State running back James Peoples committed to Penn State during the transfer-portal window, giving the team a player with upside.

Peoples was in a depth role for the Buckeyes in 2025, tallying 61 carries for 344 yards and three touchdowns. The sophomore was a 247Sports composite 4-star and the No. 115 player nationally in the 2024 class, and he flashed some of that potential this past season.

Here are the traits Peoples could bring with him to Happy Valley.

Athleticism

Peoples has the athleticism to make potential tacklers in the open field miss. He’s flashed that talent on the limited touches he saw through his two seasons with the Buckeyes.

Possibly his most noteworthy play in 2025 came against UCLA, where he took a handoff to the right side of the field, hurdling over a defender to score a touchdown on a 19-yard rush.

Peoples has athleticism in the open field, such as this hurdle to score a touchdown against UCLA pic.twitter.com/UGG526xscs— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Peoples showcased some shiftiness, being able to change direction quickly and juke out defenders.

He can make potential tacklers miss like this rush versus the Bruins pic.twitter.com/kXEGaae4bP— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

With this skillset, Penn State could try to get Peoples out in the open field on plays next season. Him consistently making opposing players miss would allow him to break off chunk yardage plays for the Nittany Lions.

Vision

Behind an offensive line that opened up running lanes at Ohio State, Peoples used his vision to find and attack those opportunities to pick up yards.

With a quick burst of speed, he can quickly run through open rushing lanes.

Peoples has the vision to see and attack open rushing lanes, which gives him opportunities to pick up large gains like this pic.twitter.com/Ro7JvBz6S9— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Peoples’ proved his vision on these plays, trusting his eyes and not hesitating on these rushes.

Peoples consistently takes advantage of rushing lanes generated by the blocking in front of him pic.twitter.com/0iLkreYrP9— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

If Penn State’s offensive line can generate a similar push on opposing defensive fronts, Peoples seems like he’ll be able to make the same impact plays on the ground for the Nittany Lions.

Yards after contact

While Peoples has speed in the open field, he can also break out of contact between the tackles.

He had one of those types of plays against Penn State in 2025, picking up a first down after being contacted near the line of scrimmage.

Peoples can pick up yards after contact, such as this rush against Penn State pic.twitter.com/mmw0VDoUhM— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

The 5-foot-10, 206-pound running back has the strength to break through would-be tacklers, powering himself downfield for tough yardage.

Here’s another look at Peoples gaining yards after contact pic.twitter.com/pkBqG3lmAw— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

It’ll give him the versatility to be used on either inside or outside zone rushes for Penn State.

Pass-catcher potential

Peoples didn’t see much action in the passing game during his two seasons at Ohio State, but he still caught 10 passes for 50 yards in 2025.

As such, Peoples flashed the potential to be involved in a passing attack with receptions via screen passes or check downs for the Buckeyes.

He could be used in the passing game as well with screen passes or checkdowns pic.twitter.com/79rYvzgCiE— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Getting the ball to Peoples with a throw also gets him in the open field, where he can use his agility to rack up yards.

Another catch by Peoples here: pic.twitter.com/cthinfL6J2— Collegian Football (@psufootblog) January 14, 2026

Peoples could be on the field in obvious passing downs for Penn State, adding another wrinkle to his game.
