title: Penn State women’s basketball looks to upset No. 14 Ohio State for 2nd straight year
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Entering the second quarter down by eight, Penn State stormed back and outscored Ohio State 20-9 in the quarter.

After upsetting the then-No. 9 Buckeyes last year, the Lady Lions travel to Columbus to take them on again at 6:30 p.m. on Wednesday with the same goal in mind.

This year’s Ohio State team looks very different this year, missing its high scorer from last year. With WNBA scouts in attendance, Cotie McMahon scored 19 points on the blue and white last January before transferring to Ole Miss for her final year.

However, the Buckeyes were without Jaloni Cambridge — last year’s No. 2 scorer and this year’s leading scorer — due to an injury.

This year, she stands among the top scorers in the conference and 10th best in the nation, averaging 21.2 points per game.

In addition to Cambridge, Ohio State found success with Chance Grey and Kylee Kitts, who combine for 22.5 points per game.

Besides Grey, who scored 18 points on last year’s Penn State team, much of the Buckeyes’ starting lineup is new to coach Carolyn Kieger’s squad and will get their first look on Wednesday.

For the Lady Lions, however, their three primary starters played against Ohio State last year. Both Gracie Merkle and Moriah Murray played big roles in the team’s upset, scoring 12 points each.

While Kiyomi McMiller didn’t suit up for the blue and white last year against the Buckeyes, she was a strong contributor for Rutgers, scoring 14 points in her team’s loss.

This year, that trio has led the Lady Lions on the court, averaging a combined 47.8 points per game.

Murray has been the blue and white’s leading 3-point scorer for the past two seasons and is on pace to be in the top 10 for most triples in a season, currently having 46 made shots from behind the arc.

Meanwhile, Merkle made her way as the nation’s most efficient shooter, shooting 74.6% from the court. McMiller rounds out the three with her strong ball-handling skills and playmaking, working her way to the basket when all else fails.

While Ohio State comes in towering over Penn State in the David versus Goliath matchup, the blue and white has the tools it needs to overtake Cambridge and the Buckeyes for its second straight upset and first conference win of the season.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Weekly recap | Penn State men’s basketball narrowly falls to ranked opponents
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State basketball started 0-3 in 2026, however the games were against three AP-ranked opponents, which boosts optimism as they move forward.

Here are three major takeaways from the most recent stretch of games where the blue and white faced then-No.20 Illinois, No. 2 Michigan and No. 5 Purdue.

Close, but no cigar

The Nittany Lions finished ten points in each of those games and even had a final possession against the Wolverines, with Freddie Dilione V just barely missing a shot on a questionable play call that Michigan easily snuffed out.

That sentiment echoes the trend of how the Nittany Lions play down the stretch, as experienced, higher-performing teams quickly derail any attempt by the blue and white to pull off an upset.

Against Illinois, the blue and white fell behind by 14 at the half and traded buckets with the Fighting Illini, but couldn’t overcome the efficiency of its foe. Against Michigan, despite the Wolverines opening a path to victory by shooting over 10 percentage points worse after the break, the Nittany Lions still shot under 40% and struggled from beyond the arc and at the free throw line.

Despite the Purdue contest marking an improved second-half shooting stretch, the blue and white dished out half as many assists and turned the ball over five times, while the Boilermakers turned it over once, again putting the win out of reach down the wire.

Tale of two shooters

In the early games of 2026, the Nittany Lions sought to improve their shooting from beyond the arc; a team that averaged 7.8 threes per game surpassed that mark in this stretch of contests. That shooting came courtesy of two main wings, Eli Rice and Dominick Stewart, who ramped up their willingness to empty the clip from downtown.

Rice posted a season high in shot attempts over the stretch, while Stewart also surpassed his averages for field goals and three-point attempts per game in two of the contests. Both the 3-and-D players posted mixed results despite their newfound willingness to shoot.

Stewart, over the three games, shot 2-for-18 from the field and committed 12 fouls, while Rice went 10-for-23 with six long-range makes.

Via Evan Miyakawa’s statistical formulas, Stewart ranks as the least efficient and worst-performing Nittany Lion with over 200 possessions. On the contrary, Rice ranks fourth on the squad in performance and posts the best defensive rating.

Introduction to injury

In two of the three games Penn State played, it did so without star freshman guard Kayden Mingo, who reportedly suffered a broken nose in practice. That absence raised concerns among the blue-and-white fanbase, as most of the Nittany Lions' on-court identity is from Mingo.

The Farmingdale, New York, native provides all-around skills: playmaking, scoring, defense and leadership, yet the difficulty without him didn’t seem to be much greater than with his services, as Penn State still posted formidable results.

It does mark the first major injury for Penn State this season, and he’s joined on the sidelines by Tibor Mirtić, who appeared on the availability report before the Purdue game after exiting against Michigan.

The last injury report for Penn State men’s basketball marked the lengthiest it’s been so far this season.

Both the guard and forward likely miss extended time for Penn State, and navigating a less-than-full-strength roster is essential for Mike Rhoades’ squad, as it looks to build a foundation and confidence on the court outside of its budding superstar.

Over the past week of play, Penn State seems to have started strongly toward that goal, which should result in a stronger team once everyone is available.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Nittany Lions in the NFL | Former Penn Staters star despite being sent home
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
The NFL Playoff is underway with wild card round action happening this past weekend.

A few former Penn State players made impacts for their NFL teams, including two players racking up over 100 yards and defensive end getting multiple sacks.

Here’s what stood out among ex-Nittany Lions.

Parker Washington, wide receiver, Jacksonville Jaguars

Wide receiver Parker Washington had a strong finish to the regular season, and he extended that into the playoffs despite the Jacksonville Jaguars’ 27-24 loss to the Buffalo Bills on Sunday.

Washington totaled seven catches for a team-high 107 yards on 12 targets, which is the most he’s seen in a game this season. The former Nittany Lion also had a 6-yard touchdown to put the Jaguars ahead 17-13 with 12:55 left in the fourth quarter.

Parker Washington gives the Jaguars the lead!BUFvsJAX on CBS/Paramount+Stream on @NFLPlus pic.twitter.com/yn2JXBuFwQ— NFL (@NFL) January 11, 2026

Washington picked up chunk yardage on multiple plays, including a long reception of 34 yards. He also had a 31-yard catch at the 7:05 mark of the fourth quarter, helping Jacksonville move down the field to eventually retake the lead.

The former sixth-round NFL draft pick ended his year with 65 catches for 954 yards and six touchdowns in the regular season and postseason combined. His regular season numbers of 58 receptions for 847 yards and five scores are all career highs for the third-year player.

Odafe Oweh, defensive end, Los Angeles Chargers

Defensive end Odafe Oweh completed his first season with the Los Angeles Chargers following a 16-3 loss to the New England Patriots on Sunday, and he set a new personal record with three sacks.

Oweh got involved in the backfield early, registering a sack with 12:57 left in the first quarter. He later stripped sacked quarterback Drake Maye, which was recovered by teammate Da'Shawn Hand.

Odafe Oweh knocks it loose!Da'Shawn Hand recovers!Chargers ball ⚡️LACvsNE on NBCStream on @NFLPlus + Peacock pic.twitter.com/YzXV08M6gu— NFL (@NFL) January 12, 2026

He ended his night with four tackles, giving him 42 tackles and 10.5 sacks across both the regular season and postseason.

Oweh was traded to the Chargers midseason from the Baltimore Ravens, where he spent the first four years of his career. With 7.5 sacks in the regular season, Oweh set the second-highest sack total he’s tallied, coming up short to his 10-sack effort in 2024.

Saquon Barkley, running back, Philadelphia Eagles

Running back Saquon Barkley eclipsed the century mark on the ground even though the Philadelphia Eagles lost to the San Francisco 49ers on Sunday, 23-19.

Barkley rushed for 106 yards on 26 carries in addition to three catches for 25 yards. He had a long rush of 31 yards, and he also had a 29-yard carry to help set up a touchdown drive in the first quarter.

First down and more for Saquon 😤SFvsPHI on FOX/FOX OneStream on @NFLPlus pic.twitter.com/v1ffV7HhvO— NFL (@NFL) January 11, 2026

Barkley finished his year with 1,246 yards and seven touchdowns on 26 attempts in the regular season and postseason. His 1,140 rushing yards in the regular season was the fifth time in his career he’s passed the 1,000-yard mark.

Jaquan Brisker, safety, Chicago Bears

Safety Jaquan Brisker was once again a leader for the Chicago Bears’ defense with a team-high nine tackles in a 31-27 win over the Green Bay Packers on Saturday.

In coverage, Brisker didn’t give up many plays as he allowed one catch for 20 yards on one target, according to PFF. This year, Brisker is up to 102 tackles in the regular season and postseason combined.

Brisker and the Bears’ season will continue with a divisional round matchup against the Los Angeles Rams next weekend.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Big Ten recap | Women’s basketball sees numerous upsets in last week’s matchups
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
While Penn State fell to Illinois to continue its six-game losing streak, the Big Ten saw several other storylines in the past week of conference play.

From top-25 showdowns to busted win streaks and continued losing streaks, many teams had their fair share of highlights and big games.

Here’s a recap of the conference action this week.

USC falls to Oregon, Minnesota

USC has looked like a different team this year without JuJu Watkins, and that was on display even more this past week.

Entering the week as No. 21 in the AP poll, the Trojans fell to two unranked teams in Oregon and Minnesota.

USC pulled into a commanding 23-9 lead after the first quarter against the Ducks, and that was extended even more to a 16-point lead at half. However, Oregon flipped the script in the final quarter, outscoring USC 26-8 to win the game.

Against the Golden Gophers, Jazzy Davidson — the No. 1 athlete in the Class of 2025 — scored 21 points alongside senior Kara Dunn’s 27 points.

The team’s bench was the ultimate letdown, however, scoring just three points.

Minnesota’s Grace Grocholski and Sophie Hart combined for 40 to win 63-62, sending USC to the middle of the Big Ten with a 2-3 conference record.

Purdue beats Wisconsin, Washington

Following three straight losses, Purdue found some hope to rejuvenate its season with a pair of upset wins over Wisconsin and Washington.

The Boilermakers had a disappointing start to the season, losing to their satellite campus Purdue Fort Worth and to Central Michigan. However, they showed signs of strength in their two wins that could carry deeper into the season.

Purdue pulled out to a commanding 18-9 lead after the first quarter to Wisconsin, and despite the Badgers closing the gap to one point at halftime, closed out the game while outscoring Wisconsin by seven points in the second half.

A big part of Purdue’s success came from the triple, as it went 12-for-20 from deep. Sophomore Nya Smith led the way with four 3-pointers, followed by Madison Layden-Zay’s three triples.

The first quarter played out a little differently against Washington, however, as Purdue entered the second quarter down by nine points.

While junior Sayvia Sellers scored 23 points against the Boilermakers, they were able to bring the game to overtime tied at 63 each.

Layden-Zay and Tara Daye put the nail in the coffin in overtime, each scoring 19 points on the game to win by six — tying USC with 10 wins on the year.

No. 19 Ohio State earns upset over No. 8 Maryland

After falling to No. 1 UConn and No. 4 UCLA earlier in the year, Ohio State earned its first big win of the year as it handed Maryland its second loss of the year.

The Terrapins came out of the first quarter shooting 60% from deep with a 24-12 lead over Ohio State. However, the Buckeyes scored 28 points in the second and fourth quarters to win by 13 points.

Jaloni Cambridge continued to craft her second straight All Big Ten season, scoring 28 points on Maryland.

Kylee Kitts, Kennedy Cambridge and Chance Grey all scored double digits as well, combining for 43 points.

Despite the loss, Maryland’s Oluchi Okananwa scored 27 points, recording over 20 points for the fifth time this year.

MORE BASKETBALL CONTENT

title: Penn State men’s basketball faces UCLA, seeking first Big Ten victory
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State started its 2026 half of the season with three consecutive ranked opponents, and was unable to claim any victories despite hard-fought battles.

Eight points decided the games against then-No. 20 Illinois and No. 5 Purdue, while the No. 2 Michigan contest came all the way down to the wire with a missed Freddie Dilione V jumper on the final buzzer, giving the Wolverines a 74-72 win. After five conference games, the blue and white sit winless.

Penn State will break the streak of facing top-of-the-conference and national opponents when it faces UCLA on Wednesday at the Bryce Jordan Center, where the Nittany Lions hold a 7-3 home record.

Although both teams play in the same conference, there are no common opponents between Penn State and UCLA so far this season. UCLA’s last two games against Wisconsin and Maryland will be Penn State's next two opponents after this game.

On the surface, scouting the Bruins, they remain a daunting foe at 11-5 overall, with a 3-2 conference record and an undefeated home streak after 10 games.

Bogged down Bruins

As the initial scouting report for UCLA presents, it doesn’t possess many flaws, with a top-half conference offense and defense. The Bruins’ +9.8 point scoring differential is a top-10 figure in the conference, despite their scoring average being the sixth lowest in the Big Ten.

These figures indicate a slower tempo and an efficient offensive approach from the Bruins, who rank sixth in the conference in field goal percentage. UCLA averages 70 possessions per game, placing it outside the top 240 teams nationally.

The Nittany Lions, who hold a slightly worse scoring offense but a much less effective defense, rank only somewhat behind the Bruins in possessions per game.

Luckily for the blue and white UCLA typically averages fewer offensive touches with the ball when they’re away from home, and is heading to Happy Valley, where Penn State ranks similarly to UCLA in their top level of play at home.

Evan Miyakawa’s formulas state that UCLA is a consistent team that plays the same regardless of the level of competition and pace. That tempo is again where a differential may emerge; however, the Bruins hold a bottom-six Big Ten tempo rating, while Penn State ranks in the top six.

The two coaching styles clash at the BJC, yet only one can prevail.

Participating personnel

Both Mike Rhoades and UCLA coach Mick Cronin’s units dealt with significant recent injuries, and that trend continues into this week’s clash.

Penn State’s star and leader on the court, Kayden Mingo reportedly broke his nose in practice and won’t play against the Bruins barring any significant change in status. The Penn State second-highest in scoring, and leader in assists, missed his second consecutive game as Penn State listed him and Tibor Mirtič on the last availability report.

Mirtič played all 15 games before his first absence this season, and Rhoades didn’t provide an immediate update on his status.

The Bruins listed senior guard Skyy Clark as out in their last contest, as well as wing Brandon Williams. Clark stands as UCLA’s second leading scorer and started in all but one of his 14 appearances, while Williams averages double-digit minutes as a valuable bench two-way contributor.

Clark dealt with a hamstring injury in the last few games, and before the previous contest, he got upgraded to day-to-day, meaning his return is inevitable and may even occur against Penn State.

Williams may also return soon, as his status is day-to-day due to leg cramps.

For UCLA, its leading scorer this season is senior forward Tyler Bilodeau, who averages 17.5 points, shoots the lowest field goal percentage out of its players who average double digits and scored a season high of 34 this year.

Joining Sky and Bilodeau are three other double-digit scorers for the Bruins, including Eric Dailey Jr., who leads the squad with 5.9 rebounds per game.

Dailey Jr transferred to UCLA after committing to Oklahoma State out of the 2023 class from IMG Academy, the same school and class that Penn State’s Eli Rice came out of and joined Nebraska before heading to Happy Valley.

Over the last four games, Rice has averaged 11.75 points per game and has reached over 20 minutes in each game of that stretch, as he puts together a breakout campaign.

Also stepping up over that stretch, and in particular once Mingo went down, is Dilione, who averages a team high 15 points per game, and orchestrates the offense with his desired tempo.

title: Penn State moves forest, wildlife technology programs to Altoona campus amid pending closures
author: Rubi Orellana | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has approved the relocation of its associate degree programs in forest technology and wildlife technology to Penn State Altoona to ensure the programs continue for future students.

In May, the Board of Trustees voted to close seven Commonwealth campuses by the spring 2027 semester, citing financial strain.

The forest technology program is currently offered at Penn State Mont Alto, while the wildlife technology program is based at Penn State DuBois.

Students already enrolled will be able to remain at their current campuses until they close, allowing most to complete their degrees without transferring.

Beginning in fall 2026, new forest technology students will start at Mont Alto and new wildlife technology students will begin at DuBois before transitioning to Altoona for their second year in the 2027–28 academic year. By fall 2027, however, all new students will complete both programs entirely at Altoona.

The forest and wildlife technology programs are among several Commonwealth campus programs approved for relocation.

Three other Commonwealth campus programs will also relocate beginning in 2026-27, with biomedical engineering technology students completing at Greater Allegheny, electro-mechanical engineering technology students completing at Altoona, Beaver or Berks and radiological sciences students completing at either Greater Allegheny or Schuylkill.

title: Penn State notebook | Guy Gadowsky talks injury updates, Spengler Cup recap
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Guy Gadowsky spoke at weekly media on Monday for the first time since before the team’s extended break. While NCAA contests were halted, several Nittany Lions continued to compete abroad over the six-week hiatus.

Since opening play in the unofficial second half of the season, the blue and white have earned a series split with RIT, and most recently, are coming off a Big Ten series sweep of Minnesota.

Injury update

Despite the successful series at Pegula Ice Arena, a dark spot on the weekend was the number of injuries sustained by the Nittany Lions. Gadowsky opened the press conference with updates on several blue and white skaters.

“I can share that Braedon Ford is going to be out for a significant amount of time,” Gadowsky said.

Ford recorded his first goal of the season after opening the scoring for the blue and white early in Saturday’s contest with the Golden Gophers. In the second period, the forward went down awkwardly into the boards and was in visible pain on his way to the locker room.

Gadowsky listed three other skaters that were “day-to-day, with nothing concrete,” including the team’s points leader, Charlie Cerrato. Cerrato exited Friday’s game with an injury and was then scratched for Saturday. Both Shea Van Olm and Casey Aman were also included in that group.

Spengler Cup recap

Over the break, five Nittany Lions competed in the Spengler Cup as a part of the first-ever U.S. Collegiate Selects team. Led by Gadowsky, they finished a successful inaugural campaign, complete with a silver medal.

“The entire experience was really tremendous,” Gadowsky said. “Switzerland is beautiful, the food was great, the atmosphere at the arena was incredible.”

The performance helped put a spotlight on collegiate hockey after an all-NCAA team defeated some top European talent.

“College hockey is really, really, good, especially this year,” Gadowsky said.

Gadowsky brought Cerrato, JJ Wiebusch, Matt DiMarsico, Aiden Fink and Mac Gadowsky over with him, and he spoke on what it meant to share the experience with them.

“It was awesome, I feel very grateful that we were able to do that, and they deserve it,” Gadowsky said. “I didn’t set out to take that many Penn Staters, but I felt they absolutely deserved it, and they all played really, really well.”

Fink’s return

After going down with an injury in late October, Fink made his return to the lineup in the new year and has made an immediate impact.

“You can’t deny, Aiden Fink is an excellent scorer,” Gadowsky said. “But when he’s at his best, and the real influence that you’re talking about is how he does it, his motor.”

Gadowsky spoke more on Fink’s work ethic, saying, “he consistently gives a lot of himself.”

After the forward’s three-assist performance on Saturday, Fink became the fastest Nittany Lion in program history to reach the 100-point threshold, and just the ninth all-time.

“No one consistently is going to score every game or get points every game, but (Fink) will never not get points because he’s just cruising,” Gadowsky said. “I haven’t seen that out of him.”

title: Ivan Jurić used to be a guard, now he’s a ‘huge part’ on Penn State basketball as a 7-footer
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Seven-footer Ivan Jurić started playing basketball as a guard, but then during the summer when he was 15-years-old, he grew over seven inches taller, making a position switch to the frontcourt.

Now, Jurić is in his freshman year at Penn State, where he’s become a standout player with recent performances like 20 points against No. 2 Michigan and nine points and 10 rebounds versus No. 5 Purdue last week.

“He's a huge part of what we do, and for him to be learning all this going through Big Ten play against the players and teams, says a lot about him and his potential, which is a great word to have tagged to you,” Rhoades said Monday. “His potential is he has a very high ceiling, but he is very open to understanding and applying it. You see what you can get from him, and he's done a good job being more consistent, and he's still a young guy, so it's gonna be some ups and downs for him.”

Jurić is averaging 9.1 points and 4.1 rebounds per game through 16 appearances this season. After coming off the bench in the first four games, the big man has started the last 12 games after proving to Rhoades he wouldn’t get in foul trouble on a regular basis.

He’s acted as a typical center by battling for boards and going for tough baskets in the paint, but he also brings the ability to stretch the floor to the Nittany Lions. Jurić has taken 30 3-point attempts this season, knocking down 10 of them, including four made 3-pointers in the last three games.

Jurić said his shooting skill comes from his days playing as a guard. He grew up in Croatia, and he played for the professional team BC Dubrava in the Croatian Premier League during the 2023-24 season.

The Zagreb, Croatia, native played for his home country in the 2024 FIBA U18 Eurobasket. He explained what it was like while making the transition to the center, citing his playing experience overseas.

“First, it was kind of hard, because I still had to grow into my body and put on some weight since I played with grown men back in my country to be able to fight with them,” Jurić said Monday. “Then I just used what I knew, started passing and shooting.”

The 19-year-old has grown into his large frame, as his listed weight with Penn State is 250 pounds.

Jurić was a late addition to Penn State’s 2025 recruiting class, signing in May after playing the 2024-25 season with Sunrise Christian Academy. He was rated as a 247Sports composite 4-star and the No. 154 player overall.

With the Nittany Lions, Jurić gets to work with assistant coach Brent Scott, who played a key role in developing 7-footer and NBA first-round pick Yanic Konan Niederhauser.

“I think he's helped me with a lot of things,” Jurić said. “The thing that worked for me the best is watching film with him, because the great player he was, he can tell me from a different perspective, like the way I do some things. So, yeah, I think every aspect I improved on, he's got a big hand in it.”

Jurić’s potential as a 7-footer who can play in both the interior and on the perimeter makes him an important player to watch for opposing defenses.

Rhoades said Jurić had a “high-level” performance against the Boilermakers, acting like a guard on the outside at times to help the rest of the offense against the Boilermakers.

“I thought he connected our offense a lot, not just because he rebounded and scored, but just continuing to keep our offense in a flow, and I thought at times Purdue got behind because we played through the big man, even on the perimeter, and it put them at a disadvantage,” Rhoades said. “I think it was one reason why we had so many layups and scores in the basket in the second half. They're so worried about him away from the basket, it created scoring, scoring lanes for other guys. So he's been doing a very good job.”

title: Penn State notebook | Mike Rhoades gives injury updates, talks Dominick Stewart’s shooting
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
With Penn State on a three-game losing streak that saw the team stay close to highly ranked opponents, Mike Rhoades met with the media on Monday to break down the state of the team.

Rhoades gave some injury updates on two players in addition to providing a review of a sophomore guard and what response he’s looking for from the team moving forward after the skid.

Here’s more of what Rhoades said.

Injury updates

Rhoades gave an update on guard Kayden Mingo and Tibor Mirtič, who both missed last Saturday’s game against Purdue. Mingo will be out for “a while” with a broken nose he endured during practice last Monday, and Mirtič will be sidelined for “a little bit” due to a knee injury he picked up from the Michigan game last Tuesday.

“Health's most important for (Mingo) and Tibor,” Rhoades said. “Just follow the gotta follow the doctor's orders and all that … We can't afford any injuries, and we have two that we really need back, but their health is number one, and we just got to keep pushing forward until we get those guys back, hopefully sooner than later.”

Rhoades said on the Penn State Sports Network after the loss to the Boilermakers that Mingo’s surgery for his broken nose “went well.”

Mingo is the Nittany Lions’ starting point guard and was the team’s leading scorer before his injury. Mirtič is a rotational big man in the frontcourt, but he started the game against the Wolverines before exiting with an injury.

Rhoades emphasized the need for recovery before returning to action.

“Find the final rhythm to get it back into the swing of things, and get your feet under and all that stuff,” Rhoades said. “So that's part of being a college athlete. Everyone's going to deal with injuries. You just got to do what's best for you and follow the plan from the trainers and the doctors. We have a great trainer. Justin (Pomar) will do a great job with him, getting him and Tibor back.”

Dominick Stewart review

Guard Dominick Stewart has 3-point shooting abilities for Penn State, but he’s gone 2-of-18 on deep shots the past three games.

“(Dominick Stewart)’s got to shoot the ball better,” Rhoades said. “He's a college two guard. He's not shooting it well right now, but we need him to. He has an impact in the game because of his intensity and his approach, and I really appreciate that. I think some of it is just calming down and playing the game and not forcing it.”

Rhoades said the team tracks the players’ heart rates during practice, and Stewart is “always” at the top in workload “because he doesn't take off reps and how hard he practices.”

Stewart is an active defender but has run into foul trouble in recent games, including fouling out against Illinois. He’s averaging 5.8 points and 2.2 rebounds per game with 35% 3-point shooting so far this season.

“We want to get to a point where he's working that hard, but he's calmer, and his workload is still high, but the intensity gets lower,” Rhoades said. “I just think that comes with experience and allows it, and I really appreciate how hard he's working and his approach, and he cares so much. I love him. We got to get him to come down and play a little, enjoy it more. He wants it so bad. It's not a bad thing.”

Team response

Penn State dropped three straight games, but it has remained competitive throughout each contest. Each loss was by a single digit and against three of the top teams in the Big Ten.

While the team is hungry for a win, Rhoades wants the players to focus on what they can still control.

“I just want to keep our guys getting better,” Rhoades said. “Process, process, process, and then hopefully, and I believe in it, that the results will come. It's frustrating. It's hard. I feel for the guys, but it is what it is.”

Rhoades said the Nittany Lions “battle” and that the players care about the “right stuff,” but the team just has to keep improving.

Penn State hosts UCLA on Wednesday before traveling to Maryland on Sunday, and it won’t face another ranked opponent again until Feb. 2, when it visits No. 2 Michigan.

“We can't control what's next, and we can't worry about what's going to happen,” Rhoades said. “I know that's hard, especially for 18 to 22-year-old competitive athletes, but I do know this, and I believe this, that if you just try to stack days upon days, and you will be all about the process, you'd be all about trying to get better. You're putting yourself in a better position and get the results you want. I really believe that.”

title: Transfer portal update | Penn State offers 2 offensive linemen, former players taking new visits
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s Day 11 of the transfer portal being officially opened.

Matt Campbell and company have brought in numerous transfers and are working on recruiting more players in the portal to Penn State. Meanwhile, former players from the team have made visits elsewhere, and the staff missed out on some prospects.

Here are some recent updates on the Nittany Lions’ action in the portal. For a full breakdown on Penn State returnees, transfers and departures, click here.

Running back room shakeup

Penn State saw a few more portal departures in recent days, but the most notable news came in the running back room, where two players changed their previously announced plans. Cam Wallace exited the transfer portal to return to the Nittany Lions while Tikey Hayes entered the portal despite originally saying he’d remain with the team.

The two moves might not have the most resounding impact on Penn State’s running back room in 2026 — the Nittany Lions added transfer commitments from Iowa State’s Carson Hansen and Ohio State’s James Peoples — but it’ll give the team more experienced depth. Hayes redshirted in 2025 after only appearing in the Pinstripe Bowl, and Wallace will be in his fourth collegiate year next season.

Wallace hit the highlight reel with a hurdle in the Nevada game this season after enduring a season-ending leg injury in 2024. He has 24 carries for 86 yards and a touchdown throughout seven appearances in his career.

As the room stands, the Nittany Lions will have Hansen, Peoples, Wallace, redshirt sophomore Quinton Martin Jr. and 2026 3-star commit D'Antae Sheffey on the roster next season.

New portal prospects

Transfer offensive lineman Tyshon Huff announced an offer from Penn State via his X account. Huff played at the Division II level with Tiffin University, starting in all 11 games this past season and getting reps at both tackle and guard.

Huff, who is 6-foot-4, 300 pounds, redshirted his freshman year in 2023 and played in one game during the 2024 season, so he has two years of eligibility remaining.

The Nittany Lions offered another offensive lineman with Rutgers transfer Carter Kadow announcing one via his X account. Kadow didn’t appear in a game through his two seasons as a Scarlet Knight, giving him three years of eligibility left.

Kadow is 6-foot-7, 307 pounds, and he was a 247Sports composite 3-star and the No. 1,676 player nationally in the 2024 class.

Former Nittany Lions taking visits

Former Penn State quarterback and current Missouri transfer Beau Pribula has continued to take visits. Recent reports said Pribula is set to visit Virginia, Georgia Tech and Tennessee.

Pribula has previously been reported to have visits set to Washington and Virginia Tech as well. The gunslinger threw for 1,941 yards, 11 touchdowns and nine interceptions with the Tigers in 2025.

Running back Corey Smith visited Boise State last Thursday, according to 247Sports. Smith started in the Pinstripe Bowl and totaled 14 carries for 30 yards in 2025, and he has 36 attempts for 182 yards and a touchdown in his career.

Penn State portal targets commit elsewhere

A few transfer portal players who were linked to Penn State have recently committed to other schools.

FIU defensive lineman Xion Chapman, who took a visit to Happy Valley last week and was offered by the staff, pledged to Minnesota on Saturday. Samford cornerback Dee Newsome reportedly planned to take a visit to Penn State last Friday, but he has since committed to Purdue, according to 247Sports.

South Dakota running back LJ Phillips Jr. transferred to Iowa after reportedly having a visit with the Nittany Lions set for last Tuesday. Montana State defensive back Seth Johnson scheduled a visit with Penn State for last Friday and Saturday, but he committed to Iowa State on Saturday.

Iowa Western Community College defensive lineman Andy Burburija was set to visit Penn State, per Allen Trieu of 247Sports, and he pledged to Nebraska on Sunday. Southeastern Louisiana wide receiver Jaylon Domingeaux reportedly had a visit lined up with the Nittany Lions, but he committed to Wisconsin on Wednesday.

title: What to know about new Penn State running backs coach Savon Huggins
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
News broke last week that Penn State was closing in on hiring Savon Huggins as its running backs coach.

Huggins, whose hire completed Matt Campbell’s first staff with the Nittany Lions, brings power-conference experience with him as well as previously coaching productive tailbacks.

Here’s what to know about Huggins.

Coaching history

Huggins previously worked at Boston College as its running backs coach prior to getting hired in Happy Valley. He had held that role since the 2022 season, and beginning in 2024, he was on former Penn State head coach and current Eagles head coach Bill O’Brien’s staff.

The Jackson, New Jersey, native led improvement in Boston College’s rushing attack after averaging 63.3 yards per game in 2022. The Eagles ran for above 100 yards per game in each of the last three seasons, including 198.3 yards per game in 2023 and 166.4 yards per game in 2024.

Prior to getting the running backs coach role at Boston College, he was a recruiting advisor for the Eagles in 2021. He’s an alum of St. Peter’s Prep, joining recruiting coordinator Naz Oliver as Penn State staffers who have connections to the New Jersey area.

Huggins was briefly the running backs coach at UMass in 2021 before getting hired by Boston College, and he never coached a game with the Minutemen.

Earlier in his career, Huggins was a wide receivers assistant at Buffalo in 2020, when the Bulls averaged 191 passing yards a game. He spent time with his high school alma mater as an offensive assistant the year prior.

After a three-year stint with Somerville High School in New Jersey as an offensive and defensive assistant from 2016-18, Huggins completed a fellowship with the Miami Dolphins during the 2019 season.

Notable running backs coached

This season, Huggins helped running back Turbo Richard rush for 749 yards and nine touchdowns on 145 carries, giving him an average of 5.2 yards per carry.

Richard then entered the transfer portal, and the production he showed helped him gain an offer from national championship contender Indiana, where he will transfer to.

Prior to Richard, Huggins had running back Kye Robichaux at Boston College. Robichaux ran for over 700 yards in each of his two seasons as an Eagle, including averaging 4.8 yards per rush in 2023. He scored 18 rushing touchdowns across 2023-24.

Robichaux went on to sign an undrafted free agent deal with the Detroit Lions following the 2025 NFL draft.

Playing days

Huggins began his collegiate career at Rutgers. He was a 247Sports composite 5-star and the No. 28 player nationally, No. 4 running back and No. 1 player from New Jersey in the 2011 class.

With the Scarlet Knights, Huggins appeared in 32 games across three seasons, tallying 261 carries for 842 yards and nine touchdowns. He ran for a career-high 179 rushing yards on 41 attempts in a 10-3 win over Cincinnati in 2012.

Huggins missed his senior year at Rutgers due to injury, transferring to Northern Iowa ahead of the 2015 season. He made three starts and rushed for 216 yards and two touchdowns across 14 games with the Panthers.

title: This week in State College
author: Neel Ved | The Daily Collegian
description:
As the spring semester begins, there are many events for students to attend as they settle in.

For those looking for something to do outside of classes, here are some events that you may want to attend.

Monday, January 12

First Day of Classes Photo Booth

From 9:30 a.m.-2:30 p.m., a photo booth will be in the Galbraith Lounge in the HUB Robeson Center. Students are encouraged to take pictures alone or with friends to celebrate the start of the spring semester.

The event is free and registration is not required.

Drag Bingo

From 8-10 p.m. the Penn State Student Orientation Transition Program will be hosting a Drag Bingo event in Alumni Hall in the HUB. It will be an evening full of games and prizes.

Doors open at 7:30 p.m. and space is limited as this is a first-come, first-served event.

Tuesday, January 13

Spring Involvement Fair

From 11 a.m.-5 p.m. the Spring Involvement Fair will be taking place in Alumni Hall in the HUB.

Students can come explore the hundreds of clubs and organizations at Penn State that are currently recruiting new members.

Salsa Lessons

The Social Dance Club at Penn State University Park will be hosting dance lessons for students, community members and faculty from 6-8:30 p.m. at the Municipal Building. The first 90 minutes of the event are for lessons, and the remainder of the class is for social dancing.

Registration is required for this event.

Wednesday, January 14

Learn to Skate Classes at Pegula Ice Arena

The Pegula Ice Arena is offering ice skating lessons to people of all levels, beginner, intermediate and advanced. The lessons are for anyone ages 2.5 to adult.

Registration is required and the price to join is $90.

Yoga & Meditation

From noon-1 p.m., the Palmer Museum of Art will be hosting yoga and meditation sessions.

During this time, anyone is welcome to let their mind and body fall into a relaxing and rejuvenating yoga and meditation practice. All the sessions are led by certified instructors and everyone is welcome to come with experience or no experience.

Supplies are limited, so it is recommended to bring your own.

Penn State vs. UCLA Men’s Basketball

The Penn State men’s basketball team will play against UCLA at 8:30 p.m. in the Bryce Jordan Center.

Tickets can be found on Ticketmaster, with prices starting at $12.

Thursday, January 15

Success Starts Here

From 11 a.m-1 p.m. come enjoy some coffee and donuts at Penn State Chaiken Center in the Boucke Building. During this time students can meet the staff of the Chaiken Center and get some helpful tips and school supplies to kick off the semester.

Registration is required for this event.

Friday, January 16

Storytelling Game Night

From 5-7 p.m., the Print Factory Bellefonte will be hosting a storytelling game night. Each week a new game will be hosted where participants can create characters, worlds and stories together.

In addition to this event there is a collection of storytelling games for groups and individuals that is kept in the back room of the Print Factory Bellefonte and can be used if unoccupied.

Registration is not required for this event.

Penn State vs. Notre Dame Men’s Ice Hockey

The Penn State men’s ice hockey team will play against Notre Dame at 7 p.m. at the Pegula Ice Arena.

Tickets can be found on Ticketmaster starting at $40.

Saturday, January 17

Chess Club

The Bellefonte Chess Club will be meeting from 10 a.m.-noon at the Centre County Library and Historical Museum. The chess club is open to all people and all skill levels.

A chess instructor is available to teach guests how to play or to better improve their play. Registration is not required.

title: Penn State women’s basketball’s bigs struggle to find momentum in loss to Illinois
author: Sam Krasowitz | The Daily Collegian
description:
While Gracie Merkle has been one of the most impactful players for Penn State over the year and a half she has been in State College, that fact was amplified in Sunday’s loss against Illinois.

Despite a 24-point performance along with seven rebounds from the junior center and strong showings from other guards, weak second and fourth quarters allowed the Fighting Illini to defeat the Lady Lions 92-76.

While Merkle had her strong night on efficient 8-of-12 shooting while going 80% from the free-throw line, being on the bench during key points of the game hurt the Lady Lions, with little help from those who were subbing in for her. Backups Maggie Mendelson and Rachel Okokoh combined for just three points and five rebounds in 19 total minutes, while Merkle put up her numbers in 20.

While the scoring numbers were not there from the backup bigs, players like Kiyomi McMiller and Nyla McFadden helped lead the way in Merkle’s absence with 19 and 12 points, respectively.

“We have two different versions of Penn State women’s basketball,” Coach Carolyn Kieger said. “When Gracie Merkle is in the game, who is the most efficient low block scorer in the country. Then we have our other lineup that creates scoring in different ways.”

Merkle was just one of three players with a positive plus-minus, as the Lady Lions outscored Illinois by five with her on the court. Mendelson and Okokoh had a combined -14, giving up multiple runs and eventually allowing the Fighting Illini to close out the game.

Merkle’s early fouls put Penn State in this position, picking up her first two early in the first and second quarter, followed by two straight that left her sidelined for most of the third. Mendelson and Okokoh quickly substituted in and out for each other, neither finding a rhythm or making a strong impact defensively, leading to Illinois’ 92-point performance.

Merkle played just 20 minutes while her fellow stars McMiller and Moriah Murray played 40 and 36, respectively.

“(Merkle) has to stay out of foul trouble. I loved today that she was 8-for-10 from the line. She’s been working really hard on her free throws, but we have to keep her on the floor and (she) has to be disciplined for her teammates,” Kieger said.

One bright spot for Kieger’s squad in Sunday’s contest was turnovers. While it averaged 20.4 turnovers and it was an area of struggle last year, it only committed 11 against Illinois and even won the turnover battle.

However, strong shooting from Illinois and the absence of Merkle’s presence contributed to the Lady Lions’ loss Sunday afternoon.

“We finally took care of the ball… We still got blown by. We forced 21 turnovers, but they shot almost 60% on our home floor, which isn’t going to win games,” Kieger said.

title: Report: Former Penn State TE Luke Reynolds transfers to Virginia Tech
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
One of Penn State’s departures is joining his former head coach down south.

Luke Reynolds is transferring to Virginia Tech, per Pete Thamel of ESPN on Sunday. He will join James Franklin there for his first year with the Hokies.

Reynolds will also join his former tight ends coach Ty Howle, who accepted the Virginia Tech offensive coordinator job.

The tight end will be a junior in 2026 after appearing in every game throughout his first two collegiate seasons at Penn State. In those two seasons, Reynolds had 35 catches for 368 yards and one touchdown.

Reynolds is best known for his fake punt conversion against Minnesota in 2024, which helped Penn State seal that win en route to a College Football Playoff berth.

Following Tyler Warren’s departure to the NFL, many believed Reynolds would fill his shoes nicely in 2025, but that didn’t necessarily pan out despite a few good games at the beginning of the season.

“It was pretty tough, obviously, when everything went down,” Reynolds said of Franklin’s firing on Oct. 29. “But coach Franklin always told us about a six second mentality. One day at a time, all this kind of stuff. So just to honor him, I think I've just been trying to be really intentional with putting my feelings aside and just trying to get better as a person.”

title: Reinvigorated defense leads Penn State men’s hockey to sweep of Minnesota
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Despite a fair amount of early-season success, Penn State men’s hockey entered its mid-season break in search of an identity and consistency.

As part of that search, coach Guy Gadowsky implored his defense to “step up” and make a greater impact during games.

“We used to get a ton of production from our defense, and we want to get back to that,” Gadowsky said.

This weekend against Minnesota, his sentiment came to fruition. Penn State’s defense controlled the Golden Gophers on both ends of the ice and led the Nittany Lions to the first home sweep of their rival since 2019.

Gadowsky mainly hoped to see the defenders contribute more in the offensive zone, a feat which they accomplished this weekend. Prior to the last two games, Jackson Smith marked the only back-end starter consistently setting off the goal light. Smith continued to shine against Minnesota, scoring a goal on a wrist shot on Sunday.

His surge coincides with a change of approach from his defensive partner, Jarod Crespo, who put his name on the stat sheet more this series as well, accounting for eight shots on goal in the series.

“I think (Crespo) and Smith have a really good thing going,” Gadowsky said. “They’re playing with a lot of synergy.”

Cade Christenson, returning from injury, became the other defenseman to notch one into the net this weekend and seemed to’ve been the key to figuring out Penn State's defensive pairings.

Christenson missed the first half due to an injury, but his size and playmaking, when available, transformed the Nittany Lions’ defense's style over two Big Ten games.

“Just because of his presence, he brings confidence to the team,” Gadowsky said. “He keeps getting better every period, so I can’t wait for the next game.”

Overall, Penn State’s defense contributed 28 shots on net against Minnesota. However, their play in their own end was the real catalyst for an impressive weekend.

The Golden Gophers only scored two goals against the Penn State goaltenders, and while Josh Fleming and Kevin Reidler each made their marks, the D-Line's performance made their jobs easier than they’d been this season. For Reidler, he faced more shots than Fleming, but with a lot of help in front by his defenders.

“It’s always hard when you don’t have a lot to do,” Reidler said. “I prefer games like today, more fun, more space.”

The defenders who didn’t put up offensive numbers were running the paint in the defensive end, matching Minnesota’s physicality and blocking lanes throughout the weekend.

Christenson’s defensive partner, Mac Gadowsky, emerged chief among them, blocking 4 shots in Sunday’s game. He and Nolan Collins used their size and physical prowess to check a Minnesota team that came out swinging after Saturday’s shutout.

“We knew they were coming out ahead, and it was a bit of a wake-up call.” Lev Katzin said. “It took us a little while to get to that, but once we were there, they couldn’t play with us.”

Carter Schade stood as the final player making a tangible impact, contributing multiple breakout passes between the zones throughout the games and staying in front of Reidler throughout Sunday’s contest.

Schade single-handedly fended off multiple rebound opportunities and tip-ins by staying physical in the paint.

“(Schade) was a single breakout machine,” Gadowsky said. “Not only did he play physical like he always does, but he skated the puck well.”

The healthy defensive core allowed Penn Star to control the game and play relaxed, which kept them out of the penalty box. The Nittany Lions only spent 12 minutes in the Penalty box, with just 10 of those being penalty-killing minutes.

Penn State’s defense guided the identity that the Nittany Lions struggled to establish in the first half. Continued performances like the one the core put up against Minnesota will be a key in the blue and white’s quest to return to the Frozen Four this spring.

“Our whole defensive core has been solid back there,” Luke Misa said. “It’s just good to have all of them back there.”

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's gymnastics defeats Army in season opener
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s gymnastics began its 2026 season with a familiar foe in Army, as the Nittany Lions faced the Black Knights seventeen times now, and won every single contest.

The blue and white began this season and last against Army, and while last year’s contest marked the closest in margin in over five years. Yet this season, Penn State triumphed 311.300-297.600, in a win where it increased the margin of victory to one of the largest in recent meetings.

On the floor, the blue and white narrowly won in Rec Hall, with a 51.500-49.900 score. Every participating athlete scored below 13, except Penn State’s Shaun Smith and Matthew Underhill, who helped pull the blue and white into the lead.

On the pommel horse, the trend of narrow wins continued. Maddox Pabellon led the Army’s efforts on the day and in the event, with a highest score of 13.850, yet couldn’t top the Penn State unit.

The run is where Penn State pulled ahead, with a six-point differential on the rings. Underhill once again reached the 13-point threshold, joined by Luke Esparo, while no Army gymnasts reached such a figure.

The vault is where Army posted a much more consistent score, yet Penn State’s pair of 14-point scores by Underhill and Kellen Ryan saw it again edge out the Black Knights. On the parallel bars, the Nittany Lions again won the event, with Esparo, Kacper Garnczarek and Eliran Ioscovich all reaching 13 points. Not one Black Knights gymnast reached such a feat, putting the clean sweep in play for Penn State.

The horizontal bar saw Penn State complete its string of dominance with a sweep, as it again won by a four-point margin. Ryan led the way with a high score in the event with 13.200.

Up next

The blue and white face Army again, this time on their turf, when the Black Knights host the West Point Open from Jan. 16 to 17, with multiple participating schools. Last year, the Nittany Lions opened their season at this event and finished second.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball fails to upset Illinois, loses 6th straight
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State returned home to the Bryce Jordan Center for the third and final time this season as it looked for its first win in conference play.

Despite the fuller-than-normal arena, the Lady Lions failed to pull off the upset, losing to Illinois 92-76.

After winning the tipoff, the Lady Lions commanded the floor and took advantage of the full shot clock, working the ball around the court before Kiyomi McMiller got her first basket with seconds left on the clock.

Penn State’s defense stood strong on its first drive down the court as Shaelyn Steele forced a steal. However, it didn’t have an answer for Berry Wallace, who scored eight straight points for Illinois.

Freshman Tèa Clèante came on the court following a foul and instantly made a mark, putting the blue and white up by two.

Despite standing at 6-foot-5, the Fighting Illini targeted Maggie Mendelson on back-to-back plays, adding another four points to their score.

As Wallace continued to score, totaling 12 points through the first quarter, Penn State went silent, going nearly three minutes without any action. However, the script flipped at the end of the first period, as Illinois went three minutes without scoring while the Lady Lions brought it to a one-point game.

Moriah Murray opened the second quarter with a triple, followed by another score from Wallace to tie things up at 23.

After Cleante missed a shot, she capitalized on the following drive on defense with a steal and score to ignite a 6-0 Penn State run, capped off with McMiller’s 11th point of the game.

However, the Fighting Illini came back even stronger with an 11-0 run of their own, holding the Lady Lions scoreless for over four minutes.

Penn State struggled through the final minutes of the first half, scoring just 12 points in the quarter as Illinois extended its lead to 11 points.

Both teams turned the ball over to start the second half before Gracie Merkle used her 6-foot-6 frame in the paint to earn her first and-one of the game.

However, Wallace came back just as strong in the second half, scoring her third triple to record 20 points, which Nyla McFadden quickly negated with another Penn State and-one.

After turnovers were a big issue through the first two months of the season, the Lady Lions kept the ball under control against Illinois, recording only 11 turnovers as they created more scoring opportunities.

Merkle’s fouls were an issue, however, as she got her fourth foul with nearly 15 minutes left to play, limiting her time on the court through the rest of the period.

Despite playing strong defense in the paint, the Lady Lions struggled to guard the 3-point line, often leaving Illinois players open, including 6-foot-3 Cearah Parchment, who drained a triple to make it a seven-point game.

The Fighting Illini ended the third quarter on a strong 9-2 run, and that momentum carried into the start of the final period, going 4-0 to start the fourth quarter.

While Merkle scored her fifth shot in the paint and Murray her second triple of the day, the Lady Lions couldn’t stop the bleeding as Illinois made it a 20-point game with six minutes left.

As both teams scored, including Merkle, who reached 20 points on the day, Penn State ultimately fell, remaining winless in conference play and moving to 7-10 on the year.

Up Next

The Lady Lions travel to Columbus to face No. 19 Ohio State at 6:30 p.m. on Wednesday.

Injury Report

Penn State listed Amiya Evans on the Big Ten availability report.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Iowa State DB Jeremiah Cooper transfers to Penn State
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
Snow squall? Nah, Cyclone.

Matt Campbell continues to pluck his former roster in the transfer portal, this time it’s defensive back Jeremiah Cooper, who announced his commitment on Sunday.

Cooper played four seasons at Iowa State, totaling 138 tackles and eight interceptions.

In three of those seasons he played safety, but he moved to cornerback for 2025. He only participated in four games in his new role, though, as he used his redshirt after a season-ending knee injury.

His best season came in 2023, being named to the coaches first team All-Big 12 after tallying five picks and 15 pass defenses on the year.

description:
The Virginia Tech Nittany Lions.

According to a report from Pete Nakos of On3, former Penn State defensive end Mylachi Williams is transferring to Virginia Tech.

Williams will reunite with James Franklin, heading to Blacksburg after two seasons with the Nittany Lions.

Williams is the third former Penn State defensive end to join the Hokies, as he'll reunite with Cortez Harris and Daniel Jennings.

title: Penn State women's gymnastics defeats Yale to open season
author: Sami Altmire | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State women’s gymnastics was back in Rec Hall on Sunday, taking on Yale. The Nittany Lions looked to start off the season strong with a roster that added a lot of depth with new recruits Kayla Bender, Ava Cash, Saidat Omilabu, and Lizzy Ryan.

The season started off strong with the Nittany Lions getting an overall score of 196.225 compared to the Yale Bulldogs score of 193.850.

Rotation One

Penn State started off on vault, and ended with a comfortable 49.000, putting it just ahead of the Bulldogs, who got a score of 48.575 on their first rotation.

Elizabeth Leary opened successfully, landing with no issue, giving her 9.750 to start off the scoring for the blue and white.

Cash opened her season with a successful twist, and with a confident stick, she added a score of 9.850, leading vault scoring so far.

Allison Kaempfer was just behind Cash with a score of 9.825, Jessica Johanson with a 9.800, Ava Piedrahita scored 9.775, Bella Misiura ended with a 9.650, Dani Latronica grabbed a score of 9.750, and Ellie Monahan ended up rotation one with a score of 9.700.

Rotation Two

The blue and white headed to its strong suit: the uneven bars. It landed a score of 49.125, which put it in a comfortable decision. Monahan opened for Penn State, who started off strong with a score of 9.775. Johanson was next and brought a score of 9.750.

Kaempfer and Latronica came in hot with scores of 9.825, and Leary and Cash led the rotation, both with a score of 9.850.

Rotation Three

The Nittany Lions headed to beam and scored a total of 48.950 on beam, with both Monahan and Latronica leading with scores of 9.825. With her score, Monahan topped her 2025 beam score of 9.800.

Alyssa Kramer and Ashley Maul both started off their scoring on beam, and both grabbed a 9.775.

Kalea McElligott followed with a score of 9.750, and Amani Herring scored a 9.725.

Rotation Four

Floor was the last event of the afternoon for the Nittany Lions and they opened with Leary and, minus a step off the mat, her routine got a score of 9.650 to start off the rotation.

Monahan nailed her routine, scoring a 9.800, and Maul followed, also scoring a 9.800. Misiura took home a score of 9.775

Kramer got a strong 9.875, and McElligot finished off for Penn State and led the scoring on floor with a 9.900.

Floor ended and gave the blue and white a strong start to the season, taking a win over the Bulldogs of 196.225-193.850.

Up Next

Penn State takes on Illinois in Champaign, Illinois, at 8 p.m. Friday.

title: 'Really grateful that I got to compete tonight' | Josh Barr returns to form, beats high school teammate
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
Josh Barr had an eventful offseason that saw him recover from an injury at the end of last season. He then suffered a rib injury late in the summer at the U23 World Championships.

It was unknown how long Barr would be out after missing the start of the season, but now, he’s back to seemingly full strength.

Barr made his return to Rec Hall on Saturday, making his home-dual debut to open up conference play against Rutgers.

“Yeah, I didn’t feel well, but it’s one of those things just trying to keep it cool, and obviously we have a really good trainer here from back home,” Barr said.

Once Barr made it back to the United States, it was all recovery in preparation for the collegiate season.

He didn’t start the season, instead it was Connor Mirasola, who started and showcased his abilities, before Barr returned and proved why he was the preseason No. 1 wrestler at 197 pounds.

“Once we got back, we got right through it with (trainer Daniel Monthley) and doing everything that we could, and trusting in the Lord’s timing for my career, my life and it was good,” Barr said.

The redshirt sophomore returned to the mat at the Collegiate Wrestling Duals in early December, where he dominated to victories. In those matches, he was wearing a more protective singlet that kept his upper body covered up due to the rib injury.

However, in his first match of 2026, Barr was back to his regular singlet, showcasing he’s back to full strength.

“I feel great. It was good. It was tough,” Barr said. “Just really fired up for the rest of the season, really excited and more grateful than ever. When you don’t get to compete for a while and need to go out there and wrestle in Rec Hall, it makes you really grateful.”

Barr’s first matchup of the calendar year wasn’t like most. He wrestled his high school teammate, Remy Cotton. Barr and Cotton both wrestled at Davison High School, where the two combined for five state titles.

The Nittany Lion wrestled in four weight classes in high school, and faced off daily against Cotton, bringing the two back to the good ole’ days.

In the rematch of the daily scraps, Barr dominated to an 18-3 tech fall in a weight class neither wrestled at in high school.

“I had told one of our coaches there, I probably spent more time wrestling him than anybody my whole life,” Barr said.

When two wrestlers face off that often, it often leads to close matches. However, Barr continued to prove he’s the top wrestler at 197 pounds, withholding his top ranking which he received at the beginning of the season.

“He’s my partner, like main partner for four years straight,” Barr said. “So, it was cool to be able to do it in Rec Hall, Rutgers vs. Penn State and really grateful that I got to compete tonight, and it’s pretty cool to do it against an old teammate.”

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Aiden Fink becomes fastest Nittany Lion to reach 100 point mark
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
During Saturday’s Penn State men’s hockey game, Aiden Fink became the ninth men’s Nittany Lion to reach the 100 career point milestone.

Fink is the fastest player in program history to reach the marker, doing so in his 87th game, and the first to do so in under 100 career games.

He surpassed Alex Limoges' record of 102 career games with his point in Penn State's game against Minnesota.

He reached the point on an assist to Jackson Smith’s third-period goal. He added point No. 101 just moments later.

Fink's three assists led Penn State to a sweep of Minnesota to begin 2026.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Fink tallies 100th point as No. 9 Penn State men's hockey tops Minnesota
author: Greg Finberg | The Daily Collegian
description:
It was a miserable start to conference play for Penn State last season — one that took Guy Gadowsky’s squad 20 tries to win its sixth Big Ten contest.

Just 10 games into this season’s Big Ten schedule, the No. 9 Nittany Lions have matched that mark after defeating Minnesota 5-2 to complete the series sweep and improve to 14-6-0, 6-4-0 Big Ten.

It marked the program’s first home sweep of the Golden Gophers since 2019 — a feat Gadowsky lauded postgame.

“Anytime you sweep in the Big Ten, you've got to be thrilled,” Gadowsky said. “Great weekend.”

After Josh Fleming starred Friday in Penn State’s 3-0 victory, Kevin Reidler started Game 2 as Gadowsky continued to split starting goaltender duties. Reese Laubach joined JJ Wiebusch and Matt DiMarsico’s line with Charlie Cerrato sidelined after exiting Friday’s contest with an injury.

Penn State applied early pressure, but it was the Golden Gophers who struck first when Brodie Ziemer found himself on a breakaway before he fired a wrist shot beyond Reidler’s blocker. After a scoreless Game 1, Minnesota had tallied less than four minutes into Saturday’s contest.

Brodie Ziemer puts @GopherHockey on the board first 💥📺: @BigTenNetwork pic.twitter.com/eUJ8smoTx1— Big Ten Hockey (@B1GHockey) January 10, 2026

But it didn’t take long for the Nittany Lions to respond.

With his back to the offensive zone inside his own blue line, Gavin McKenna cleverly played a between-the-legs feed to a streaking Braeden Ford, who dangled from his forehand to his backhand before beating Nathan Airey five-hole to tie the game.

Great feed, better finish!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/MWB6UeC6rR— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 10, 2026

After extended zone time led to several point-blank chances for the Golden Gophers, it was Penn State’s turn in the offensive zone. And unlike Minnesota, the Nittany Lions converted.

Airey denied Aiden Fink’s wrist shot, but he left the rebound to an awaiting DiMarsico, who tapped it home to ignite the Pegula Ice Arena crowd.

DD Doesn't Miss!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/augBL24LVv— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 10, 2026

Airey’s rebound-control issues didn’t stop there. With 16 seconds remaining in the opening frame, Minnesota’s netminder denied Ben Schoen’s initial shot but again failed to cover the puck. This time, it was Lev Katzin who tapped the puck into the open net for his first collegiate goal.

Gadowsky called Katzin “a hell of a guy.” He said when Katzin was awarded the hammer, which is given to a standout player after a Penn State victory, the freshman forward instead gave it to Ford.

“It's not easy to be in (Ford’s) position, in and out of the lineup, and he always works his bag off no matter what,” Katzin said. “He's so positive on the bench, and he's just such a great team guy. And to see him go down, as one of my best buddies on the team, was hard. I thought he deserved (the hammer) more than myself tonight.”

LEV GETS ON THE BOARD!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/NGvpBuVl3O— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 10, 2026

Minnesota coach Bob Motzko pulled Airey in favor of Luca Di Pasquo to open the second frame. And nearly three minutes in, it was Di Pasquo’s save that ignited a Golden Gophers 2-on-1 break.

Off a perfectly weighted cross-ice feed from Teddy Townsend, Javon Moore sniped a one-timer past Reidler’s outstretched glove to make it 3-2.

Give us MOORE 🤩📺: BTN pic.twitter.com/WAa28NEAQ0— Minnesota Men’s Hockey (@GopherHockey) January 10, 2026

DiMarsico nearly doubled Penn State’s advantage halfway through the second period when he beat Di Pasquo amid a net-front scrum. But after a lengthy review, the officials determined there was goaltender interference, thus wiping the Nittany Lions’ tally off the board.

Gadowsky said he was told by officials that although DiMarsico was pushed into the netminder, it was still goaltender interference.

“I don't know what to tell you,” Gadowsky said. “I can't tell you what is goaltender interference and what isn't.”

Momentum temporarily flipped when Ford was booked for hooking before seconds later injuring his left foot following a post-whistle check. Minnesota threatened, but Reidler flashed the leather several times to preserve his team’s narrow lead entering the final period.

Reidler’s standout play continued past the second intermission. The 6-foot-6 netminder made multiple pad saves throughout a barrage of offensive-zone turnovers as the Nittany Lions clung to a one-goal advantage — a peppering of shots he said plays to his advantage.

“Facing a lot of shots helps you stay in the game,” Reidler said. “ It's hard when you don't have a lot to do. But I definitely prefer games like this (that are) more fun, (have) more space.”

Minnesota had tilted the ice in its favor since the second period, but Gadowsky's squad never wavered. And after Penn State again emerged unscathed from a barrage of Golden Gophers scoring opportunities, Jackson Smith iced his team’s 14th victory with fifth goal of the campaign.

A SMITTY SNIPE!!!!!#WeAre #HockeyValley pic.twitter.com/l9wZ0MvuVu— Penn State Men’s Hockey (@PennStateMHKY) January 11, 2026

Fink’s assist on Smith’s tally marked his 100th career point, becoming just the ninth skater in program history to reach that milestone.

“It talks a lot of the offensive success that (Fink) has had,” Gadowsky said. “He's a skilled guy, but he works really hard, gives a lot of himself every game. And when you work as hard as he does, good things happen.”

Dane Dowiak added an empty-net goal in the final seconds to put the finishing touches on a 32-save performance from Reidler and a 5-2 Penn State win.

Up Next

Penn State returns at 7 p.m. Friday to Pegula Ice Arena to face Notre Dame for the first of two games.

Injury Report

Ford exited in the second period after taking a big hit along the boards. He was helped off the ice by his teammates but couldn’t put any weight on his left foot.

title: 2 Penn State players make NFL All-Pro 1st team
