title: Penn State long snapper Tyler Duzansky declares for NFL draft
author: Avery Hill | Football Editor
description:
It’s a snap into a new chapter.

Penn State long snapper Tyler Duzansky has announced he’ll enter the NFL draft.

Thank you Penn State 💙🤍 pic.twitter.com/LZzaoE7MNA— Tyler Duzansky (@DuzanskyTyler) January 10, 2026

Duzansky spent five seasons in Happy Valley, becoming the team’s lead snapper in 2023.

“Obviously it took a couple more years than expected,” Duzansky said in November. “But just got to trust God that everything happens for a reason.”

His final season was his most fruitful, being selected as a finalist for the Patrick Mannelly Award, the honor for the best long snapper in the country.

In addition, he helped punter Gabe Nwosu and Ryan Barker have successful seasons, with Barker most notably setting the program record for single-season field goal percentage at 94.7%.

The Wheaton, Illinois, native will now look for the chance to become the second active Penn State snapper in the NFL, with his predecessor Chris Stoll being the other.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: No. 1 Penn State wrestling continues dominance, shuts out No. 16 Rutgers in first Big Ten dual of season
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 1 Penn State wrestling opened 2026 at Rec Hall against Rutgers Saturday. The match turned from a dual that could’ve been fairly competitive turned one-sided as the Scarlet Knights didn’t wrestle multiple starters against the Nittany Lions.

Penn State defeated Rutgers 46-0 behind three pinfalls by the heart of the lineup.

125: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl vs No. 29 Ayden Smith

Luke Lilledahl started chasing Smith around from the start, securing the first takedown just one minute into the bout. After that, Smith stalled his way through the rest of the first period, at one point comically dancing along the edge of the mat while tangled up with Lilledahl.

The trend continued through the second period after Lilledahl escaped from the down position. The ref finally gave Lilledahl a stall point 90 seconds into the frame. Lilledahl secured one last takedown in the third, but let Smith up to chase another one before hitting one minute of riding time. Lilledahl took an 8-3 decision.

Penn State 3, Rutgers 0

133: No. 5 Marcus Blaze vs No. 24 Dylan Shawver

Marcus Blaze tested himself against an All-American in the form of Dylan Shawver. Neither man got the other to move throughout the first frame. Shawver nearly reversed Blaze in frame two, but it ended up as just an escape. Blaze secured the first takedown of the match after that by spinning around Shawver at the speed of light. He passed one minute of riding time before the frame expired.

Blaze extended his lead into major decision territory with two third-period takedowns, and Rec Hall erupted for the true freshman after his 12-2 victory.

Penn State 7, Rutgers 0

141: Braeden Davis vs Tahir Perkins

Braeden Davis returned to the lineup for Penn State for the first time since it was announced that he’d redshirt for the 2025-26 season.

Davis returned to the mat for Penn State for the first time this season after Aaron Nagao went down with another injury. Davis burned his redshirt to compete against Tahir Perkins.

Davis looked like he hadn’t lost a step wrestling unattached; he took down Perkins three times in round one. The second round was slower, with just an escape from Perkins after Davis crossed two minutes of riding time. Davis notched two more takedowns to secure the 18-7 major decision victory in his return.

Penn State 11, Rutgers 0

149: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness vs Devon Magro

Shayne Van Ness continued the trend of moving quickly, getting two takedowns in the first half of the first period. After that takedown, Van Ness managed to flip Magro, momentarily holding him down and securing four nearfall points. Van Ness racked up twelve points and 1:15 of riding time when the whistle blew on the round.

Van Ness turned Magro over again in round two, this time hooking his neck and after a twenty-second struggle, secured the pin.

Penn State 17, Rutgers 0

157: PJ Duke vs Easton Doster

PJ Duke took on 4-0 Easton Doster. Duke notched the first takedown nine seconds into the match. He kept the pace up, notching three more in the following minute, but tallying barely any riding time. Duke continued to let Doster back up in search of a techfall, which he successfully earned after his first takedown of round two, winning 19-4.

Penn State 22, Rutgers 0

165: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink vs Ryan Ford

Ryan Ford shocked the crowd by securing the first takedown against Mitchell Mesenbrink, without Mesenbrink visually leaving his feet. Mesenbrink responded with a takedown of his own seconds later, securing four nearfall points while Ford’s face turned red in his arms. Mesenbrink got another four-point nearfall before hooking Ford’s leg and finishing the first-round fall.

Penn State 28, Rutgers 0

174: No. 1 Levi Haines vs Jordan Chapman

Levi Haines immediately lifted Jordan Chapman into the air, which set the tone for a dominant victory. He secured a quick first takedown and a second one before Chapman entered concussion protocol with 25 seconds on the clock. Chapman returned a couple of minutes later to complete the bout.

The return didn’t bode well for Chapman, as after two more takedowns, Haines secured Penn State’s third pinfall of the day.

Penn State 34, Rutgers 0

184: No. 4 Rocco Welsh vs No. 15 Shane Cartagena-Walsh

Rocco Welsh proved he is in the upper tier of the 184 weight class against Shane Cartegena-Walsh. Welsh secured three first-period takedowns, leading Cartagena-Welsh to stall throughout the second period. Welsh received a stall point in round three to win 13-3.

Penn State 38, Rutgers 0

197: No. 1 Josh Barr vs No. 18 Remy Cotton

Josh Barr wrestled in his first home match of the season against Remy Cotton, walking out to his signature “I Love It” by Icona Pop. His match matched the energy of the music, as he nearly pinned Cotton in the first period. Barr led 7-0 as time expired.

After an escape in round two, Barr took down Cotton again and looked to turn Cotton after grabbing his leg, but the referee called it off for head danger.

After another takedown and another danger call, Barr elected to let Cotton stand up, leading 14-3 in the third to hunt for a tech fall. He secured it with a final takedown and riding time, winning 18-3.

Penn State 43, Rutgers 0

285: No. 15 Cole Mirasola vs No. 21 Hunter Catka

Cole Mirasola stepped to the mat last, looking to secure the shutout in the closest match on paper of the evening. The first period lived up to that billing, with no points awarded for either man.

Mirasola quickly escaped in the second period and nearly got taken down with 45 seconds to go, but quickly latched onto Catka’s calf to land a stalemate call.

It took just three seconds for Catka to escape in round three, and Mirasola took control to launch a takedown that blew the roof off of Rec Hall. Catka stood up with 40 seconds on the clock and failed to return the takedown. Mirasola took the final bout 4-2.

Penn State 46, Rutgers 0.

Up Next

Penn State takes a road trip to Iowa and Northwestern next Friday and Sunday.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball opens 2-0 after Saturday matinee sweep over Manhattan
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State won its opening match against Mount Olive last night, kicking off a new season with a 3-1 victory.

This afternoon, the Nittany Lions moved upstairs to the South Gym to take on Manhattan as the wrestling team occupied the main gym in Rec Hall.

In the second match of Mark Pavlik’s final season at the helm, it was No. 13 Penn State that left the smaller court with the win, earning a 3-0 victory.

The blue and white quickly scored two points in the first set, but the Jaspers struck back thanks to a couple of service errors and a nifty kill that put six points on the board for each team.

Points were traded back and forth for most of the first set, with Penn State’s Sean Harvey responsible for four points off of kills halfway through the set.

A Carter Dittman ace made it 17-14 in the Nittany Lions’ favor, but Manhattan was closing in with back-to-back kills that tightened the contest.

The Jaspers were forced to take a timeout down 22-18 with the set slipping away from them.

Manhattan’s attack efforts brought it closer, but it just wasn’t enough, and Penn State won the first set 25-21.

The second set started the same way with the two sides trading blows, but the Jaspers got up to an early 3-2 lead after a pair of kills from Kasen Owens and Max Larcheid an error on a Penn State serve.

The 6-foot-7 Harvey earned another kill to make it a 7-4 advantage and in the process, picked up his sixth kill of the afternoon, still in the early stages of the second set.

Penn State put an end to Manhattan’s gaining momentum thanks to a service error and an attack error that put the blue and white up 18-13 with the end of the second set in sight.

Once again, the Jaspers took a timeout with a seven-point Nittany Lion advantage looking insurmountable.

Thanks to Dittman and Harvey earning another pair of kills and a Matthew Luoma service ace, Penn State captured the second set, stifling the Jaspers 25-16 as it inched one set closer to a sweep.

History repeats itself, and apparently so did each set. The third set started out with points coming in rapid succession for each squad until Manhattan eventually found itself on top with a 6-5 advantage, thanks to Penn State’s Owen Rose missing the mark for an attack error.

Penn State jumped back up 10-8, though, after back-to-back plays from Gabriel Gaige to force an attack error from Larcheid, he then followed up with a kill.

Some more back-and-forth play saw consecutive Chase Marston aces that allowed the Jaspers to tie it at 12 points a piece, but six consecutive errors let Penn State jump back up to a 17-14 advantage.

Manhattan once again took a timeout after falling into a 19-14 hole after back-to-back Harvey kills, which put him up to 14 on the afternoon on 16 total attempts.

The Jaspers tightened it up right at the end but just couldn’t catch the Nittany Lions as they captured the third set 25-20 to sweep Manhattan and cap off its opening weekend with a 2-0 record.

Up Next

Penn State is back in action when it returns to Rec Hall’s main gym at 7 p.m. on Thursday to take on St. Thomas Aquinas.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s basketball suffers another close loss to ranked opponent at hands of No. 5 Purdue
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State hit the road, continuing its three-game ranked-opponent stretch and leaving Pennsylvania for the first time in five games, as No. 5 Purdue served as the worthy foe.

The Nittany Lions entered banged up, both mentally and physically, suffering back-to-back heartbreaking close defeats to then-No. 20 Illinois and No. 2 Michigan, in a stretch where they also didn’t play at full strength.

With those absences, the blue and white trudged out a first unit against Purdue that resembled little of the other starting fives previously this season. Earning the nod for Mike Rhoades’ squad were Freddie Dilione V, Dom Stewart, Eli Rice, Josh Reed and Ivan Juric.

That group all appeared in starting roles before, though not together, as the No. 4 KenPom and Evan Miya-rated Boilermakers pose a daunting task that almost all statistical formulas, media voters and analysts note as a top-five team in the nation.

For the Nittany Lions, only one of its rostered players appeared in West Lafayette before Saturday, Sasa Ciani, and the forward didn’t crack the starting lineup, let alone appear in the contest, until Penn State endured a Purdue scoring run.

The Nittany Lions earned the first bucket of the game, courtesy of a Rice three pointer, and fought back against everything that Purdue offered. At the midpoint of the first, only a score separated the two schools.

Yet, almost all of the Boilermakers’ offensive effort, Braden Smith orchestrated behind his game-high 10 points, which were double his next-highest teammate and triple the highest Penn State scorer.

Smith typically isn’t a primary scorer for Purdue; his 9.5 assists entering against the Nittany Lions were an NCAA-leading figure, and pace him to challenge Bobby Hurley’s collegiate assist record.

Penn State’s offense, in which all but Stewart scored by the ten-minute mark of the first half, showed a collective effort that hung in there and prevented either team from pulling ahead.

Jurić notched tough, physical buckets in the paint and stood out with a game-high five rebounds, as his play started to decide the tempo for the Nittany Lions.

When the first half closed down, Purdue led 45-44, and repelled every single answer Penn State answered with on offense with its own Boilermakers score. For the blue and white, it looked solid but needed a little more to take the lead, especially on defense.

Smith led scoring at the half for either squad with 17 points, and also supplied seven assists. Reed, Rice and Tunca all tied for eight points at the half on perfect shooting for Penn State, only trailing Dilione, who led the blue and white with a single point more.

Both squads nearly shot 60%, but the Nittany Lions held a five-point advantage in 3-point percentage.

Smith started the second half on fire, contributing both with playmaking and scoring to a 10-3 run, which gave Purdue its largest lead of the game with the score at 55-47.

No. 2 Michigan, which Penn State took down to the wire only four days ago, suffered a crushing defeat at the hands of Wisconsin, while the Nittany Lions were actively attempting to pull off such an upset against the Boilermakers. Yet Purdue continued to pull away, as the lead grew to ten.

Smith reached a twenty-point double-double performance, joined by three other Boilermakers who reached double-digit scoring as the last ten-minute mark approached. Despite the efficient Penn State team-wide offensive approach in the first half, only Tunca and Dilione reached double-digit scoring at this point.

Both squads stood relatively evenly matched in how those buckets came, except Penn State’s large advantage in scoring off the bench. Marginally better scoring efficiency and turnover rates helped the Boilermakers obtain their lead, however.

That trend continued, with Purdue routinely snagging off blue and white passes and translating on the other end not just with fast break buckets, but with and-ones.

Purdue’s lead extended to 14 through its defensive hot streak, and it looked to cruise to victory barring any major Penn State run. The Nittany Lions' only highlight came from a Dilione downtown stepback to cut the lead to nine.

The Nittany Lions ultimately couldn’t pull that run out, as they fell 93-85, giving Penn State a winless conference record after five Big Ten games.

Dilione finished with a team-high 25 points on 50% shooting, while Rice and Tunca followed in double digits, with the team shooting efficient marks. Stewart, despite shooting 0-for-4 from the field and leading Penn State in fouls, also posted the best plus-minus rating.

For Purdue, Smith finished with 26 points and 14 assists, while fellow starter Oscar Cluff followed with 23 points, only missing one shot.

Availability Report

Penn State listed Kayden Mingo out again for the contest against Purdue, the second straight game the Farmingdale, New York native missed, and Mike Rhoades said he’d be out for “some time,” giving no exact timeline on return, in line with Pennsylvania state regulations.

Joining Mingo on the report was Tibor Mirtić, who entered as out against Purdue, marking the first game of the season in which the forward missed.

Rounding out the lengthiest Availability Report of the season for Penn State is Reggie Grodin, who already reportedly will use his redshirt.

Up Next

After facing three consecutive ranked opponents, the Nittany Lions host UCLA at the BJC on Wednesday, Jan 14, at 8:30 p.m. The Bruins are 10-5 overall and 2-2 in the Big Ten, placing them in the middle of the pack in the conference and just inside the top-40 in KenPom's ratings.

title: No. 4 Penn State loses to Mercyhurst with a nailbiter 4-3 overtime contest
author: Steven Pavelka | The Daily Collegian
description:
The No. 4 Nittany Lions returned to Mercyhurst Ice Center Saturday with a chance to sweep their conference series against in-state rival Mercyhurst in their fourth meeting of the season. After a rebounding shutout win in their last matchup, Penn State wants to keep the momentum going.

The White and Blue dropped its third game out of the last four to Mercyhurst in a 4-3 overtime loss. A game that was tied for the majority of its duration, the Lakers won with only 13 seconds left.

Mercyhurst started off the game controlling the offensive pace while the Nittany Lions struggled to keep hold of the puck.

Tessa Janecke got sent to the box for tripping, marking her 76th career penalty and allowing the Lakers to keep offensive pressure during a power play.

Miscues hurt Penn State as Danica Maynard had a shot at an open goal but failed to receive the pass from Janecke, who returned from the box.

Strong defense and play from both goalies led to a stalemate early, as both teams struggled to generate high-percentage shots. The White and Blue have prioritized getting as many shots as possible up to this point, while Mercyhurst has been more selective.

While this game appeared cleaner in terms of penalties than their previous matchup, there is still noticeable chippiness from both teams, as Abby Stonehouse took a hard hit from a Mercyhurst Laker.

Mercyhurst had its first player, Maja Alenius, sent to the box for tripping, allowing the Nittany Lions to take a stronger offensive charge during the power play. The first period ended without a goal scored for either team.

The Nittany Lions broke open the second period with a quick Stonehouse backhand score down the center and Janecke on the assist to take the lead 1-0.

Penn State made a noticeable difference in their offensive approach, becoming the team controlling the offensive pressure in the second period, led by Janecke.

Stonehouse headed to the box for Penn State’s second tripping penalty of the day. Allowing a Laker power play. Followed by Maddy Christian and Abby Poitras exchanging some shoves shortly after.

Murcyhurst responded with a power play goal from Berlin Lolacher to tie up the game 1-1, but their celebration was cut short as Taylor Lum responded on the next possession with a goal of her own to give Penn State a 2-1 lead.

The extracurriculars continued in the game as Janecke exchanged some shoves of her own with another Laker skater, which continued the theme of chippiness.

As McKenna Walsh headed to the box for the Nittany Lions' third penalty of the day, Lolacher responded with her second goal of the day for Mercyhurst to tie the game up 2-2.

Mercyhurst’s Payten Evans got sent to the box for holding, which marked her third penalty of the season.

As the game headed into the third period tied up, both teams struggled to keep the puck in the attacking zone.

The Lakers entered a power play as Janecke entered the box for the second time on the day, this time for cross-checking. Mercyhurst tried to take advantage and found their third power-play goal of the day, but time and time again, they were denied by Maddy Campbell as she faced a plethora of shot attempts.

Jancke returns from the box and scores a magical angle shot in the corner that allowed Penn State to take a 3-2 lead with five minutes left to play.

Maddy Christian heads to the box for tripping, which gave the Lakers a power play with under two minutes in the game.

Mercyhurst’s Julia Schalin clapped back with a quick goal during the power play, which tied the game 3-3 and eventually sent the contest to overtime.

As the White and Blue headed into their first overtime of the season, they continued to keep offensive pressure on the Lakers with Janecke keeping the pace.

Magdalena Luggin continued to keep Mercyhurst alive as she saved 35 shots in goal for the Lakers. Payten Evans called game as she scored with 13 seconds left and a dominant push to the goal on Campbell. The score allowed the Lakers to pull out a nailbiter with a 4-3 victory.

Injury Report

Katie DeSa didn’t get listed in the lineup for the third-straight game. Matilde Fantin also wasn’t listed in the lineup for the second-straight game.

Up Next

Penn State heads to the Tennity Ice Pavilion to play Syracuse on January 16 and 17 in a back-to-back road series.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Former Penn State DE Chaz Coleman transfers to Tennessee, becomes 3rd Nittany Lion to do so
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A prolific Penn State portal entrant has found his new home.

Chaz Coleman is transferring to Tennessee, per Hayes Fawcett of On3.

The defensive end entered the transfer portal on Dec. 18, becoming a 5-star in the portal and the No. 1 edge rusher available. Coleman took visits to Ohio State and LSU along with the Volunteers.

Coleman appeared in nine games this season, missing three due to injury. He tallied eight tackles, three tackles for loss, a sack and a forced fumble.

The Ohio native will reunite with Xavier Gilliam, Amare Campbell, defensive coordinator Jim Knowles and assistant defensive line coach Andrew Jackson in Knoxville. He has three years of eligibility remaining.

“He’s crazy athletic, explosive, and for a freshman, he plays really hard,” Knowles said Aug. 12. “He’s that guy. He’s very mature for his age. He wants to learn. He doesn’t like making mistakes. He’s smart. He’s gonna be the guy that can help us.”

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s basketball to fight for first conference win against Illinois
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State is in the midst of a search for any sign of hope amid a five-game losing streak as it gets a chance to earn its first conference win.

The Lady Lions get that opportunity on Sunday when they host Illinois in the We Back Pat game in support of Alzheimer's awareness.

The Fighting Illini also arrive in the contest off a losing stretch, after falling against Maryland and Michigan State in their previous games, but upset No. 8 Maryland earlier this month, which gave the Terrapins their lone loss of the year so far.

While both teams struggled over the past two weeks, both also turned to their frontcourt for consistent success.

Gracie Merkle led the Lady Lions in scoring for most of the season. Up until mid-December, Merkle averaged over 20 points per game.

However, the 6-foot-6 center has also led the nation in efficiency from the court with 75.1% shooting, making her a reliable target anywhere in the paint.

In the Illinois starting lineup, however, is 6-foot-1 forward Berry Wallace, the sister of former Penn State forward Bexley Wallace.

Wallace consistently ranks among the Fighting Illini's top scorers this season, averaging 18.1 points per game, including eight 20-plus-point games.

The last time the two squads matched up, the Lady Lions fell 67-55 at Illinois. However, the blue and white get the privilege of home-court advantage on Sunday, playing at the Bryce Jordan Center.

In the team’s two previous games at the BJC this year, it suffered devastating losses to Nebraska and Arizona State, falling by a combined 32 points.

While Merkle and Kiyomi McMiller both provide the Lady Lions with a lot of scoring on offense, the team hasn’t been able to find a consistent option outside of the two.

Moriah Murray and Tèa Clèante both average 9.8 points per game, but have been very inconsistent in their scoring. While Murray scored double digits in six games, she also posted less than five points in several games.

For Penn State to earn its first conference victory, it’ll need production from those athletes to create more options on the offensive end.

Defensively, the Lady Lions must watch for more than just Wallace. The Fighting Illini arrive in Happy Valley with four double-digit scorers, including another tall forward in Cearah Parchment, who will keep Penn State’s frontcourt busy.

Between Maggie Mendelson — who started playing less than three weeks ago — and Amiya Evans — who earned the start on Thursday against Michigan but didn’t score — the blue and white need an answer down low against Illinois.

title: Penn State men's gymnastics opens up season with matchup against Army
author: Myles Hannak | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State opens its 2026 season inside Rec Hall at 2 p.m. on Sunday, and for the occasion, Army marches to Happy Valley.

The Nittany Lions finished fifth in the NCAA Championships last season, the first time they accomplished a feat since 2023, and despite a fifth-place finish, there remained many positives from that outing.

With that factor, though, coach Randy Jepson’s unit appears poised to build on last season’s finish, boasting an incredibly versatile 16-athlete roster that retained key upperclassmen performers such as Kacper Garnczarek, one of just two members of the blue and white named to the 2026 Big Ten Gymnasts to Watch list, while also welcoming an influx of six freshmen.

Although the outlook is positive, Jepson’s squad still appears to face an uphill battle, with the Big Ten coaches poll predicting a fourth-place finish among the five conference schools that have a team in the sport.

While the outlook appears mixed, with proven contributors pairing with high-upside newcomers, the limited competition suggests a strong run could propel Penn State to recreate last season’s successes.

The Nittany Lions start 2026 with an opponent that could provide all the juice needed to hit the ground running, as Penn State holds an undefeated 16-0 record against Army all-time entering the season opener.

The Black Knights and Penn State last met amidst that 2025 Nittany Lions’ run, also in the first two-team meet of that season, and the Nittany Lions triumphed with a score of 316.9 to 306.5. While the scale historically tips all time in the blue and white’s favor, and that continued last year, that meet was the only one between the schools to be decided by ten points or fewer since a 2019 victory where Penn State won by six.

Both the top point earners on the floor in last year’s contest with the Black Knights return for Penn State, in Matt Underhill and Akseli Karsikas. Yet on the pommel horse. Josh Karnes led Penn State in a unit that narrowly edged out Army, but he departed the team after his four years and has begun Olympic preparation and won’t compete in 2026.

Although that departure might nag at the Nittany Lions, it still contains a versatile leader in Kellen Ryan, who excels at both the rings and the vault.

Those mark all the key returnees for Penn State from last year’s meeting with Army, except Ian Rabual, the only member of a parallel bars squad that earned a perfect sweep.

For Army, its key gymnast to watch is Maddox Pabellon, the Event Champion on pommel horse in the meet last season, and a mainstay in the Black Knights squad that finished tenth in NCAA Championships last season, the highest in program history.

The Houston native is a team captain for the Black Knights and earned a plethora of accolades last season, including 2025 All-ECAC First Team, 2025 CGA Regular Season All-American honors and 2025 West Point Open Pommel Horse Champion.

The West Point Open kicked off both the Army and Penn State 2025 seasons, and in 2026, it’ll be the next event the two schools compete in since this opener. The two-day outing is scheduled for Jan. 16 and 17, with formal opponents to be announced shortly.

In the 2025 event, Penn State finished second behind Ohio State, with Navy, Springfield, William and Mary and Army rounding out the field.

title: Former Penn State LB Amare Campbell commits to Tennessee
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Jim Knowles has landed another former Nittany Lion.

GBO 🍊🍊🍊🍊🍊 LETS DO IT IM HOME 💯💯💯 https://t.co/LH5sG4E6WU— Amare🐐 (@amareGcampbell) January 10, 2026

title: No. 9 Penn State men’s hockey shuts out Minnesota in first Big Ten series of the second half
author: Maggie Hardy | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State jumped back into conference play on Friday night, hosting Minnesota for the two teams’ second and final series of the regular season.

The blue and white shut the Golden Gophers out 3-0 in the first game of the weekend.

The Nittany Lions struggled continuously with slow starts all season, but in their first Big Ten series of the new year, they were the ones to strike first.

Both teams appeared evenly matched to start the first period, but the blue and white gained momentum early in front of the crowd at Pegula Ice Arena.

Freshman forward Luke Misa broke the ice about five minutes into play, after redirecting a shot from the point from defenseman Carter Schade that found its way past Golden Gophers goaltender Luca Di Pasquo.

Penn State continued to maintain much of the offensive possession after the goal and doubled its lead about seven minutes later.

Misa tallied his second point of the night, finding sophomore defenseman Cade Christenson in the high slot, who fired a diving one-timer into the back of Minnesota’s net. After missing the first half of the season due to injury, Christenson's impact in the lineup has been felt, with his second goal in just three games back for the blue and white.

Despite a last-minute attempt by the Golden Gophers as the clock ran out, goaltender Josh Fleming stood tall in net, and Penn State went into the locker room with a 2-0 lead, holding the 19-9 edge in shots through the first 20 minutes.

Minnesota ramped up its offense in the second period, but the Nittany Lions countered with another strong period of their own.

The Golden Gophers welcomed back LJ Mooney and Brodie Ziemer after the forwards’ recent World Junior Championship campaign for Team USA, and both had chances throughout the period, but neither could get through Fleming.

After a relatively quiet 20 minutes on both sides, it looked like Penn State would hold on to its two-score lead, but with five seconds left on the clock, the home team added another.

After forward Reese Laubach fired a shot that trickled past Di Pasquo, sophomore JJ Wiebusch was there to tip in the loose puck and send the Nittany Lions into the second intermission up 3-0.

Unlike many Big Ten contests this season, neither team was overly physical, with over 50 minutes of play without a penalty called. That changed with about eight minutes to go, after Wiebusch was called for a 10-minute misconduct, ending his night.

The Golden Gophers had one of their best chances of the night just seconds after the penalty, after forward Beckett Hendrickson was all alone in front of the Nittany Lion net and tried to stuff the puck past Fleming, but the goaltender held strong.

The intensity grew as the minutes ticked down, and the game saw its first power play, after Penn State forward Lev Katzin was called for roughing with about five minutes to play.

Minnesota couldn’t get much going on the man-advantage, however, and the blue and white’s Big Ten-leading penalty kill held on to the shutout.

The Nittany Lions got a power play of their own after a scrum along the boards ended in matching penalties for both teams, and an additional 10-minute misconduct for Minnesota.

Penn State ran out the remaining minutes of the final frame and took the first game of the series 3-0.

Up Next

Penn State continues play at Pegula Ice Arena, hosting Minnesota for a rematch Saturday night, slated for a 6 p.m. puck drop.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: No. 13 Penn State men’s volleyball opens season with four-set victory over Mount Olive
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
The final season for Penn State under coach Mark Pavlik began with a home matchup against Mount Olive.

The No. 13 Nittany Lions took down the Trojans in a 3-1 victory behind all-around hitting from the team.

Mount Olive stuck with Penn State throughout the first set, despite the Nittany Lions scoring the first two points of the match on kills from right-side hitter Miller Truby and middle blocker Gaige Gabriel.

The teams traded points, with Penn State never giving up the lead. A kill from Trubey made the blue and white the first to 15, holding a 15-13 lead.

The Trojans made it close late in the first set, after a Maksim Kazanov kill made it 19-18 in the Nittany Lions’ favor.

It never got closer as setter Michael Schwob and middle blocker Owen Rose stuffed a swing, ending the first set on a 25-20 Penn State win.

Trubey led the way with six kills in the opening set as Penn State hit .395 in the set. Mount Olive hit .367, but couldn’t hold down the Nittany Lion attack.

Things remained the same in the second set, as both teams traded points. Penn State extended its lead in the second set on a 5-0 run, going ahead 15-8, and becoming the first team to reach the always important 15 point mark.

Holding a 17-11 lead, Penn State went on another run to extend its lead. A 4-0 run from the Nittany Lions behind the blocking of the front row. The block unit forced two straight attack errors, and a solo block from Rose put the blue and white up 21-11.

Mount Olive stormed back to make things interesting in the second set. A 5-0 run from the Trojans on two points from opposite hitter Kory Grant closed the gap to just six points, with Penn State leading 23-17.

That run extended to 8-0 after Grant’s second ace of the run. Penn State’s lead slimmed to just three after leading by 11 prior to the Trojans’ extended run.

Back-to-back kills from Schwob put away the set. The junior showcased his offensive abilities despite being a setter, closing out the set. Penn State took the second set 25-20, and inched one set away from a sweep.

Despite losing the first two sets, Mount Olive erupted, gaining more momentum to begin the third set.

Pavlik made the switch at setter to senior Jaxon Herr. The Grand Canyon transfer got off to a slow start, allowing the Trojans to get out to the lead. After leading 11-10, Mount Olive went on a 5-0 run after three attack errors from Penn State hitters.

After Penn State ended the run, the Trojans responded with a 3-0 run behind kills from Kazanov and Matthew Ekberg, leading Mount Olive to a 19-11 advantage.

The Nittany Lions attempted to crawl back, taking two points for every point the Trojans scored. Penn State forced a timeout after a double block from Herr and Gabriel.

Despite this, Mount Olive put away the set on a kill from Christos Savvidis, giving the Trojans the set victory, 25-20. Penn State still held a 2-1 lead in the match.

Penn State picked up momentum after inserting Jaidyn Bethel into the lineup. The redshirt freshman replaced Matthew Luoma at an outside hitter spot and provided a spark both offensively and defensively.

Leading 8-5, the blue and white erupted to a 4-0 run, rounded out by an ace from Rose. Like the second set, Penn State never gave up the lead.

Mount Olive could never respond after the 12-5 start. Despite consecutive points from the Trojans, Penn State immediately responded, putting to sleep any thought of a run.

Gabriel gave Penn State 20 points on the set, putting it in the “red zone,” just five points away from the match victory, holding a 20-15 lead.

After a lengthy review with Penn State holding set point, the review went in favor of the Nittany Lions, ending the match with a 25-18 victory in set 4.

Penn State took the match 3-1, advancing to 1-0 on the first weekend of the season.

Up Next

Penn State remains at Rec Hall, but plays in the South Gym to host Manhattan at 3 p.m. Saturday.

title: Penn State hires Northwestern DL coach Christian Smith
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has made an addition to its defensive staff.

The Nittany Lions have hired Northwestern defensive line coach Christian Smith as their edge rusher coach, the team announced Friday.

Another piece to the puzzle.Welcome to Happy Valley, @CoachSmith_9.#WeAre | https://t.co/r15KdC5syZ pic.twitter.com/JYCP0FvAvb— Penn State Football (@PennStateFball) January 9, 2026

Smith worked with the Wildcats’ defensive line for the last three seasons. He helped defensive lineman Aidan Hubbard, who totaled 19.5 sacks since 2023, to become an All-Big Ten honoree twice.

Prior to joining Northwestern, Smith was with South Dakota State for six seasons. He helped the squad to a 2022 FCS national championship, a year where the defensive line allowed an average of 88.1 rushing yards per game.

Smith was a graduate assistant under Matt Campbell at both Toledo in 2014-15 and Iowa State in 2016. He played as a defensive end with the Rockets from 2010-13 as well, tallying 80 tackles, 11.5 tackles for loss, five sacks and four forced fumbles.

title: Maddy Campbell records third career shutout, lifts No. 4 Penn State women's hockey over Mercyhurst
author: Dominic Megats I The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State concluded its stretch of games against top-10 teams suffering its first sweep of the season to Ohio State. While their toughest stretch of games may be finished, the Nittany Lions remained on the road for a conference series against an in-state rival in Mercyhurst.

Maddy Campbell found herself starting in net for the fourth time in her freshman season as Katie DeSa was kept out of the lineup for the second-straight game.

In what was the third matchup of the season between the two conference rivals, it was Campbell who took the spotlight as the Nittany Lions recorded their 10th shutout of the season, beating the Lakers 3-0.

Both teams created chances on the offensive rush to open the contest. Although neither chance resulted in points on the board, the two sides showed quick transition and immediate offensive zone pressure put on both goalies.

It wasn’t until just under nine minutes left in the opening frame that Penn State was given a chance to break the ice as Kate Donegan headed to the box. Ultimately resulting in a change on the scoreboard, the Nittany Lions spent almost the entire powerplay in the offensive zone.

The opening period was played very differently between the teams compared to the most recent game. Penn State opened that game with three opening goals. However, in Friday’s contest, the scoreboard was filled with zeros, and the shots were tied at six apiece.

Nearly six minutes removed in the middle frame, the Nittany Lions broke the ice. Tessa Janecke fed a pass to Nicole Hall from the boards. Hall quickly shot a wrister from the slot that beat Magdelena Luggin, giving the Stockholm, Sweden, native her eighth of the season.

The Lakers quickly developed momentum in an attempt to score as a flurry of shots were put on Campbell. Ultimately, all were saved by the freshman goalie, keeping the lead in Penn State’s favor halfway through the second period.

Campbell stopped all 27 shots in her fourth career start, most of which came in bunches through the middle frame.

Much of the second period was kept quiet due to the stellar performance in net for the Nittany Lions. On the other end of the ice, Penn State attempted to double its lead with quick transitions and occasional offensive zone threats. Ultimately, the horn sounded to conclude the second period, leaving the Nittany Lions with a 1-0 lead.

It only took heavy traffic and multiple wrap-around attempts for Penn State to add to its lead as Taya MacDonald took a wrap-around rebound behind the net herself and snuck one in on the right post.

Not even two minutes later, the Nittany Lions were caught with too many players on the ice after a line change gone wrong. An opportunity for the Lakers to answer. To no prevail as the penalty kill of Penn State suffocated offensive chances, matched with an exceptional performance in net.

Rains of stick taps poured into Mercyhurst Ice Center after Sofia Nuutinen found herself alone behind the Penn State defense, one-on-one with Campbell, ultimately being denied by the freshman’s blocker.

The Lakers weren’t done there as an offensive surge developed off of just about four rebound attempts. The suffocating pressure was quickly extinguished by Courtice, Ontario, native.

Danica Maynard put the dagger into the game between the two storied rivals off a quick shot from the left faceoff circle. Penn State remains undefeated in conference play as the clock hit triple zeros with the score 3-0.

Injury Report

DeSa was not listed in the lineup for the second-straight game. Matilde Fantin was not listed in the lineup, as well.

Up Next

Both teams return to Mercyhurst Ice Center at 1 p.m. on Saturday for the conclusion of the series.

MORE HOCKEY COVERAGE

title: Penn State women’s gymnastics opens 2026 season by welcoming Yale
author: Caroline Riley | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State gymnastics opens its 2026 season Sunday with a double dual meet at Rec Hall, as the women’s team hosts Yale and the men’s team faces Army at 2 p.m. The meet offers an early opportunity for both Nittany Lions squads to start the season 1-0, but for one potentially more than the other.

Sunday’s matchup is a great opportunity for the Penn State women’s gymnastics team to test out potential lineups from practice to consider possible adjustments before taking on the heart of its Big Ten schedule after facing the Bulldogs.

Last season, Yale scored in the 195.000+ range only once, in mid-March. Meanwhile, the blue and white scored above the 195.000 range in every meet but one last season. However, Penn State shouldn’t count the Bulldogs out.

Despite the blue and white’s undefeated record against Yale, every meet is a challenge to uphold it. In many ways, the head-to-head matchup can take a back seat to early-season score-building as the Nittany Lions look to improve their NQS from last season later in the year.

The lineups for both teams are far from locked, as injuries and good training days could impact each decision up until Sunday. Moreover, with Penn State's slew of new talent and the return of some injured stars from last season, how head coach Sarah Brown configures her depth will be a developing storyline throughout the season.

On vault, both teams expect to rely heavily on Yurchenko fulls, which carry a 9.95 start value. Penn State may also feature senior Ava Piedrahita’s Omelianchik on vault or perhaps an upgraded performance from some of the freshmen.

Clean form off the table and stuck landings will be the difference maker between two teams closely matched in their maximum start values.

Uneven bars were a strength for the Nittany Lions last season, but key gymnasts like Gabbie Gallentine and Cassi Barbanente graduated. Their departure leaves opportunities for new faces to step in or for older gymnasts who never made the lineup before.

Fortunately for Penn State, incoming freshman Ava Cash was a National Bars Champion in 2022 and could play a role in that lineup moving forward.

Beam, always precarious, poses a unique challenge in this meet for both teams as they battle nerves about opening the season. While Penn State returns several experienced beam workers, coach Brown needs to balance veteran reliability with the development of younger gymnasts.

Yale doesn’t consistently score as high on beam as some other events. Last season, at their top meet of the year, the Bulldogs’ top beam contributor posted just a 9.800. Increasing that score will be important for keeping pace with the Nittany Lions.

The floor exercise should be one of the best head-to-head matchups of the meet. Penn State struggled to consistently deliver strong performances on the event last season, at one point posting a low 48.575.

The Bulldogs, on the other hand, managed to tie their fifth-highest score in program history on the floor last season with a 49.225. If the meet comes down to the last rotation, a strong floor showing by Penn State might be something to watch for.

Some key gymnasts with event-winning potential for Yale to keep in mind include Hailey Kriz on the uneven bars, Hana Strause on beam, and Gigi Sabatini in the all around. For the blue and white, there are many storylines to keep an eye out for.

The significant returns of Jessica Johanson, Amani Herring, and Piedrahita after season-ending injuries could provide an immediate boost. How Brown utilizes Kalea McElligott within lineups, particularly in anchor roles, will also be worth monitoring.

Finally, what lineups the freshmen break into and the scores they manage to put up so early in the season are something to keep an eye on. On Sunday, the Nittany Lions will not only compete but also evaluate depth and begin to shape lineups designed to keep the program competitive in a demanding Big Ten field.

MORE GYMNASTICS COVERAGE

title: Penn State wrestling starts Big Ten schedule with dual vs. Rutgers
author: AJ Piazza | The Daily Collegian
description:
After breaking the record for longest win-streak in NCAA division I wrestling, Penn State returns to Rec Hall to start its Big Ten wrestling for this season. The Nittany Lions will take on Rutgers on Saturday at 4 p.m.

Here’s how each wrestler matches up against the Scarlet Knights.

125 Pounds: No. 2 Luke Lilledahl vs No. 29. Ayden Smith

Luke Lilledahl has wrestled up to the standard he’s capable of so far, but he’s the No. 2 wrestler for a reason. He hasn’t put up a ton of points in his most recent matches, totaling 10 in his last two matches.

Lilledahl has shown improvements with his defense as the season has gone on. In the close matches, his defense has been crucial to his victories.

Ayden Smith has an impressive 9-2 record so far this season. The Allentown, Pennsylvania, native will return to his home state and try to pull off a major upset over Lilledahl.

133 Pounds: No. 5 Marcus Blaze vs No. 24 Dylan Shawver

Marcus Blaze has been stellar this season. He has a perfect record of 10-0 and has beaten a few top-10 opponents, including Tyler Knox of Stanford. As a freshman, Blaze is already being talked about in the national championship conversation.

Dylan Shawver has lost his last two matches and will try to start 2026 the right way. The senior has an 11-4 record so far this season, and will look to bounce back from his current losing skid.

141 Pounds: No.9 Aaron Nagao/Nate Desmond vs No. 5 Joey Oliveri

This is the big question mark for the Nittany Lions. It looked like Aaron Nagao would be back, but he got re-injured at the Southern Scuffle. Cael Nasdeo also got hurt.

This leaves Nate Desmond, who was originally looked at as a 125-pounder, but has been wrestling at 141 the last few weeks. He’s 6-0 in limited action at the weight class, but could earn that starting job with Nagao battling injuries.

Whoever is wrestling will face a tough task in Joey Oliveri. Oliveri is the best wrestler in the Scarlet Knights lineup, continuing to climb the rankings.

149 Pounds: No. 1 Shayne Van Ness vs No. 31 Andrew Clark

Shayne Van Ness has been on a different level this season. He’s been dominant in every match he’s been in this season, going undefeated so far.

Clark has continued to fall down the rankings and needs to get a win to change his momentum. Van Ness is expected to dominate in this matchup and continue to sit at the top of the weight class.

157 Pounds: No. 4 PJ Duke vs No. 32 Tony White

PJ Duke has been a pleasant surprise for Penn State and is in a similar situation as Blaze, becoming a dominant wrestler in his respective weight class. The freshman’s coming off a victory against then No. 5 Daniel Cardenas.

Tony White is another member of the Scarlet Knights that has been trending in the wrong direction. This match looks like it could be lopsided, and could end up that way if Duke gets off to an aggressive start.

165 Pounds: No. 1 Mitchell Mesenbrink vs No. 21 Andrew Barbosa

Mitchell Mesebrink has been firing on all cylinders since the beginning of last season. He is one of the best wrestlers pound-for-pound in the country and has continued to show it this season.

Andrew Barbosa has the chance to face Mesenbrink, but Mesenbrink should get the victory in this match the same way he does in his other matches, by a large margin.

174 Pounds: No. 1 Levi Haines vs No. 9 Lenny Pinto

Levi Haines has taken the last two matchups against Lenny Pinto. Haines has been dominant on the mat for the entire season and is trying to win his first national championship at 174 pounds.

Pinto’s most recent loss was to No. 7 Carter Schubert. Pinto has had a solid season so far, but hasn’t been able to defeat the wrestlers in front of him.

He will need to change that and defeat the wrestler all the way at the top of the weight class, while Haines will look to continue his momentum that he’s built this season.

184 Pounds: No. 4 Rocco Welsh vs No. 15 Shane Cartagena-Walsh

Rocco Welsh hasn’t been scoring as much as expected, but he’s been able to get victories, though it's been inconsistent. In his last two matches he’s won 19-4 and 5-1, but Welsh’s defense has been elite.

Shane Cartagena-Walsh is another very good defensive wrestler. This match could be low scoring and might come down to the final seconds.

Welsh has flashed more offensively, than Cartagena-Walsh this season and will need to do so to get the win in this match.

197 Pounds: No. 1 Josh Barr vs No. 18 Remy Cotton

Even though he missed the start of this season, Josh Barr has shown why he’s the top ranked wrestler at 197. Barr just dominated No. 3 Stephen Little at the Southern Scuffle this past weekend, whereas Remy Cotton lost via tech fall by Seth Shumate 19-5.

If Barr gets off to an aggressive start, this match could end early.

285 Pounds: No. 15 Cole Mirasola vs No. 21 Hunter Catka

Cole Mirasola has had an up and down season. He has struggled with heavyweights that are bigger than him. Hunter Catka could be a good bounce back match for Mirasola, but it won’t be an easy task.

Catka has put up 19 and 20 points in his last two matches. While the opponents weren’t the same caliber wrestler as Mirasola, he’s been winning big against weaker competition.

This match contains two wrestlers that are pretty even and the match could go either way.

MORE WRESTLING COVERAGE

title: Penn State men's basketball looks to win first Big Ten game on road against No. 5 Purdue
author: Chase Mitchell | The Daily Collegian
description:
Teams from the Midwest have really been a thorn in Penn State’s side in the early part of this season, and it now faces another – only, this one sits in the AP Poll’s top five.

In their first Big Ten game, the Nittany Lions were devastated by Indiana, with the Hoosiers handing the blue and white a 41-point loss.

A gut-wrenching loss was then suffered just four days later when it looked like Penn State was going to upset No. 9 Michigan State. The same story can be told about this past Tuesday’s game against No. 2 Michigan – almost to a tee.

Including a pre-season loss to Dayton and a loss to Illinois last week, the Nittany Lions have been defeated by five teams hailing from the Midwest in 2025-26, and they’re about to face another.

Penn State heads to West Lafayette to square off against No. 5 Purdue on Saturday for a chance to win a road game against a top-5 opponent for the first time in program history. Tipoff is slated for 2 p.m., with the game broadcast on the Big Ten Network.

The Nittany Lions handled the Boilermakers at the Bryce Jordan Center, earning an 11-point upset last season. Penn State’s first win over a top-10 team since 2019 prompted a court storm that had people thinking the blue and white were on its way to a special season.

Purdue is once again led by its big three of Fletcher Loyer, Trey Kaufman-Renn and Braden Smith, and sits at 14-1 on the season.

Loyer and Kaufman-Renn average 13.8 points per game, with Kaufman-Renn also grabbing 10.1 rebounds per game.

Smith, who was a finalist for the Naismith Award a season ago, as well as the Big Ten Player of the Year and Bob Cousy Award winner, is averaging almost a double-double on the year, netting 13.3 points and 9.5 assists per game, leading the country in assists per game.

Matt Painter’s squad has the second-best assist-to-turnover ratio in the country and has ranked wins over Alabama, Texas Tech, Iowa State and Auburn while scoring 80-plus points in all but one game this season.

The Boilermakers are tied for the 41st-ranked scoring defense in the nation, allowing opponents to score 66.9 points per game on average. Penn State is averaging 77.7 points per game.

Penn State will be without star Kayden Mingo again after he sustained an injury prior to the loss against the Wolverines. Mike Rhoades said postgame that he will “be out for a little bit.”

While the severity of Mingo’s injury is unclear, his absence was noticeable against the No. 2 team in the nation and will be against the No. 5 team, as well.

The freshman was averaging 14.9 points per game as well as 3.9 rebounds, 4.5 assists and 2.5 steals while also playing the most minutes for the blue and white.

Hailing from Croatia, Penn State’s Ivan Jurić is shooting 55.8% from the field – the best on the team. He is coming off a career-high 20-point performance against Michigan.

Guard Freddie Dilione V has been the most consistent for the blue and white this season, all while playing most of his minutes from off the bench. He got the starting nod in Mingo’s absence against the Wolverines and dropped 17 points.

Penn State is undefeated this season when it scores 80 or more points, but 1-6 when scoring less.

With the Boilermakers allowing less than 70 points a game and the Nittany Lions being without their leading scorer, the younger, more inexperienced blue and white have a challenging top-5 road test on its hands.

Rhoades’ squad’s remaining schedule loosens up ever so slightly, with games against bottom of the conference Northwestern and Maryland on the horizon. However, a likely loss to the Boilermakers means time is ticking for Penn State to gain any sort of momentum moving forward.

MORE BASKETBALL COVERAGE

title: Report: UCLA DT Siale Taupaki to transfer to Penn State
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Penn State continues to bolster the trenches and it’s a player who is going on his eighth year of college football.

The Nittany Lions landed a commitment from former UCLA defensive tackle Siale Taupaki, per Matt Zenitz of CBS Sports.

It’s been a long road for Taupaki, starting his career in 2019 where he didn’t see any game action, maintaining his redshirt. The following season he played in seven games, earning himself an extra year of eligibility due to COVID.

The next two years he appeared in two games, both in 2022, as he dealt with injuries. It is unclear as to when he received a medical redshirt, but he picked one up due to injuries suffered somewhere in this time period.

In 2023 Taupaki returned to the field, switching positions to become an offensive lineman, where he saw game action in seven contests as a reserve.

Then he went back to the defensive side of the ball in 2024, appearing in all 24 games over the course of the next two seasons as a defensive tackle.

Overall, in his career with the Bruins, he appeared in 40 total games with 33 on defense and seven on offense. Defensively, he notched 38 total tackles, three tackles for loss and two sacks.

Taupaki will head to Penn State and will reunite with defensive coordinator D’Anton Lynn and defensive line coach Ikaika Malloe, who both coached him at UCLA.

title: Former Penn State RB, East Carolina transfer London Montgomery commits to Florida
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
A former member of the LawnBoyz found the third school of their collegiate career.

East Carolina transfer running back London Montgomery committed to Florida, he announced Thursday via X.

🐊🐊 pic.twitter.com/wrHkjNi42C— London Montgomery (@LondonMontgom11) January 9, 2026

Montgomery didn't play in a game with the Nittany Lions during his lone season in Happy Valley, redshirting in 2023 after tearing his ACL during his senior year of high school. He transferred to the Pirates following the year.

At East Carolina, Montgomery rushed for 1,101 yards and nine touchdowns in the past two seasons, including 742 yards and seven touchdowns on 156 carries in 2025. The redshirt sophomore opted out of the team's Military Bowl game against Pitt.

Montgomery was a 247Sports composite 4-star in the 2023 class out of Scranton Prep in Pennsylvania. He ranked as the No. 416 player nationally, No. 28 running back and No. 8 player from his home state.

title: Penn State women's hoops overmatched by Michigan’s fast start, as Lady Lions still search for Big Ten footing
author: Sam Simonic I The Daily Collegian
description:
The start to Big Ten play hasn’t treated the Lady Lions well. In welcoming a top-ten opponent to State College, their record failed to improve.

After a uniquely convincing start to the season, Penn State showed it might have something to prove. However, behind the 4-0 start came lots of growing pains as the young team hasn’t quite clicked.

Any talk of jet lag following the holiday festivities was a convenient scapegoat after the Lady Lions lost to Wisconsin days ago. Thursday’s contest was a different story. Penn State’s Rec Hall welcomed another sizable loss, as Penn State fell to Michigan 105-65.

The game was over before it even started.

Heading into the tilt, the Wolverines’ recent slump gave Penn State a gleam of hope. Despite the No. 9 ranking next to its name, Michigan proved vulnerable as the team displayed subpar shooting numbers.

In a loss to Washington and a close win over Minnesota, the Wolverines’ three-point shooting dipped to 21 percent in each of their last two games. Maybe the Lady Lions got too comfortable scouting that.

Slow starts have continuously haunted coach Carolyn Kieger’s team. Once more, it fell victim to that against Michigan. Mila Holloway kick-started the offensive onslaught with a three-pointer, which essentially set the tone for the rest of the game.

It wasn’t just the offense, but the defense too, that starred behind Michigan’s hot start. Penn State went on a nearly five-minute first-quarter drought in which the Wolverines took a 20-2 lead. That gap created enough room for Michigan to run away with the victory before the fight began.

The Lady Lions would’ve needed a near-perfect showing to encore their first win since Dec. 20. Tèa Clèante got Penn State in the scoring column to start, but Gracie Merkle laid the foundation for a comeback as the team fired back in the second frame.

Nevertheless, each short run the Wolverines neutralized with a counter-run even more vast. Michigan’s Te’Yala Delfosse, Brooke Quarles Daniel and Holloway combined to score 41 points in the first half. The three-headed monster outscored the Lady Lions by ten points and terrorized the team in transition.

Penn State’s 17 turnovers at the break were an issue of its own, as the team had continued to give away free points. Despite the deficit, Penn State kept the Wolverines’ leading scorer, Olivia Olson, relatively quiet.

It didn’t seem to matter as virtually everyone got invited to the scoring party for the maize and blue. Penn State didn’t play a consistent offensive approach, as the Lady Lions failed to use their height in the paint with Merkle and Aimya Evans on the court together.

Michigan widened its lead through each of the four quarters as Penn State had few options to stop the aggressive guard attack. The blue and white found limited bench options as Kieger switched up lineups in the final frame.

Trial and error had been a significant theme for Penn State in its 2025-26 season, yet the Big Ten continues to eat at any lineup Kieger offered so far.

Michigan finished with 44 bench points and five players in double figures. It was the highest scoring output the Lady Lions have surrendered all year.

Injury Report

Viktoria Ranisavljevic entered Thursday's contest with an undisclosed injury and therefore didn’t appear against Michigan. The Massagno, Switzerland, native logged 18 minutes and scored five points in the Lady Lions’ last game against Wisconsin.

Up Next

Penn State gets a chance to turn the page on Sunday, Jan. 11, when it hosts the 13-3 Illinois Fighting Illini. The two teams meet in the Bryce Jordan Center, with a scheduled 3:00 p.m. tipoff.

title: Penn State DT Xavier Gilliam transfers to Tennessee
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
A former Penn State defensive lineman is reuniting with a handful of ex-Nittany Lion coaches at his next stop.

After spending two years in Happy Valley, defensive tackle Xavier Gilliam has transferred to Tennessee, he announced on Thursday.

I’m home! https://t.co/M3MomAKw46— Xavier Gilliam (@XavierGilliam_) January 9, 2026

Despite Chris Hummer of CBS Sports reporting that Gilliam was open to returning to Penn State, that was quickly shut down, as a quartet of teams in Indiana, Tennessee, Notre Dame and Texas A&M showed interest.

He ended up visiting the Hoosiers, Volunteers and Fighting Irish in that order, and it was Tennessee who won out in the end. A trio of ex-Penn State staffers in defensive coordinator Jim Knowles, safeties coach Anthony Poindexter and defensive analyst Andrew Jackson all went from State College to Knoxville following the 2025 season.

Knowles and Poindexter will have the same roles, whereas Jackson will work as the LEOs coach, a hybrid role created by Knowles for his defenses.

Gilliam redshirted in 2024, and was the No. 3 defensive tackle on the depth chart in 2025 behind Zane Durant and Alonzo Ford Jr. In two seasons with Penn State, he appeared in 17 games, garnering 16 total tackles, 0.5 sacks and blocked a field goal.

The former 4-star will have three years of eligibility remaining.

title: Report: Penn State hires Savon Huggins as RBs coach
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
The last position on Matt Campbell's coaching staff has been filled.

Boston College's Savon Huggins has reportedly been hired by the Nittany Lions as their running backs coach, per Chris Hummer, Tyler Donohue and Matt Zenitz of 247Sports.

Huggins has been the running backs coach for the Eagles the last five seasons. During that span, he coached Pat Garwo, Turbo Richard and Kye Robichaux.

The former Rutgers running back began his coaching career at Somerville High School in New Jersey before doing a fellowship with the Miami Dolphins in 2019.

Huggins has spent time with Buffalo, UMass and St. Peter's Prep as well.

title: Penn State notebook | Cael Sanderson discusses weight-class depth, Rutgers
author: Andrew Deal | Sports Editor
description:
No. 1 Penn State returns to the mat for Big Ten play on Saturday against No. 16 Rutgers for the start of the Nittany Lions’ 2026.

During the dual-season hiatus, multiple Penn State wrestlers competed across different tournaments and events, including the Southern Scuffle and the Bob Kauffman Memorial Open.

Cael Sanderson met with local media to discuss decisions at weight classes and the dominance of his young Nittany Lions.

Here’s what he had to say.

141-pound decision

Aaron Nagao made his return to the mat after suffering an injury at the Black Knight Invitational in November. However, Nagao had to medically forfeit out of the Southern Scuffle, making the Penn State weight class up in the air for the future.

It wasn’t a thought for Sanderson that Nagao would return to the starting lineup when he recovered from the injury, but after suffering a setback, Nagao’s availability is in question.

“He just wanted to get back on the mat and see how he would feel, and that was kind of the idea,” Sanderson told local reporters via a video from Zack Seyko of Locked on Nittany Lions. “Obviously, things didn’t go as we kind of hoped for him.”

Prior to this, the decision was seemingly to have true freshman Nate Desmond fill in before his five dates ran out to maintain his redshirt. Now, Desmond could burn the redshirt and be the starter at the class, having wrestled three dates thus far.

Desmond has proven himself to be a capable starter, already holding a 6-0 record, with three of the wins coming at 141 pounds.

He was listed at 125 pounds, and made that weight for the Black Knight Invitational. However, he wrestled up two weight classes, weighing in around 138 pounds each time.

“Nate Desmond did a great job filling in when he moved up to 41, even having wrestled 25 this year,” Sanderson said. “He’s made a lot of progress, obviously, he’s been one of the best wrestlers since he was a little kid, but he’s been doing a really good job, really good mindset, attitude, getting better in all regards.”

With Desmond having been the starter at 141 pounds the last three matches, he could easily be the choice. However, there’s another wrestler who’s currently on the path to redshirt that could insert himself back into the lineup, a place he’s been the past two seasons.

Braeden Davis was on track to redshirt. He dominated in the Kauffman Open, winning the weight class with ease, while wrestling unattached. He could provide a more veteran presence, with experience at the Big Ten Tournament and the NCAA Championships.

“Davis has kind of been on standby, and he competed last week,” Sanderson said. “Just trying to see… definitely an option we have.”

Rutgers rivalry

Despite Rutgers never having beat Penn State, there’s still a geographical rivalry between the two programs.

Shayne Van Ness is from Somerville, New Jersey, which is just 12 minutes from Piscataway. For Rutgers, Mason Gibson and Devon Magro went to high school at Bishop McCort, which is 81.5 miles from State College.

The two programs are constantly competing for recruits, and geographically are close enough to each other to fit a rivalry.

“They always bring fire and passion, and coach (Scott) Goodale is one of the best. He does a really good job,” Sanderson said. “I don’t know the history, or whatever the past is, but we always enjoy wrestling them.”

With the matchup against Rutgers, it restarts the Big Ten schedule, with the dual season kicking into high gear for the final two months.

Penn State will only wrestle Big Ten teams from here on out, as the Big Ten championship is in the Bryce Jordan Center in March.

“Obviously, start with Rutgers this week, it’s always a great match,” Sanderson said. “Big Ten schedule’s always a lot of fun.”

157-pound depth

Tyler Kasak was the Big Ten champion last season at 157 pounds, and entered the NCAA Tournament as the No. 1 seed. Despite this, Kasak is expected to hold his redshirt this season, opening the door for younger wrestlers.

PJ Duke and Joe Sealey have both proven that they’re capable wrestlers. Duke’s redshirt will officially be burnt if he wrestles against Rutgers, with Sealey already redshirting last season.

“All three of those guys are incredible wrestlers and have a great mindset and (are) team players,” Sanderson said. “They see the big picture. You don’t come to Penn State if you’re not a big picture kind of person.”

Duke, Sealey and Kasak could all be viable options for Penn State to earn another Big Ten title at the weight class, and compete for the national championship. However, Duke’s dominance could place him in a tier above the two depending on the rest of the season. With all this, the picture is still bigger than just national championships.

“They’re trying to be world Olympic champions. It’s just a different mindset that maybe people aren’t going to understand,” Sanderson said. “Joe Sealey wants to be a world Olympic champion, PJ Duke wants to be a world Olympic champion, obviously, Tyler Kasak wants to be a world Olympic champion.”

title: Penn State men's hockey returns to Big Ten play against Minnesota
author: Evan Smith | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State men’s hockey faces conference foe Minnesota at Pegula Ice Arena this weekend.

The series will serve as a momentum boost for two teams returning star players for the World Juniors as they look to separate themselves in college hockey’s deepest conference.

The Golden Gophers and Nittany Lions are tied in the Big Ten at 4-4-0, apiece. Minnesota is just 8-10-1 overall compared to Penn State’s 12-6-0 record, but has faced a tougher non-conference strength of schedule.

Penn State is coming off a split series against RIT, while Minnesota tied Bemidji State in its last outing. The teams split their matchup against each other earlier this year, as well as the two prior series in Happy Valley.

The teams will faceoff at Pegula Ice Arena at 6 p.m. Friday and Saturday. Both games will be televised on Big Ten Network.

Stars

Big-name talent will be on display and highlighted in this matchup. To start, the Nittany Lions will regain the services of Gavin McKenna after his stint in the World Junior Championships. McKenna recorded 14 points in the tournament en route to a bronze medal. He reunites with Aiden Fink for the first time since Fink’s injury early in the season.

Speaking of Fink, the first-line winger is only three points away from becoming the fastest Nittany Lion to reach 100 career points. Alex Limoges is the current record holder with 102 games to reach the mark. Fink will play in his 86th and 87th career games this weekend. Fink would be the ninth Nittany Lion to reach the milestone.

Minnesota returns two members of Team USA this weekend, including team captain Brodie Ziemer and Pittsburgh native, and cousin of NHL star Logan Cooley, LJ Mooney. Ziemer and Mooney are two of 13 NHL draft picks on the roster for the Golden Gophers.

Ziemer and Brody Lamb are tied for the team’s lead in points at 19 apiece, while five other Golden Gophers sit at double-digits for the season.

Penn State will need its stars to counter, as only six members of the current roster have scored goals against Minnesota. The leaders are Reese Laubach and Matt DiMarsico, each with six career points against the Golden Gophers.

Goaltending has been the Achilles heel for Minnesota throughout the first half, with neither Luca Di Pasquo nor Nathan Airey clocking a goals-against-average under 2.99 or save percentage above .905. Kevin Reidler only gave up one goal to Minnesota and is in line for at least one start this weekend.

Starting strong

Penn State will need to start hot in order to secure victories in these two games. Against RIT, the Nittany Lions started slow on the road and ended up getting shut out, before scoring the first goal on Sunday en route to a 7-3 drubbing of the Tigers.

On the year, Penn State is 8-1 when scoring the first goal, with the lone loss coming to these Golden Gophers on the road.

The Nittany Lions will also look to draw penalties early, as Minnesota runs the second-worst penalty kill in the country, killing just 62.4% of opposing power plays.

Return of the roar

On Sunday, despite a high-scoring victory over RIT, the energy in Pegula Ice Arena was noticeably softer. This is because the Penn State student body was on break so the Roar Zone was filled with non-students.

While some may think the atmosphere isn’t a factor, it’s clear that the Roar Zone means a lot to the players. During Sunday’s senior night speeches, every senior took time to shout out to the student section and express their desire to play in front of them again. They will get that opportunity this weekend with students filing back to campus ahead of the spring semester.

title: Penn State women's lacrosse releases 2026 schedule
author: Noah Aberegg | The Daily Collegian
description:
A new era under coach Kayla Treanor is about to begin in Happy Valley.

2026 🔜#WeAre pic.twitter.com/PqLhgAxVPz— Penn State Women’s Lacrosse (@PennStateWLAX) January 8, 2026

Penn State released its 2026 schedule on Thursday, kicking off on the road on Feb. 7.

The Nittany Lions match up against Richmond before a three-game home stretch against Massachusetts, Bucknell and Pitt on Feb. 11, 15 and 18.

Penn State then hits the road against Drexel and Cornell to round out February, followed by a home matchup against Colgate on March 4.

The blue and white travel to the West Coast to take on San Diego State and Princeton on March 8 and 12, followed by home games against Princeton and Michigan on March 15 and 22.

In the team's first conference road trip, it faces Maryland and Ohio State on March 29 and April 5, before playing host to Oregon, Northwestern and Johns Hopkins on April 9, 12 and 16.

The Nittany Lions close out the season at Rutgers on April 18.
