title: Transfer portal update | Penn State looks to non-Iowa State players, Chaz Coleman decision looms
author: Lexie Linderman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has been booked and busy lately as the transfer portal window continues to get crazier by the day.

Matt Campbell may not be dealing with his star quarterback breaching a brand new contract, but he is dealing with a roster that’s seen 48 players enter the transfer portal.

Here’s the latest on the transfer portal action in Happy Valley these past few days. For a full list of returnees, departures and incoming transfers throughout the portal cycle, click here.

Shocking changes of plans

The most eye-catching updates for Penn State recently were quite unexpected, with two players that previously announced returns to the Nittany Lions entering the transfer portal.

Both safety Dejuan Lane and wide receiver Tyseer Denmark are searching for new homes after the pair deleted their X posts that indicated they had chosen to stay at Penn State.

“Rather drown with my guys before I ever jump ship,” Lane’s return announcement wrote.

Why Lane and Denmark changed their minds remains unclear, although it could have something to do with Campbell bringing in a few defensive backs and wide receivers from Iowa State.

Regardless, both are pretty substantial losses for the Nittany Lions. Lane’s departure means all four of Penn State’s main safeties from 2025 won’t be in Happy Valley next year, while Denmark had always been a promising young talent.

Outside visitors

Penn State has been hosting transfer portal targets for the past few days, with a few notable names making their way to State College.

FIU defensive tackle Xion Chapman was on campus Tuesday as the Nittany Lions look to continue their overhaul on the defensive line. Chapman had 15 tackles, three tackles for loss and one forced fumble in 2025.

The Allentown, Pennsylvania, native started his collegiate career at Lackawanna College, where former Penn State safeties Ji’Ayir Brown and Jaquan Brisker began their careers as well.

Following Chapman’s visit, the defensive tackle posted that Penn State offered him a scholarship.

Michigan State running back Makhi Frazier was also at Penn State on Tuesday as Campbell looks to rebuild that room as well. As of now, the Nittany Lions have just four running backs on board with two transfer commitments from James Peoples and Carson Hansen along with Tikey Hayes and Quinton Martin Jr., both of whom were with the blue and white in 2025.

Frazier led the Spartans in rushing yards this year with 520, making seven starts and playing nine games.

Other players that had visits scheduled for Tuesday include Colorado defensive back Noah King, South Dakota running back LJ Phillips and Wyoming defensive tackle Lucas Samsula. UConn linebacker Oumar Diomande was scheduled to be on campus Wednesday.

New homes

As Penn State lands portal commits, former Nittany Lions are busy on visits while finding new homes of their own.

Defensive end Zuriah Fisher committed to USC after taking an official visit there, while defensive tackle Owen Wafle pledged to Duke.

Former Penn State offensive line coach Phil Trautwein also picked up a pair of his guys, with T.J. Shanahan Jr. and Eagan Boyer both committed to their position coach down at Florida.

James Franklin locked down another one of his former players as well, as Jeff Exinor Jr. committed to Virginia Tech. Additionally, wide receiver Josiah Brown has a visit scheduled with the Hokies, per 247Sports’ Kolby Crawford.

Linebacker Anthony Speca landed at a Big Ten foe in Purdue, while offensive lineman Alex Birchmeier is set to return to his home state of Virginia at Liberty.

Some notable uncommitted former Nittany Lions are currently out and about, as defensive end Chaz Coleman is currently at Ohio State for a visit after taking trips to both LSU and Tennessee. Xavier Gilliam, meanwhile, is at Notre Dame after also visiting Tennessee.

Finally, former Penn State quarterback Beau Pribula is set to visit Washington, per Matt Zenitz of CBS Sports, as the Huskies work to pursue legal action against Demond Williams Jr. after the quarterback shockingly entered the portal just days after signing a new deal.

Pribula spent 2025 with Missouri before deciding to enter the portal again.

MORE FOOTBALL COVERAGE

title: Penn State men’s volleyball opens season with back-to-back games
author: Keira Albert I The Daily Collegian
description:
It’s a busy weekend ahead for Penn State as it opens the season with back-to-back games.

The Nittany Lions open their 2026 season against the Mount Olive Trojans in Rec Hall at 6 p.m. Friday. They then face the Manhattan Jaspers in Rec Hall’s South Gym at 3 p.m. Saturday.

Mount Olive

With both teams starting their seasons on Friday night, it could be anyone’s game.

The Trojans went 20-4 last season, losing only two games on the road all year. While the two teams didn’t share many similar opponents, the blue and white held a noticeably different 15-16 record.

While the two teams played very different schedules last season, they shared an opponent in Loyola Chicago.

Loyola Chicago swept Mount Olive 3-0, and it concluded the match with 30 kills and 17 errors.

When the blue and white played the same team, it lost 1-3. Similar to the Trojans, the blue and white totaled 39 kills and 16 errors during that match.

While the teams posted wildly different records, they played a similar game against this shared opponent, which could suggest a close match on Friday.

And where one team struggles, the other seems to flourish.

Penn State totaled 1,252 kills last season, while Mount Olive tallied a lesser total with 1,038. However, while the blue and white finished with 563 errors on the year, the Trojans traded with the favorable 333.

In terms of the offensive attack, it seems to be a fairly even matchup when looking at the top players on each roster.

Mount Olive’s Kory Grant finished the year with 284 kills and 324.0 points. He led the team in both categories. Entering his senior season, Grant poses a threat to the blue and white, especially with the absence of Penn State’s Will Kuhns.

Kuhns finished the year with 330 kills and 390.5 points, leading the team in both categories just as Grant had. The difference, however, is that Kuhns graduated and won’t take the court on Friday.

But with a player like Matthew Luoma returning, the blue and white still have the statistical advantage. The redshirt junior had 294 kills and 351.5 points last year.

However, it looks like the defense leans in Penn State’s favor.

Owen Rose led the Penn State squad with 115 blocks on the year. Similarly, Ryan Merk led with 209 digs. With both redshirt seniors returning, the duo poses a threat to any opponent.

The leader in blocks for the Trojans last year was Holden Maryott. But he tallied only 79 on the year, much fewer than Rose. However, Maryott won’t be in the lineup on Friday, as he also graduated, which could play in the blue and white’s favor.

However, last year’s dig leader, Luca Colombo, bested Merk’s numbers with 234 on the year.

Friday’s game could easily be a close one in the season opener.

Manhattan

Saturday’s game could continue the trend and prove to be an interesting one.

In July of 2024, Manhattan College announced the addition of a men’s volleyball team to the school, with its launch scheduled for the 2025-26 season.

This fact means that the Jaspers are debuting their team to the world against the blue and white in what they are calling their Inaugural Match.

The Manhattan team is very young, consisting primarily of freshmen. In fact, 13 of the 16 players on the roster are freshmen.

However, that’s not to say they aren’t a talented team.

One of the few upperclassmen, Wojtek Nowak, is a standout. Before Manhattan, he played at Menlo College, where he totaled 311.5 points and accumulated 236 kills in his sophomore season. He also had 57 service aces, ranking him fourth in the NCAA.

Kasen Owens, a sophomore, has one of the other more impressive resumes in terms of his days before the Jaspers. Playing for Merrimack his freshman year, he totaled 101.5 points in 15 matches.

Owens faced the Nittany Lions while at Merrimack, and even tallied a season-high two service aces in that match.

It’s hard to say which way Saturday’s game will go. While it’s clear the Jaspers have the talent, their lack of experience could present an issue against the veteran Penn State team.

MORE VOLLEYBALL COVERAGE

title: Staff predictions | What will Mark Pavlik’s final season look like for Penn State men’s volleyball?
author: Daily Collegian men's volleyball staff
description:
Penn State men's volleyball's 2026 season will be remembered regardless of its outcome, and the preseason outlook only suggests more hype.

Keira Albert: 14-13

The loss of a key playmaker like Will Kuhns definitely presents the potential to impact overall performance this season. However, the blue and white still have the keys to produce a winning season with the remaining talent on the roster.

The blue and white will open the season with three straight wins against Mount Olive, Manhattan and St. Thomas Aquinas. However, its win streak gets broken against Lewis, making them 3-1.

Heading into the series against McKendree, the Nittany Lions will win one and lose one. But just like last year, they’ll lose both games to Hawai'i, putting Penn State at an even 4-4.

Going into the Saint Francis series, Penn State leaves the court with a full sweep, putting them on a two-game winning streak.

The streak will yet again be broken, however, during the Princeton series. Here, the blue and white will lose one game and win the other, putting them at a solid 7-5.

The next three games, two of which are against Harvard and one against Merrimack, will put the blue and white on a three-game winning streak and cement their record at 10-5. Ultimately, Long Beach State breaks the streak again in their match against Penn State.

This loss will trigger a series of losses against Pepperdine, USC and Ohio State, putting the Nittany Lions at a rocky 10-9.

To close out the year, Penn State will leave the NJIT series with one win and one loss, but will lose both the Charleston games. There will be a brief turnaround with back-to-back wins against Sacred Heart, but it will ultimately have to settle for one win and one loss in the George Mason series.

By the end of the regular season, the Nittany Lions will end with a winning season at 14-13.

Chase Mitchell: 15-12

Penn State recently earned predictions to finish first in the EIVA and once again win the conference to claim its 38th title.

In the last year under longtime coach Mark Pavlik, libero Ryan Merk and middle blocker Owen Rose will be key pieces to make a run for another championship.

The Nittany Lions roll at the start of the season, winning their first three matches with ease.

The Jan. 17 matchup against Lewis will be the first test of the season, but I think the blue and white pull it out and get the victory, likely in a fifth set.

Penn State then heads to Lebanon, Illinois, to take on McKendree. I think this will be the first falter of 2026 for the Nittany Lions, but I don’t see them losing both matches. I think they’ll split the series and leave it at 5-1.

To end January, the 2021 and 2022 National Champions come to Rec Hall. I do think Penn State loses both matches to Hawaii, but the optimist in me really wants to say they’ll split.

Pavlik and the blue and white then have a two-match series against Saint Francis, with one match in Rec Hall and the other in Loretto, Pennsylvania. I’ve got Penn State winning both of these to move to 7-3.

By the time the Nittany Lions face USC, I think they’ll be 10-7 after splitting with Princeton and Harvard and a loss to the defending National Champions, Long Beach State.

I’ve got Penn State falling to the Trojans and Ohio State to slide to 10-9. I also think it’ll lose a couple of matches that it should win– I could see losses to NJIT or Charleston.

I think the Nittany Lions close out the season by splitting the series against George Mason, hopefully heading into the postseason with momentum after ending 15-12.

George Keene: 13-14

After finishing 15-16 last season, the Nittany Lions finish this season with the same fate.

Penn State should get off to a fast start and grab four early wins against Mount Olive, Manhattan, St. Thomas Aquinas and Lewis.

The Nittany Lions then take on McKendree on the road, and I have them splitting the series, making them 5-1 heading into their first real test of the season.

Back-to-back matchups with Hawaii will be a turning point for the blue and white. After getting eliminated by Hawaii in the NCAA tournament last year, I don’t think Penn State can compete and steal a win. I think they will drop both matches and split the following Saint Francis series, dropping them to 6-4.

Despite being picked to finish at the top of the EIVA, conference matchups always become decided in the margins and the Nittany Lions will need to grab two wins against George Mason, NJIT, and Sacred Heart to finish above .500.

The Nittany Lions start conference play against Princeton and Harvard. I have them splitting matches with Princeton and losing both to Harvard, leaving them 7-7 overall.

After a brief stretch of conference play, the Nittany Lions face Merrimack, Long Beach State, Pepperdine, USC and Ohio State. With four of the five matches being away from Happy Valley, I have Penn State winning against Merrimack and dropping the following four matches, putting them at 8-11.

The blue and white then closes out the regular season with eight in-conference matches. I think Penn State will split with NJIT, split with Charleston, split with Sacred Heart, and win both against George Mason to end the season.

title: Penn State adds Joe Resendez as director of football sports medicine
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Penn State has a new support staffer.

The Nittany Lions have hired Joe Resendez as its director of football sports medicine, per the staff directory. Greg Pickel of Blue White Illustrated first reported the news Wednesday night.

Resendez joined Matt Campbell's staff at Iowa State ahead of the 2025 season, when he was the team's director of sports medicine.

Prior to his lone year in Ames, Iowa, Resendez worked for the XFL/UFL as the league's head athletic trainer from 2022-24. He has NBA experience as well as he was the head athletic trainer for the Sacramento Kings in 2018-22 and an assistant athletic trainer for the Los Angeles Clippers from 2010-18.

title: Position Preview | A look into Penn State men’s volleyball outside and opposite hitters
author: George Keene | The Daily Collegian
description:
Despite capturing another EIVA championship this past season, Penn State endured a 15-16 record and second-round exit to No. 2 Hawaii in the quarterfinals of the NCAA tournament.

As the Nittany Lions enter the 2026 season with plenty of new faces, coach Mark Pavlik has a variety of options when it comes to the frontline.

Bennett Wilson, OH

In his freshman season, Wilson appeared in one match in which Penn State swept Saint Francis. In his sophomore year, Wilson should have a larger opportunity to use his 6-foot-4 frame and help bolster the Nittany Lions' front line, especially with the lack of collegiate experience in front of him.

Kyle Fagan, OH

The 6-foot-4 freshman joins Penn State off an impressive high school career. Fagan attended Ward Melville Senior High School, where, in his 2023 season, he earned numerous accolades: 1st Team All-Conference, 1st Team All-County, 1st Team All-Region, and 1st Team All-State. Fagan also played for Academy Volleyball of Long Island. Fagan is one of several young players on this team who will get an opportunity to earn their spot early.

Tristan Hassell, OPP

Entering his freshman season, Hassell is another young player who may not see significant playing time. However, he gets the opportunity to learn from two experienced opposite hitters, Matthew Luoma and Miller Trubey.

Christian Couch, OPP

Couch, like Hassell, will compete for court time in 2026. Couch attended Bel Air High School and fills out the competition for the hitting unit for next season. He redshirted his 2025 season, and this year marks his first real opportunity to make an impact in Happy Valley.

Jaidyn Bethel, OH

Bethel used his redshirt season this past year. Out of high school, AVCA named Bethel to the 2024 AVCA Boys High School All-American Watch list.

Matija Grbić, OH

Entering his first season in Happy Valley, the Zabalj, Serbia, native stands at 6-foot-6 and is another freshman who bolsters their outside-hitter depth. Grbić spent two seasons with SIR Safety Perugia Juniores and three seasons with Calzedonia Verona Juniores.

Sean Harvey, OH, OPP

The 6-foot-7 redshirt sophomore didn’t see any action this past season, but likely sees a larger workload this year. Before Penn State, VolleyballMag.com named Harvey a 2023 Fab 50 recruit and he played two years of varsity volleyball at South Elgin High School. He totaled 350 kills and 204 digs in his varsity career, leading his squad to a conference title in 2022.

Carter Dittman, OH

Entering his third season with the blue and white, Dittman arrives off a productive sophomore season. The Fairport, New York, native tallied 42 kills in 39 sets. His hitting percentage is a key area for improvement, as Dittman committed 21 errors on his 122 total attempts. If he can find the open spots on the court, he will likely become a leader for this squad.

Matthew Luoma, OH/OPP

Luoma is coming off a strong season in which EIVA gave him a spot on the All-Tournament Team, Academic All-Big Ten and All-EIVA Academic Team. The publication also gave him an honorable mention for the All-EIVA 2025 team. In his redshirt sophomore season, Luoma played in 89 sets, hitting .194 with 294 kills. He also collected 94 digs, 69 blocks, and 21 aces. He reached double-digit kills 15 times and finished the season with seven such matches. If Penn State hopes to compete for an EIVA title, it starts with Luoma leading the front line and being even more productive this season.

Blainey Jones OH

Named a VolleyballMag.com Fab 50 recruit coming out of high school, Jones hasn’t had the opportunity to make an impact in the blue and white quite yet. Playing in a total of five sets in three seasons thus far, one can expect Jones to have more of an opportunity this season with all the newcomers on the squad.

Miller Trubey

Like Luoma, Penn State’s frontline relies on Trubey's production. Trubey arrives off a productive year collecting 70 kills, 15 blocks, 31 digs and 12 aces in 65 sets played. As one of the more experienced opposite hitters on the squad, another increase in production from the 7-footer would help the Nittany Lions improve from their record a year ago.

The Nittany Lions start their 2026 season with their home-opener against Mount Olive at 6 p.m. Friday.

title: ‘I want to win’ | Mike Rhoades not satisfied with Penn State’s close loss to No. 2 Michigan
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Mike Rhoades walked into the Bryce Jordan Center media room following Penn State’s 74-72 loss to No. 2 Michigan looking defeated.

He didn’t seem satisfied that his team, which ranks last in the Big Ten standings, took the Wolverines, who are 14-0 and a national championship contender, down to the wire with a last-second shot missing its mark to lose the game. And he proved that when asked about it.

“I want to win. I didn’t come here to do this bullsh—,” Rhoades said. “I want to win, and I don't care if it's a one-point game or a 30 point game. I mean, I've been coaching long enough we all go through this, but I want to win, and I want these guys to win, and to win, a lot of things go into it. So yeah, I mean, I'm pissed.”

The Nittany Lions got out to a quick start to Tuesday’s game, securing a 12-6 lead behind 10 early points by 7-footer Ivan Jurić. The offense then went cold, and despite shooting 31.4% during the first half, Penn State remained in range of Michigan, which led 40-31 at halftime.

Rhoades’ squad battled right out of the gate in the second half, mounting a 6-0 run, but the Wolverines had an answer and grew their lead back out to 53-40. That was a trend throughout much of the half as Michigan led for its entirety.

But Penn State made a late push, and it was one the Wolverines barely survived. Behind free throws by forward Josh Reed and wing Eli Rice in addition to a 3-pointer by guard Melih Tunca, the Nittany Lions only trailed 73-72 with 1:04 left after a 7-0 run.

Penn State generated a stop on defense, but guard Freddie Dilione V missed a mid-range jumper to take a lead with 16 seconds left. Reed then fouled center Aday Mara, who went 1-of-2 at the stripe to give the Nittany Lions another chance.

Coming out of a timeout, Dilione dribbled the ball around halfcourt before attempting an off-balanced 3-pointer that missed, losing the game but having a chance late even without freshman star Kayden Mingo.

“Our guys showed something today,” Rhoades said. “I'm sure everybody at Penn State's proud of it, but let's do more. Let's figure it out. Let's keep building on it. We got the youngest team in the league, one of the youngest teams in the country. Our best player goes down. Yeah, we responded the right way. I'm really proud of it, but I want these guys to win.”

The Nittany Lions begin Big Ten play at 0-4 this season. While there was one blowout loss — Indiana’s 113-72 win on Dec. 9 — the other three games have been decided by single digits.

Penn State’s conference home opener saw it hold a 39-36 lead over No. 9 Michigan State at halftime and even had a 67-64 advantage with 5:00 left in the game. However, the Nittany Lions didn’t score a basket for over four minutes in crunchtime, causing a 76-72 loss.

Last Saturday, Penn State hung around Illinois’ lead for much of the second half, but the Fighting Illini never allowed it to get closer than eight points before a 73-65 loss. Rhoades said he isn't into moral victories.

“I didn't sign up for this. I don't want to do this,” Rhoades said. “I'm here, though, and we're going to figure it out. We're going to fight like crazy to do it. So I'm not dejected. I don't get dejected. I hate losing. I freaking hate it, and I don't want us to ever like it or being close is okay, screw that. We didn't come here to be close.”

title: Analyzing what Matt Campbell has accomplished early in Penn State tenure
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
Matt Campbell and the new staff have been working nonstop since arriving in State College, as they try to build Penn State back into a team that was supposed to compete for a national championship.

It may be early in his tenure, but there’s been a handful of things accomplished by the new regime.

Here’s what’s been done so far.

Retention

Many knew that Campbell would be bringing in his guys from Iowa State to follow him to Happy Valley, but there was uncertainty as to who would stick around from the current Penn State roster.

A good chunk of those projected to contribute in 2026 are staying, notably tight end Andrew Rappleyea, starting right guard Anthony Donkoh, linebacker Tony Rojas and defensive end Max Granville.

As far as the losses went, notable departures from Penn State were linebacker Amare Campbell, safety King Mack, defensive end Chaz Coleman and defensive tackle Xavier Gilliam.

There was bound to be turnover on the coaching staff, as Campbell brought in a large chunk of his Cyclones staff, paired with James Franklin poaching guys to Virginia Tech.

A pair of notable keeps were Terry Smith and Dan Connor.

Upon the initial reported hiring of Campbell, reports came in that Smith would be sticking around on staff after serving as interim head coach. Campbell had a prior relationship with him when he coached at Toledo and Smith was coaching at Gateway High School. On Monday, the staff directory confirmed he will return to being the associate head coach and cornerbacks coach.`

As for Connor, he’ll stick around but is taking a step back from his role. After being promoted from defensive analyst to linebackers coach for the 2025 season, Penn State hired Cincinnati defensive coordinator Tyson Veidt as its next linebackers coach. Connor will be the assistant linebackers coach.

Connor could’ve departed to try and become the lead position coach elsewhere, but the former letterman and Penn State’s all-time leader in tackles chose to stick around.

Methodical with Cyclones who followed

Bringing in quarterback Rocco Becht was the obvious move for Campbell, but Becht’s weapons joined him also. Iowa State’s three leading receivers from 2025, wide receiver Brett Eskildsen, wideout Chase Sowell and tight end Benjamin Brahmer have all pledged to Penn State.

Additionally, starting running back Carson Hansen is on board as well.

Defensively, safety Marcus Neal. Jr., defensive back Jamison Patton and a trio of linebackers in Caleb Bacon, Cael Brezina and Kooper Ebel have pledged as well.

Now, Brahmer will slide in for Luke Reynolds. Neal will fill in for Mack. The trio of aforementioned linebackers will make up the lost production from Amare Campbell.

The other move was on the coaching side, bringing in offensive coordinator/tight ends coach Jake Mouser, quarterbacks coach Jake Water, wide receivers coach Noah Pauley, offensive line coach Ryan Clanton and safeties coach Deon Broomfield.

Each position coach received multiple commits from Iowa State per position, giving them familiarity to build on moving forward as they look to develop them.

New recruiting terrain

During his introductory press conference, Campbell said he's focusing on the 6-8 hour region for recruiting, which likely entails prioritizing Pennsylvania, the northeast and the DMV.

This likely will be the case, but he spent 10 years at Iowa State program with a lack of resources and prestige, he had to cast a wide net and hone in on the midwest.

Campbell will look to dominate Pennsylvania like Franklin once did, but he’s not letting go of the Iowa pipeline. As part of the transfer class, the Nittany Lions are bringing in seven players who are natives of Iowa.

The other state is Nebraska, as Penn State has four committed in their 2026 recruiting class and one as part of the portal group. Of the recruits, four of them are top 10 players in the state.

title: Report: Former Penn State Director of Player Personnel Kenny Sanders heads to Notre Dame
author: Lyle Alenstein | Wrestling Editor
description:
A new home has reportedly been found for a former longtime Nittany Lion recruiting staffer.

According to Matt Zenitz of CBS Sports, ex-Penn State Director of Player Personnel Kenny Sanders is headed to Notre Dame to become the assistant general manager.

Sanders was with Penn State from 2014-19, before leaving to work under then-head coach Mario Cristobal at Oregon as the director of recruiting before returning to State College in 2021.

Over a year later, he earned the title of director of player personnel for the 2022 season.

Sanders played a key role in recruiting the DMV as well as Philadelphia areas. He was a graduate of the McDonogh School in Maryland, which has become a Penn State recruiting hotbed in recent years.

Sanders will work alongside Notre Dame General Manager Mike Martin, who was promoted to the role in the 2025 season from director of scouting advancement. Martin replaced Chad Bowden, who departed for the general manager position at USC.

"Thank you to Penn State and Nittany Nation for 10 unforgettable seasons. I can't put into one post what this place means to me," Sanders wrote on X on Tuesday. "The relationships gained, milestones and life imprints will be with me forever. Special thanks to coach Franklin for everything you did for me and my family and all the opportunities you gave a kid to help impact the program he grew up rooting for."

title: Preview | No. 4 Penn State women’s hockey returns to AHA play, visits Mercyhurst
author: Andrew Mercer | The Daily Collegian
description:
No. 4 Penn State closed out its non-conference stretch on a low note, as the Nittany Lions suffered their first series sweep at the hands of No. 2 Ohio State. The blue and white return to AHA action with an 18-3 record, and remain in-state for a battle with Mercyhurst in Erie, Pennsylvania.

Penn State previously swept the then-No. 15 Lakers on Oct. 17 and Oct. 18, by scores of 3-0 and 6-1, respectively, at Pegula Ice Arena.

Scouting the Lakers

The Lakers return home to the Mercyhurst Ice Center after spending last week in St. Charles, Missouri, in the second half of a four-game series against Lindenwood. On a two-game winning streak, Mercyhurst sits at 13-9-2. Coach Michael Sisti’s squad sits on the cusp of breaking back into the USCHO rankings, recently receiving five votes.

The Lakers’ all-around top performer, Julia Perjus, paces the team with 11 goals and 11 assists on the season. She sits second on Mercyhurst in points only behind Julia Schali, whose team-leading 15 assists bolster her total 23 points.

Sophomore Abby Poitras and freshman Maja Alenius lead the defense with 10 points each, primarily generated by assists. Poitras also paces Mercyhurst with 46 blocked shots, as the first to lay down the body to protect her goaltenders. Right behind her, senior Makayla Javier holds 35 blocks.

Set to start between the pipes, Goaltender Magdalena Luggin, makes her 20th start of the season. In her last meeting with the Nittany Lions, she came in relief for freshman Tara Bach in Game 2 of the series. However, the Vienna, Austria, native made 32 saves on 35 shots in Game 1 before originally being given the day off.

While Mercyhurst endured an up-and-down season, Luggin's play has been solid in the crease. Despite a 9-8-2 record, the sophomore posted a .923 save percentage and 2.35 goals-against average, including a pair of shutouts.

Penn State’s soon-to-be roster changes

Three Nittany Lions will miss collegiate action from Feb. 6 to 22 for the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics, and potentially even before, due to their international duty. This factor makes every series leading up to this date potentially their last for Penn State before heading to the Olympics, including this series against the Lakers.

Tessa Janecke recently broke Penn State’s program record for career goals when she scored her 75th goal in Game 2 against Ohio State. She will be playing for the U.S Olympic women’s ice hockey team, the first Nittany Lion to do so, against teammates Nicole Hall for Sweden and Matilde Fantin for Italy, both of whom are in line to receive honors to their respective Olympic rosters.

Penn State retains much of its offensive and all of its defensive threats despite not being at full strength. Grace Outwater, who wasn’t in the lineup against the Buckeyes, and Maddy Christian lead the blue and white with 13 goals each, while freshman Danica Maynard paces the defense with 20 points.

The AHA landscape

Penn State and Mercyhurst previously sat atop the AHA for the past three seasons, with the Lakers’ dominance dating back to a record 13 AHA championship titles. However, the Nittany Lions boast more recent success, winning the last three AHA championships with Mercyhurst as the runner-up.

In 2022, the year before Penn State’s dynasty began, Mercyhurst fell to Syracuse in the conference championship.

This season, the standings sit as wide-open as they’ve ever been. The Nittany Lions lead the conference with an undefeated 12-0 record and 36 points. The Lakers currently rank second with a 9-4-1 record and 26 points.

Past the two juggernauts, RIT, Robert Morris, and Syracuse are each in a war to decide who’ll earn the higher seed in the AHA tournament. Lindenwood and Delaware round out the standings at the bottom.

title: State College Police Department swears in Joseph Merrill as ninth chief
author: Jonathon Chiu | The Daily Collegian
description:
Joseph Merrill was sworn in as the ninth chief of the State College Police Department (SCPD) during a ceremony Monday.

Merrill, a State College native, began his career as a student auxiliary officer while attending Penn State before spending 20 years with the Altoona Police Department (APD), according to a SCPD press release announcing his appointment. Merrill served in multiple positions in the APD before being appointed as police chief in 2021.

Merrill is an active instructor for many law enforcement programs such as the Pennsylvania Sheriff and Deputy Sheriff Training Academy with the Penn State Justice and Safety Institute, according to the press release.

title: ‘It's tough for Freddie’ | Last-second miss overshadows Freddie Dilione V’s performance vs. Michigan
author: Will Horstman | The Daily Collegian
description:
Guard Freddie Dilione V dribbled the ball around halfcourt of Penn State’s final possession against Michigan. The Nittany Lions were down 74-72, and Dilione had a chance to tie or win.

Dilione took the ball to the right side of the arc, and his 3-point attempt rattled off the rim as Penn State lost its fourth-straight Big Ten game on Tuesday. The redshirt junior was leading the Nittany Lions’ offense throughout the game as freshman star Kayden Mingo didn’t play.

“The last possession, it seemed like they were trying to get (forward Yaxel Lendeborg) off of him, and I thought he did a nice job of switching up and forcing a tough shot,” Michigan coach Dusty May said. “And it's tough for Freddie, because he's made a couple threes in that same situation.”

Dilione finished the game with 17 points, six rebounds and four assists on 6-of-16 shooting from the field and 2-of-6 shooting from 3-point range. While he missed three shots with under two minutes to go, he made back-to-back 3-point attempts earlier in the half to help start Penn State’s comeback.

On that final possession, Dilione said the Nittany Lions were looking to get wing Eli Rice, who’s known as a sharpshooter, a shot.

“(Rice) ended up switching the ball screen,” Dilione said. “Any shot would have been a good shot, just so happens that I ended up missing.”

Dilione was in the starting lineup for the third consecutive game, and he kicked off his night with a layup and two assists as Penn State jumped out to an early 9-4 lead. He finished the first half with six points, but he was battling on the floor elsewhere with five rebounds and three assists.

He fought on the defensive end as well, as he had two steals, including one to kick off a run to start the second half. More deep shots fell in for Dilione during the second half, too, hitting 2-of-3 3-pointers.

Dilione is a usual double-digit scorer for the Nittany Lions, averaging 14.3 points on 48.2% shooting this season. He was averaging 26.7 minutes per game entering the contest versus the Wolverines.

But Dilione was more involved Tuesday night as Mingo, who’s referred to as Penn State’s “head of the snake,” was inactive due to injury.

“When a guy goes down, you rally around them the way you help him and help him get on the mend is play really hard. Play hard for him and play hard for each other,” Rhoades said. “(I) thought our guys did that. We told Freddie he's probably gonna play a lot and handle the ball a lot.”

Dilione did exactly that as he saw 38 minutes throughout Tuesday’s contest. He was a team-high +7 while on the court, and Penn State was -9 in the two minutes he was off the court.

Moving forward, Penn State will be without Mingo for “a little bit,” according to Rhoades. Dilione will likely continue to be the Nittany Lions’ starting point guard in Mingo’s absence.

“Obviously, we want Kayden out there,” Dilione said. “He brings a great presence to the game, and he's obviously a great player. Just know him not being out there, next man mentality, just got to go out there, bring it all, and those are pretty close games.”
